answer: un deux trois quatre cinq (pronounced 'sanq' but the Q is dropped if a word follows cinq)
six ('sees') sept ('set') huit ('ueet') neuf dix ('dees')

vingt ('vah')

vingt-quatre vingt-cinq vingt-six
vingt-sept vingt-huit vingt-neuf

question: For which 10's (under 100) do you have to add elements together?
answer: 70s (60 and add 10 11 12 13 etc to make the 70s) 80s (4 x 20) and 90s (80 and add 10 11 12 13 etc to make the 90s)
trente ('tront')
quarante ('karant'); The Q/K almost sounds like a hard G.
cinquante ('sah-cohnt'); The C/Q sound in the middle almost sounds like a hard G.
soixante ('swois-onT')
soixante-dix ('sois-on-dees')
quatre-vingt ('catre-von')
quatre-vingt-dix ('catre-von-dees')
soixante + soixante et un + soixante-duex + soixant-trois
soixante-dix + soixante et onze (use the 'et' with 1 and 11) + soixante-douze + soixante-treize
quatre-vingts + quatre-vingt-un + quatre-vingt-duex + quatre-vingt-trois

quatre-vingt-dix + quatre-vingt-onze + quatre-vingt-douze + quatre-vingt-treize; NB: to write out numbers add a dash between each word and delete a final S (e.g. from cents) if a word follows it - leave the final S if it is the last word in the number series.
cent (kind of like 'saw' in english but pronounced like sont in french)
cent un ('saw uh')

deux cent un

question: Specify the pronunciation: 2 euros
answer: deux euros ('duh-zoo-rhoh'; The X makes a Z liaison with euro.)

question: Specify the pronunication: 500
answer: cinq cents ('san-sohn'; The Q sound at the end of cinq is dropped because it is followed by a word.)

question: Specify the pronunication: 600 coins
answer: six cents pièces ('see-sohn-pee-ays'); The S at the end of 'cents' is silent because followed by word that does not start with a vowel.

question: Specify the pronunication: 700 cash
answer: sept cents espèces ('sept-sohn-Zeh-spehs); Pronounce the S at the end of 'cents' as a Z because the following word starts with a vowel. A liaison is required.

question: Specify spelling and pronunciation of: 80 + 82 + 80 years.
answer: 80: quatre-vingts (silent S) + 82: quatre-vingt-deux (remove S in spelling because followed by more numbers) + 80 years: quatre-vingts an ('ca-tr-vuhn-Zan'; Keep the S in spelling because that is the word/number. Then the S makes a Z liaison with an because it starts with a vowel.)
mille; Never say: un mille. When you mean exact numbers: mille (1000) + deux mille (2000) + trois mille (3000) etc.; If you mean roughly (but not exactly) one thousand: un millier

question: 1997 (like the year)
answer: Years are spelled out (and spoken) as full numbers: mille-neuf-cent-quatre-vingt-dix-sept
six mille
dix mille (pronounced 'dimil' because we drop the x when a noun follows the 10)
cent mille
un million ...one million
cinq milliOn; Pronounce the end as a strong 'oh'.
un milliaRd (one billion); pronounce the R at the end.

question: 2 billion euros
answer: 2 milliard D'euro; Use DE between the number and the item. Treat the number like any other quantity (e.g. beaucoup + une bouteille + ...)

question: What time is it?
answer: Quelle heure est-il?; pronounced ...'ay-teel' because we link almost all words AND when a vowel follows est then we must pronunce the T - otherwise it would be two vowel sounds together which does not work in french; Use quelle (feminine singular form) because huere is feminine singular.

question: At what time does the class start?
answer: à quelle heure commence la classe?; à quelle heure + VERB + SUBJECT?; NB: Use classe to talk about the time you are at school. Use cours to talk about the type of class you are taking. e.g. un cours de tango (literally: a course of study)

question: the morning (6h to 12h)
answer: le matin

question: midday/noon
answer: midi OR à la mi-journée

question: the afternoon (12h to 18h)
answer: l'après midi

question: the evening(18h to 22h)
answer: le soir

question: the night(22h to 6h)
answer: la nuit ('nyee'; Do not pronounce the T.)

question: midnight
answer: minuit

question: It is 1:00.
answer: Il est une heure.
sept heures; heures is pronounced 'euhr' (same sound as leur)
duex heures cinq; Do not use 'et' (and) if you are using numbers instead of quarter or half.; Pronounce the Q sound at the end of cinq because there is no word following it.
huit heures dix
neuf heures et quart
neuf heures moins le quart; !!when you use demi/quart then you cannot use military time
quatre heures vingt
cinq heures et demie
quatorze heures moins vingt-cinq
dix-sept heures moins vingt

question: 9 o'clock in the morning / afternoon / evening.
answer: 9h DU matin / DE l'après-midi / DU soir; DE + LE/LA + time of day is the correct structure for expressing doing something at some time of day or the time at some time of day.; We are referring to a specific instant - not a duration. So use matin + jour + soir + etc

question: 1 o'clock in the morning (late night)
answer: une heure DU matin; Use matin (like english) even though it is before dawn.

question: I will leave at 20 (minutes) past the hour.
answer: Je pars à vingt.; This is a more common expression in french than in English. You can use this structure to say that something will happen at some time (some minute) when the hour is assumed.

question: a second + a minute + an hour
answer: une seconde (the C almost sounds like a hard G) + une minute + une heure (liaison 'ooh-noohr'); All denominations of time are feminine.

question: first + firstly
answer: 1e OR en premier/première (m/f) + premièrement; '1e' is how you write floors of a building and the arrodissiments (e.g. 5e arrodissiment); Transform an adjective that ends in a consonant by selecting the feminine version of the adjective. Then add -MENT. This ensures a vowel is present before -MENT ending.

question: second + secondly
answer: deuxième / 2e (doo-ziem) + deuxièmement

question: third
answer: troisième / 3e (twah-ziem)

question: fourth
answer: quatrième / 4e (ke-treim)

question: fifth
answer: cinqième / 5e (sanq-em)

question: sixth
answer: sixième / 6e (see-ziem)

question: seventh
answer: septième / 7e (seeup-tiem)

question: eighth
answer: huitième / 8e (wheat-iem)

question: ninth
answer: neuvième / 9e (nu-viem)

question: tenth
answer: dixième / 10e (dee-ziem)

question: eleventh
answer: onzième / 11e (ohn-ziem)

question: firstly
answer: premièrement; Use this when you are enumerating items or things that happened or will happen

question: secondy
answer: deuxièmement

question: a half (1/2) + a third (1/3)
answer: un demi + un tiers

question: a fourth (1/4) + a fifth (1/5)
answer: un quart + un cinquième
dix pour cent OR sur dix (a tenth)
vingt-cinq pour cent OR sur quatre (a quarter)

question: the 10th + the 20th + the 30th
answer: le dixième + le vingtième + le trentième

question: the 21st + the 22nd + the 23rd + the 31st
answer: le vingt et unième + le vingt-deuxième + le vingt-troisième + le trente et unième

question: the 100th (the hundredth) + the thousandth + the millionth
answer: le centième + le millième + le millionième

question: How do you pronounce: 6 people + 8 people + 10 people?
answer: six personnes ('see-pear-sohn') + huit personnes ('ooeet-pear-sohn') + dix personnes ('dee-pear-sohn'); Take care to drop the ending sound of the number when a noun follows it - NOT 'sees-pear-sohn' or 'dees-pear-sohn'.

question: How to pronounce a b c d e
answer: ah beh seh deh uh (like wool but the lips are a bit puckered and the sound is made high in the mouth; same sound as ö in german)

question: How to pronounce f g h i j
answer: eff zhey (like massage) ah-sh ee zhee/jhee

question: How to pronounce k l m n o
answer: kah ell ehm ehn oh

question: How to pronounce p q r s t
answer: peh keoo (like KEE with rounded lips) ehr ess teh

question: How to pronounce u v w x y z
answer: eew veh doobluh-veh eeks ee-grehk zehd

question: How are the following pronounced differently? à + â + a?
answer: no difference - these are all pronounced the same

question: How do you pronounce accent grave vs la grève (the strike)?
answer: grave ('grahv')...normal A sound in french / grève ('grave')... e with downward accent is pronounced like a hard A in english

question: How is 'an' pronounced differently than 'on'?
answer: 'an' is an open sound. The mouth is like in a big smile. The sound is nasal but towards the back of the nose/mouth. Pronunced like 'aunt' in British English.; 'on' is a closed sound. The mouth forms an o-shape. The sound is nasal but towards the front of the nose/mouth. The sound is short and a bit downward like a pout.

question: Pronounce these words with a regular A sound: la + ma + sa
answer: A on its own is spoken very strongly + sharply + emphatically: la ('lAh') + ma ('mAh') + sa ('sAh');NB: It is important to prounounce an A strongly because this is one of the ways to indicate gender (e.g. MA maison).

question: How are these differently? 'an' + 'am' + 'en' + 'em'
answer: There is almost no difference between these syllables because 1) The vowel sound is exactly the same - a very nasal augmented E sound 2) The consonants (N or M) are not really pronounced.

question: Pronounce these words with an open AN / EN sound: banc + sans + lent + Septembre + grand + jambre + champ + langue + dans + en + éléphant
answer: EN and AN sound like 'ohn' but with the corners of the mouth pulled back. Think 'aunt' in British English.; banc ('bohnk') + sans ('sohn') + lent ('lohn') + Septembre ('sehp-tohmbr') + grand ('grohn') + jambre ('zshohmbr') + champ ('shohm') + langue ('lohng') + dans ('dohn') + en ('ohn') + éléphant (ay-lay-fohn')

question: Pronounce these words with a closed AN / ENT which sounds more like like 'ohn': an (year) + camp + tante + vent (wind)
answer: an ('ohn') + camp ('kohm') + tante ('tohnt') + vent ('vohn')

question: How do you pronounce the written 'ai'?
answer: like 'ay'; e.g. j'ai is pronounced 'zshay'; Generally it is best practice to keep vowel sounds short - do not drag them out.

question: How do you pronounce the written 'au'?
answer: like a closed 'o' (called a hard O in English); e.g. au revoir ('oh-rev-ror') + aujourd'hui ('ohn-jer-dwee'); NB: AU makes the same sound as EAU and as Ô.

question: Pronounce the following: sauce + pause + épaule
answer: AU makes the same sound as EAU and as Ô... a hard/closed/downward O: sauce ('soes') + pause ('pose') + épaule ('ay-pole'); NB: AU is pronounced as one syllable but UA is pronounced as two syllables - two separate vowels.

question: What is this called: ç? And what does it do?
answer: C cédille; Ç is used to change the sound of a C from a hard K sound to a soft S sound. This is only necessary when the C is followed by A or O or U.; We do NOT need to make C cédille for ce or ci because those already sound like S. That is why c'est does not use C cédille.

question: How do you pronounce 'ce' and 'ci'?
answer: The C here is soft like S so 'suh' and 'see'; to make it sound harder like K you write 'cue' + 'cui'

question: How do you pronounce 'ca' and co' and 'cu'?
answer: The C in this cases is pronounced like a hard K.; To make the C sound like an S... use C cédille ...'ça' + 'ço' + 'çu'

question: How do you pronounce 'ça' and 'ço' and 'çu'?
answer: The C cédille changes the C from a K-sound to an S-sound: 'sa' and 'so' and 'su'.

question: Pronounce these words with 'ch': réchauffement + chou + chauflouer
answer: CH sounds like a soft 'sh' in English. réchauffement ('ray-showf-mohn') + chou ('show') + chauflouer ('show-floo-ay'); NB: The only words in french where CH makes the hard sound like 'chorizo' are words that are foreign to french. e.g. cheque from Czech.

question: Pronounce these words that end in -CIAL: artificial + provincial
answer: artificial ('ahr-tee-fee-see-ehl') + provincial ('pro-vee-nsee-ehl'); When a french word ends in -CIAL pronounce it the same as the word for sky: ciel.

question: When is a 'd' pronounced like T?
answer: When a liaison is required and the end of the first word is D. When you apply the liaison the ending D is pronounced as a T sound (e.g. un grand architecte is pronounced 'uhn-gran-Tar-shee-tehkt')

question: How is a regular E pronounced in french?
answer: The lips are in an O-shape. Say 'uh'. So it is a mix between an english 'uh' and 'oh'.

question: Pronounce these words with a regular E sound ('uh' but with lips in O-shape): ce + que + petit + devez + sera + me + je + de + cheveaux + chemise + regard + depuis
answer: All with lips very rounded almost making an O sound: de ('duh') + me ('muh') + je ('zshuh') + ce ('suh') + que ('kuh') + petit ('puh-tee') + devez ('duh-vay') + sera ('suh-ra') + cheveaux ('zshuh-voh') + chemise ('zshuh-mees') + regard ('ruh-gar') + depuis ('duh-pwee'); NB: Avoid making any kind of R or gutteral sound unless there is actually an R in the word.

question: How are these pronounced: de + cent?
answer: These are NOT both regular E sounds. EN sounds different than E because the consonants around an E change it's sounds.; DE is pronounced 'dUh' with lips very rounded. CENT is pronounced 'sOhn'. For both the lips are rounded but the pronuciation of cent (EN) is much more nasal.

question: What is the name of this character and how is it pronounced? é
answer: L'accent aigu (acute accent) sounds like 'ay' instead of a regular e which sounds like 'uh'; Most of the time accent marks do not impact pronunciation significantly. É is the major exception.

question: What is the name of this character and how is it pronounced? è
answer: L'accent grave (grave accent) is pronounced exactly the same as ê... sounds like a light 'eh' sound with open mouth; e.g. lève ('lev')

question: What is the name of this character and how is it pronounced? ê
answer: L'accent circonflexe (circumflex) is pronounced exactly the same as è... sounds like a light 'eh' sound with open mouth; e.g. lève ('lev')

question: Pronounce these words with the open È or Ê sound (ouvert) which sounds like 'eh' in english: êtes + près
answer: êtes ('eht') + près ('preh')

question: Pronounce these words with the closed E sound (ferme) which sounds like 'ay' in english: pied + ses + et + chez
answer: pied ('pee-ay') + ses ('say') + et ('ay') + chez ('shay')

question: Pronounce these words where the EU is pronounced in an open way: ingénieur + beurre + peur + seul + fleur + cœur + cooleur + heures + leur
answer: with flattened mouth and an open sound high in the mouth (like a mix between 'uh' and 'ooh'): ingénieur ('uhn-juh-neuhr') + beurre ('beuhr') + peur ('peuhr') + seul ('seuhl') + fleur ('fleuhr') + cœur ('ceuhr') + cooleur ('coo-leuhr') + heures ('heuhr') + leur ('leuhr')

question: Pronounce these words where the EU is pronounced in a closed way: peu + ceux + feu + veux + monsieur + bleu + euro + cheveu
answer: with a closed rounded mouth but the sound is still high in the mouth (not a deep U sound): peu ('poo') + ceux ('coo') + feu ('foo') + veux ('voo') + monsieur ('mohn-soo') + bleu ('bloo') + euro ('oo-roh') + cheveu ('shuh-voo'; The first e sounds like a regular french E. The second E is followed by U so together they make the 'oo' sound).

question: Pronounce these words: veux + adieu + lieu
answer: veux ('voo'; EU makes the 'oo' sound.) + adieu ('ah-dyoo'; an I infront of EU forces us to add a Y sound before the 'oo' sound - two verb sounds spoken sequentially) + lieu ('lyoo'; an I infront of EU forces us to add a Y sound before the 'oo' sound - two verb sounds spoken sequentially)

question: How are these words pronounced differently? un œil (an eye) + des yeux (eyes)
answer: UN ŒIL ('uhn-oouhy'; there are two vowel sounds in the last syllable but it is pronounced smashed together as one syllable. The mouth is open and flattened.; DES YEUX ('dayz-yoo'; The sound is still in the top of the mouth but the 'oo' sound is more closed than in œil.; There is a liaison but we still hear the Y sound.

question: Pronounce these words with EAU (sounds like a hard O): chapeau + l'eau + bureau + bateau + cerveau + château
answer: chapeau ('shah-poe') + l'eau ('loe') + bureau ('bu-roe') + bateau ('bah-toe') + cerveau ('cuh-rvoe') + château ('shah-toe'); EAU and AU and Ô all make the same sound - a hard O where the sound is at the bottom of the mouth. The tone is very short and downward.

question: How are these pronounced differently?: -ez / -er / -é / -et / -ai
answer: They are pronounced exactly the same. They are used often in verbs.

question: How do you pronounce: intermittent? Focus on the E sound in the middle of the word.
answer: 'uhn-tEHr-mee-tohn' The second syllable is not the regular E sound ('uh'). It is almost like the english word air but more aspirated.

question: When is G pronounced softly 'zsh' vs hard 'ghu'?
answer: 'ge' and 'gi' are soft; 'ga' and 'go' and 'gu' have the hard g sound. But this will change some if accents are added on the vowels.

question: When is J pronounced softly 'zsh' vs hard 'ghu'?
answer: J is always pronounced as a soft sound.

question: Pronounce these words with the soft 'zsh' sound: rejeter + danger + écologie
answer: rejeter ('ruh-zshuh-tay') + danger ('dahn-zshay') + écologie ('ay-kohl-oh-zshee')

question: How are these words pronounced differently: gare (train station) + guerre (war)
answer: gare ('gahr' rhymes with car) + guerre ('gehr' rhymes with air)

question: How do you prounounce 'h' at the beginning of a word?
answer: It's completely silent and you ignore it. This means that if the second word in the letter is a vowel - then you may need to use a liaison to connect.

question: How do you pronounce î and ï differently?
answer: These are pronounced exactly the same.

question: How do you pronounce double I (ii) in french?
answer: It makes a Y sound.; This happens with verbs in the imparfait tense in the nous and vous forms. e.g. ÉTUDIER: nous étudiions + vous étudiiez

question: How do you pronounce all of these written syllables: in + ain + ein + en + yn?
answer: It's an open nasal sound that is a mix between 'ohn' and 'uhn' - like INgénieur ('uhn-geh-noor').; NB: If you switch the consonant from N to M (for all of these) the pronunciation is almost exactly the same because we don't really pronounce the consonant.

question: Pronounce these words with an open 'in' sound: INgénieur(e) + main + train + chien + fin + coin + nain + pain + rien + saint + teint + lien + vin + chien + point + prochain
answer: INgénieur ('AHN-zshay-noor') is leading example for this group + main ('mahn') + train ('trahn') + chien ('shee-ahn') + fin ('fahn') + coin ('kwahn') + nain ('nahn') + pain ('pahn')+ rien ('ray-ahn')+ saint ('sahn') + teint ('tahn') + lien ('lay-ahn') + vin ('vahn') + chien ('shee-ahn') + point ('pwahn') + prochain ('proe-shahn')

question: How do you pronounce important + inéligible + immueble? Why?
answer: important ('UHM-por-tahn' with the same open 'uhn' sound as ingénieur) + inéligible ('EE-nay-lee-zsheebl') + immueble ('EE-mobl'); Generally IN + consonant is pronounced like a regular french I 'uhn'. Generally IN + vowel is pronounced like a hard E in english 'ee'.; Immueble does not follow these rules because the double consonnant MM changes the sounds of the vowel before it.

question: Pronounce these words with a long 'eel' sound: pile + il + fil (thread) + bile + avril + gilet + huile
answer: pile ('peel') + il ('eel') + fil ('feel') + bile ('beel') + avril ('ah-vreel') + gilet ('zshee-lay') + huile ('ooeel')

question: Pronounce these words with a long 'eey' sound because the combination of 'ille' like Y in french: pille + famille + fille + grill + grille + maquillage + billet
answer: pille ('peey') + famille ('fa-meey') + fille ('feey') + grill ('gril'; This does not have lle so the sound is like an L instead of a Y) + grille ('greey') + maquillage ('ma-key-ahj') + billet ('bee-yay'); NB: ville is an exception as it is pronounced 'veel'.; NB: The combination 'elle' does not result in a Y sound. e.g. elle + voyelle

question: How do you pronounce words that end in -ER differently from words that end in -IER? e.g. cuisiner vs cuisinier
answer: -ER is pronounced 'ay'. -IER is pronounced 'yay' with two Y sounds. cuisiner ('qwee-suh-nay') = to cook. cuisinier ('qwee-suh-nYay') = a professional cook.

question: inalienable (as in a right); Specify the pronunciation.
answer: inaliénables ('EEN-ah-lee-ah-nabl'); NB: When IN is a prefix AND the N is between two vowels (as it in this case) instead of part of the word (like ingénieur)

question: indiscipline; Specify the pronunciation.
answer: indiscipline ('UHN-dis-ee-plin'); IN is a prefix in this case but the N is not between two vowels. So the IN is pronounced the same as ingénieur.

question: How do you pronounce 'll' in french and what are the two exceptions?
answer: ll is pronounced like Y (e.g. fille = 'feey' and famille = 'fa-meey'); the two exceptions are mille ('mil') and ville ('vil') which are pronounced like L

question: How do you pronounce 'r' at end of a word?
answer: light 'gh' at back of throat - put tongue at the top of back of mouth and blow air across it almost like a hiss (e.g. noir + catre + être) - it's more like a rolling g instead of a rolling r; If it's at the end of the word then you hit it quickly and lightly.

question: How do you pronounce 'r' in the middle of a word or when linking words?
answer: strong gurgling 'gh' witha trilling at the back of the throat.; Take care not to trill with the tongue which is a spanish R - not a french R.; When the R occurs in the middle of a word or link then you hit it very hard - as hard as the 'th' sound in english.

question: How to you pronounce 's' at the end of word? what about 'se'?
answer: if just one 's' then it is completely silent; but if an e follows the s 'se' (like française) then it makes a z sound

question: When is the S pronounced in 'plus'?
answer: Most of the time the S is silent. But there are exceptions where the S is pronounced: 1) PLUS + adjective beginning with vowel because it forms liaison (e.g. plus importante)  2) PLUS DE + noun because we are referring to a quantity 3) + the sign for addition 4) When PLUS is at the end of phrase (e.g. plus en plus: both S are pronounced. The first one because of liaison and the second because it is at the end of the phrase.

question: Which combinations of letters produce an S sound (instead of K or Z)?
answer: s (when not between two vowels) + ss + + sc + c + tion ('seeon')

question: How do you pronounce the french word association?
answer: 'ah-so-see-ay-syon'; almost every syllable has an S sound; TION in french is 'seeon'

question: How do you pronounce words that end in -TION?
answer: The ending is a very sharp 'seeon' - as quick and emphatic as non; It's very quick with a downward tone almost like a pout. There is no 't' or 'sh' sound as in english and spanish.

question: How do you pronounce le métro odéon?
answer: luh-may-tro-da-yon'; everything flows together and é is pronounced 'ay' instead of 'uh'

question: How do you pronounce 'oi'?
answer: 'wah' e.g. the king = le roi ('rwah') e.g. the law = la loi ('lwa')

question: Pronounce these words with an open 'o' sound (ouvert): personne + robe + mort + école + l'alcool (alcohol) + soldat (soldier) + hotte (hood)
answer: Sound is at the top of the mouth: personne ('pear-sohn') + robe ('rob') + mort ('mohr') + école ('ay-cohl') + l'alcool ('lal-cohl') + soldat ('sohl-da') + hotte ('hoht'); Remember that a double consonant can change the sound of the vowel that precedes the pair. e.g. personne

question: Pronounce these words with a closed 'o' or 'ô' sound (ferme): hôpital + diplôme + mot + policier + chocolat + dossier + pot + l'eaux + peau
answer: In english it is called a hard O. Mouth rounded. Sound in the bottom of the mouth. Short/downward tone.; hôpital ('ope') + diplôme ('ome') + mot ('moe') + policier ('poe-lee-seeay') + chocolat ('choe-coh-lah') + dossier ('doe-seeay') + pot ('poe') + l'eaux ('loe') + peau ('poe'); NB: This sound occurs with both o and ô. The accent does not make a large difference.

question: Pronounce these words with a closed 'on' sound: bon + don + son + long + Montpellier + oncle
answer: bon ('bohn') + don ('dohn') + son ('sohn') + long ('lohn') + Montpellier ('mohn-peh-leeay') + oncle ('ohncl')

question: How do you pronounce the 'o' at the end of a word? e.g. vélo + zéro + apéro + photo + bistro + numéro
answer: When an O is at the end of a word then use the closed/ferme sound with a short and downward tone. Do not drag it out. It is same sound as -eau at end of a word. The last syllable receives a lot of emphasis.

question: How is 'un homme' pronounced differently than 'un nom'?
answer: Un homme uses an open O sound. It is pronounced like a mix between 'ah-nohm' and 'ah-nahm'.; Un nom has closed O sound. It is pronunced like 'ah-nome'.; Both use liaison but the only way to tell the difference between these two when speaking is to differentiate the O sound.

question: How are these pronounced differently?: un os (bone) + des os (bones)
answer: un os ('uhn-ohs') is open/ouvert with sound at the top of the mouth. des os ('day-zoh') is closed/ferme with downward tone.

question: How are these pronounced differently?: on / -ont / -ons
answer: They are pronounced exactly the same. They are used often in verbs. The sound is very nasal.

question: How do you practice the difference between OU and U?
answer: Alternate saying: koukou and kuku. koukou is higher in the mouth with tongue pulled back from teeth. kuku is more downward with rounded lips and tongue resting on the bottom teeth.

question: How do you pronounce 'ou' (an open sound)? How do you pronounce these words: ou + où + nous + vous + sous + dessous + bouche + fou + four + jour + cour + route?
answer: OU is pronounced somewhat like an English U (the short and clear 'oo' sound like in food). But the mouth is in a flattened shape and slightly open. The tongue rests on the bottom teeth.; With the mouth in a flattened shape.: ou ('oo') + où ('oo') + nous ('noo') + vous ('voo') + sous ('soo') + dessous ('duh-soo') + bouche ('boosh') + fou ('foo') + four ('foor') + jour ('joor') + cour ('koor') + route ('root'); NB: VOUS (like 'food') is pronounced differently than VU (uses the french U sound which is more like 'ewww' with lips in pursed o-shape); The following spellings are all pronounced with the same sound: ou + où + ous + oux + oû + ow + hou + houx

question: How do you pronounce 'u' (a closed sound)? How do you pronounce these words: tu + Hugo + vu + eu (avoir passé composé) + musique + voiture + minute + rue + avenue + bus + rue + vue + mur + Lune + sucre + puce (chip)?
answer: The french 'U' is very different than the English U (which is pronounced like 'food'). The french U is a long 'ewwww' sound with pursed and rounded lips (o-shape). Really stress the EWW part - it is not just a deep U. The tongue is pulled back from the teeth.; The sound has a deep and downward tone / low in the mouth. You should feel reverberation of the sound - like a bass speaker.; tu ('teuww') + Hugo ('euww-go') + vu ('veuww') + eu ('euww') + musique ('meuww-zik') + voiture ('vwa-teuwwr') + minute ('mee-neuwwt') + rue ('reuww') + avenue ('ah-vuh-neuww') + bus ('beuwws') + rue ('reuww') + vue ('veuww') + mur ('meuww') + Lune ('leuwwn') + sucre ('seuwwkr') + puce ('peuwws')

question: How are these words pronounced differently? DEUX (2) + DOUZE (12)
answer: DEUX = mix between 'duh' and 'dooh' with flattened mouth and an open sound; DOUZE = 'dewwwz' the very deep french U sound with downward and closed tone - where the sound is not on the top of the mouth.

question: What's the difference in pronunciation between u and û and ù?
answer: There is no difference. These are all pronounced like the french 'U' which is very different than in English.; It's a long 'ewwww' sound with pursed and rounded lips (o-shape) in French. The tongue rests on the bottom teeth. It's not the 'oo' sound that we use for U in English.; NB: Even though u and û are pronounced the same in french they will change the meaning of a word in writing.

question: Pronounce these phrases to clarify the difference between EU and OU: Je peux. Je veux. chez eux. vs... nous vous doux tout
answer: The EU sound is high in the mouth and a combination of 'uh' and 'oo'. The OU sound is like an English 'oo'.

question: Pronounce these phrases to clarify the difference between EU and U: Je peux. J'ai pu. Je veux. Ja'i vu.
answer: The U sound is much lower in the mouth with more of an 'ewww' sound.

question: How do you pronounce: l'accentuation (emphasis)?
answer: 'lahk-suhn-syOO-Ah-syon'; UA is pronounced as two separate vowels. This is different from AU which is pronounced as single 'oh' sound.

question: How do you pronounce Y?
answer: Treat it like I. Y is a vowel in french.

question: How do you pronounce Zoe + Zoé?
answer: 'zo' + 'zo-ee'

question: How do you pronounce each of these words?: cent (hundred) + sent (I feel/smell) + sont (e.g. Elles sont...)
answer: cent ('suhn') and sent ('suhn') are pronounced exactly the same with the sound higher in the mouth. sont ('sohn') is pronounced lower in the mouth and with a more downward tone.

question: How do you know whether or not to pronounce the 'e' at the end of a word?
answer: Never pronounce an E (without accent) at the end of a word.; If the E has an accent (e.g. é) then you pronounce it as 'ay' regardless of where it is in the word.

question: How do you know whether or not to pronounce a consonant at the end of a word?
answer: 1)DPST ('DePoSiTo') never pronounce these consonants at the end of a word - but pronounce them lightly if followed by 'e'; 2) LCFR ('lucifer') are the only four consonants that are pronounced when at the end of a word (e.g. aérobic) OR if at the end and followed only by an 'e' (e.g. livre) - otherwise the final consonants (regardless of if they are followed by an 'e') are not pronounced unless feminine adjective

question: Pronounce petit (masc singular) + petite (fem singular) + petits (masc plural) + petites (fem plural)
answer: 'puh-tee' + 'puh-teet' + 'puh-tee' + 'puh-teet'

question: When might you need to use a liaison between a two words?
answer: If the first word ends in a consonant and the second word starts with a vowel (or H muet = silent H).; NB: If the second word starts with an H aspiré (apirated H) then you cannot form a liaison. e.g. un homme ('uhn-ohm'; with liaison because H in homme is a silent H) + un héros ('uhn-hay-ro'; no liaison because H in héros is aspirated)

question: What is the difference between 1) liaison obligatoire 2) liaison facultative 3) liaison interdite? When do you use them?
answer: 1) Liaison obligatoire (obligatory) must be used in order to be understood in any scenario. There are many types of liaison obligatoire.; 2) Liaison facultative (optional) are used in formal settings. One typically does not use these in casual situations among friends.; 3) Liaison interdite (forbidden) are word combinations where the liaison is forbidden.

question: What are three major types of liaison obligatoire? (there are more than 3 in total)
answer: 1) Between a subject pronoun and its verb: Nous‿avons... Peut‿-on... but never make a liaison between a subject/verb when the subject is not a pronoun.; 2) Between le déterminent (e.g. article) and its noun: un‿intérêt + les‿amis + mes‿amis + quels‿adorables; 3) Between these prepositions and their object: dans + chez + sans + en. e.g. dans‿une maison + sans‿objectif + chez‿eux + en‿avance

question: Which liaisons should you focus on first?
answer: 1) Start by making sure to use liaisons after all verbs. It occurs frequently and helps you to know the spelling of things: e.g. C'est importé ('tim'). C'est is one of the most common phrases and it makes a liaison when it is followed by a vowel.) e.g. Je vais au… (‘zay’ lets you know that the ending of the verb is a S.) Ils parlent à…(‘tah’ lets you know that the ending of the verb must be -ENT so the subject must be plural).; 2) Then focus on using liaisons to identify a plural: e.g. fleurs exotiques (‘zeh’) lets you know that the flowers are plural.

question: How do you pronounce these? dans une heure + dans une usine
answer: Both phrases have two obligatory liaison - first between preposition and its object and second between a déterminant and its noun. dans‿une‿heure ('dan-zoo-noor') + dans‿une‿usine ('dan-zoo-noo-zeen')

question: After which two words is there never a liaison?
answer: 1) ET (and) 2) All the forms of tout (tout/toute/tous/toutes); e.g. et une café. There is no liaison between et and une ...even though the first word ends in a consonant and the second word starts with a vowel.; e.g. and Anna = et Anna ('ay-a-na') We do not hear the T from et even though Anna starts with a vowel.

question: When you are spelling a word out loud how to you say two A or two L or two O?
answer: duex A ('duh-za') + deux L ('duh-zelle') + deux O ('duh-zoo'); liaison Z is added

question: How do you pronounce: Quand est-ce qu'on arrive? (When do we arrive?)
answer: 'koh-Te-skuh-na-reev'; When the word quand (when) makes a liason... the ending D makes a T sound.

question: What is the rule for pronouncing phrases?
answer: The words in a phrase are linked like singing and the last syllable is drawn out more than the others. e.g. Vous allez bien is pronounced 'voo-za-lay-bee-uuuuuhn'

question: How do you pronounce two sequential words where the first word ends in a vowel and the second word starts with a vowel?
answer: You make a very clear break between the two verbs to ensure they do not run together. e.g. J'ai eu ('jay' 'oo'; not 'jayoo')

question: Explain how academic disciplines are pronounced.
answer: They can be spelled and spoken with full greek ending (e.g. sociology + philosophy + physiology) but generally they are spoken and written as socio + philo + physio etc.

question: What does it mean if you see 'a' without accent?
answer: An 'a' alone (without accent) is always a verb - the conjugated form of avoir; Remember you always need to add an accent (grave or aigu) to a lone 'a' if you do not mean the verb avoir

question: How do you conjugate for 'we' when speaking?
answer: Use nous ___ for writing. Use on ___ for speaking. (same conjugation as il/elle) There is often a liaison between 'on' and the verb.; Two critical exceptions when speaking: 1) You must conjugate the verb in the nous form if you spell out the subjects. e.g. Jacques et moi ALLONS (not va) au magasin. 2) You must use NOUS (instead of on) when you started by spelling out the subjects or if you already used nous. e.g. Jacques et moi allons au magasin` NOUS allons (not on va) ensemble.

question: three ways to say no
answer: 1) non (no); 2) moi non pas/plus (not for me); 3) si (when you are contradicting a negative statement - e.g. Vous n'êtes pas Caroline? Si je suis Caroline)

question: me too
answer: moi si ("mwow-see"); This is the opposite of moi non pas/plus (not for me)

question: How do you make a noun plural?
answer: generally just add 's' but don't pronounce it - does not impact pronunciation; there are only a few exceptions (for example sometimes you add x like un bateau changes to des bateaux)

question: How do form the plural of nouns that end in -al? (e.g. un animal)
answer: -al becomes -aux ('oh'); e.g. un animal des animaux; e.g. un festival des festivaux; e.g. végétal végétaux

question: thank you
answer: merci

question: please (formal and informal)
answer: s'il te plaît (when you are familiar) / s'il vous plaît (when you are unfamiliar) = S.V.P.; Literally: if it pleases you

question: Three idiomatic ways to say: You're welcome.
answer: 1) very casual/everyday use: de rien ('duh-rian') literally means 'it's nothing' 2) friendly with generosity: avec plaisir ('plah-Zeer') literally means 'with pleasure'; 3) very polite: Je vous en prie. ('zshuh-voo-zohn-pree') This is something that a vendor in a store would say to a client.

question: Which pleasantry should you say when someone is talking or minding their own business but you need to interupt them for some reason?
answer: Excusez-moi; Use this when you need to ask someone something on the street or when a professor is talking but you really need to interupt to say something. Use excusez-moi when you are asking forgiveness for something that you are doing intentionally.

question: Which pleasantry should you say when you make an unintentional mistake?
answer: Pardon; Use this when you've made an error or inconvenience but is was completely unintentional. e.g. when you accidentally bump into someone e.g. when you make an error in class. If it is a grave error then you might add 'je suis désolé(e)' to express that you are sorry.

question: How do you accept an invitation - the equivalent of 'Yes I would like to'
answer: Je veux bien. ('voo' but at the top of the mouth - not the deep U sound) This uses the verb vouloir (to want).; NB: Be careful to make the distinction between Je veux ('voo' at the top of the mouth) bien = I want to do it! AND Je vais ('vay') bien = I'm doing well.

question: Thank you for...
answer: Je vous remercie pour/de... OR Merce de...; The choice of POUR or DE depends on the context.

question: Thank you for the advice / the tip(s).
answer: Merci du conseil. (if one tip) + Merci des conseils. (if more than one tip).; Do not un astuce in this way.

question: Thank you for inviting me.
answer: Merci de m'avoir invité.; NB: Inviter means to pay for someone at dinner (for example).

question: Thank you for your help.
answer: Merci pour votre aide ('vot-red').; The help and the wait are nouns in this case. Literally: Thank you for your help/wait.

question: Thank you for waiting.
answer: Merci pour votre attendre.; The help and the wait are nouns in this case. Literally: Thank you for your help/wait.

question: idiomatic way to express: You get me. / You really got me.
answer: Tu m'as bien cerné.

question: He is waving. / He says hi!
answer: Il te salut. = He says hello to you.; NB: The word for wave in french does not work to mean a greeting - only the feature of water.

question: I want to introduce Anna.
answer: Je veux présenter Anna.

question: I will introduce myself. (e.g. the thing you say at the beginning of a job interview)
answer: Je me présente.

question: Ella introduced me to Ethan.
answer: Ella m'a présenté Ethan.; There is no preposition between the verb and the person being introduced/presented (direct object).

question: Ella introduced Isa to Ethan.
answer: Ella a présenté Isa à Ethan.; There is no preposition between the verb and the person being introduced/presented (COD). Use À between the verb and the indirect object (the person to whom the introduction/presentation is happening).

question: I know Isa through Ella.
answer: Je connais Isa grâce à Ella. OR Je connais Isa par Ella.; To express being familiar with something: Je connais + noun/person.

question: a greeting that is strictly formal and a greeting that is strictly informal
answer: enchanté (pleased to meet you only when formal) + salut (for hello only when familiar); SALUER = to greet or to say goodbye

question: How do you greet someone in the morning + in the afternoon + in the evening (starting 18:00)?
answer: Bonjour. + Bon après-midi. + Bonsoir.; For politeness add Madame/Monsieur.; NB: Use -jour and -soir for greetings. Use journée and soirée (the durations) for the salutation when leaving.

question: when leaving someone: Have a nice day. + Have a good afternoon. + Have a good evening. + Good night!
answer: Bonne journée. + Bon après-midi. + Bonne soirée. + Bonne nuit.; For politeness add Madame/Monsieur.

question: Have a good weekend!
answer: Bonne week-end!; NB: 'fin de semaine' means Friday - not the weekend

question: See you later! (today). + See you soon! (but no today)
answer: À tout à l'heure! + À bientôt!;  NB: Add À in front of the word to make it a salutation. If you are simply saying the word for tomorrow or a day of the week - then just use the word without à in front of it. e.g. On va aller demain. = We will go tomorrow. On va aller mercredi. = We will go on Wednesday.; NB: tout à l'heure can also mean previously.

question: See you next week!
answer: À la semaine prochaine!; NB: prochain(e)(s) moves in front of the noun if we change the noun to be plural.

question: Until tomorrow!
answer: À demain! ('ah-doo-ma'); NB: Add À in front of the word to make it a salutation. If you are simply saying the word for tomorrow or a day of the week - then just use the word without à in front of it. e.g. On va aller demain. = We will go tomorrow. On va aller mercredi. = We will go on Wednesday.

question: goodbye
answer: au revoir; In Paris this is pronounced as two syllables 'ohrv-wah'.; For politeness add Madame/Monsieur.

question: I'm glad/happy to see you. (in the moment when you see someone)
answer: content(e) de te voir; Just this. Omit the submit and verb completely.; être content(e)/heureux(euse)/ravi(e) trigger DE.

question: I was glad/happy to see you.
answer: J'étais content(e) DE te voir.; être content(e)/heureux(euse)/ravi(e) trigger DE.

question: I am happy that I saw it.
answer: Je suis content(e) DE l'avoir vu.; être content(e)/heureux(euse)/ravi(e) trigger DE.

question: I am happy to come. + I am excited to come.
answer: Je suis heureux(euse) DE venir. + Je suis ravi(e) DE venir.; être content(e)/heureux(euse)/ravi(e) trigger DE.

question: I am happy to be back in Paris.
answer: Je suis content(e) d'être de retour à Paris.; If instead you said something like: Je suis content(e) de retourner à Paris. ...this means you are happy to return in the future.; être content(e)/heureux(euse)/ravi(e) trigger DE.

question: I am very happy to be able to retake the exam.
answer: Je suis très content(e) DE pouvoir repasser l'examen.; être content(e)/heureux(euse)/ravi(e) trigger DE.

question: I am looking forward to it.
answer: J'ai hâte. OR Je suis impatiente.; Do not add EN or a complement (object). Simply J'ai hâte. You must use DE following J'ai hâte AND Je suis impatient ...to explain to what you are looking forward. e.g. J'ai hâte d'y être. = I'm looking forward to be there.

question: I look forward to seeing you! / I can't wait to see you.
answer: J’ai hâte DE te voir!; Literally: I have haste to see you.; Avoir hâte must be followed by DE + INFINITIVE (what you are looking forward to doing). You cannot say: J'ai hâte de qqch. There must be a verb.

question: I can't wait to hear what is next.
answer: J'ai hâte (or je suis impatiente) D'entendre la suite.; Avoir hâte must be followed by DE + INFINITIVE (what you are looking forward to doing). You cannot say: J'ai hâte de qqch. There must be a verb.

question: We can't wait to do it.
answer: On a hâte D'en faire.; In this case you need both the preposition DE and the pronom EN.

question: I'm looking forward to seeing them.
answer: J'ai hâte DE LES revoir.; Them is a COD so use les.; Use REVOIR because the implication is that is has been a while since you saw them last.

question: I am looking forward to the activities.
answer: On a hâte DE faire les activités.; Avoir hâte must be followed by DE + INFINITIVE (what you are looking forward to doing). You cannot say: J'ai hâte de qqch. There must be a verb.

question: She is looking forward to be done with the exam.
answer: Elle a hâte d'en avoir fini avec l'examen.; EN is required to represent the direct object which is implicit because of the way we have to use a prepositional phrase to talk about the exam.; Avoir hâte must be followed by DE + INFINITIVE (what you are looking forward to doing). You cannot say: J'ai hâte de qqch. There must be a verb.

question: I look forward to returning to Paris.
answer: J'ai hâte de rentrer à Paris.; In this case use RENTRER instead of RETOURNER or REVENIR.

question: I'm really looking forward to going there.
answer: J'ai vraiment hâte D'Y (de + y) aller.; The pronoun Y replaces the place because if you didn't use a pronoun it would be something like: J'ai vraiment hâte d'aller À Nantes.

question: I am looking forward to having some (e.g. children)
answer: J'ai hâte D'EN (de + en) avoir.; The pronoun EN replaces children or whatever it is that you want SOME of (some quantity of something).; The pronoun EN replaces children or whatever it is that you want SOME of (some quantity of something) because if you did not use a pronoun then it would be something like: J'ai hâte d'avoir DES enfants.

question: I am really not looking forward to having any (e.g. children)
answer: Je n'ai vraiment pas hâte D'EN (de + en) avoir.; The pronoun EN replaces children or whatever it is that you want SOME of (some quantity of something) because if you did not use a pronoun then it would be something like: Je n'ai vraiment pas hâte d'avoir DES enfants.

question: I did not put pressure on myself in case I fail the exam.
answer: Je ne me suis pas mis de pression au cas où je raterai l'examen.; Use SE METTRE to express this. The reflexive verb forces the use of être in passé composé.

question: idiomatic way to say: No pressure!
answer: Rien ne presse.

question: idiomatic way to say: Go ahead. (when you are talking with a friend and you both speak at the same time and you want the other person to go ahead)
answer: Vas-y. ('vah-zee'); Vas-y is a really common phrase to use with friends.; The formal version: Allez-y ('ah-lay-zee') is used when you want a stranger to go ahead of you through a door.

question: idiomatic way to say: Take your time. / No rush.
answer: Same in french. Formal: Prenez votre temps. Informal: Prends ton temps.

question: idiomatic way to say: Take it easy.
answer: Vas-y tranquille.

question: idiomatic way to say: Stay in touch.
answer: On reste en contact.; Literally: We stay in contact.; RESTER + EN = to stay in (something)

question: idiomatic way to say: We will keep eachother posted.
answer: On se tient au courant.; SE TENIR au courant = to keep abreast of some topic; tenir = to hold

question: Come any time after 7:30pm. (when inviting people to a party)
answer: Viens/Venez à partir de 19h30.; à partir de = starting at; In this case do not translate 'anytime' directly.

question: How do you say ___ in french? + How do you pronounce ___?
answer: Comment on dit ___ en français? ('co-mun-dee') + Comment ça se prononce?

question: How do you write ___? + How do you spell ___?
answer: Comment ça s'écrit ___? (comm-on-sa-say-cree) + Comment ça s'épèle?; NB: These use the reflexive forms of the verbs because what you are saying is how the word writes/spells itself.

question: Is it possible to say...?
answer: Est-il possible DE DIRE...?

question: I will try to spell it. + ...to write it. + ...to pronounce it.
answer: Je vais essayer DE l'épeler. + ...DE l'écrire. + ...DE le prononcer.; Essayer triggers the preposition DE before the verb that is the object. le/l' is the pronoun that represents 'it' - the thing you want to spell etc.

question: They are spelled the same.
answer: Ils ont la même forme. OR Ils s'écrivent de la même manière.

question: What does it mean?
answer: Qu'est-ce que ça veut dire? (kes-kuh-sa-voo-deer); Alternatively - in very casual situations - you could repeat the word in questions and then add: C'est quoi? (literally: It is what?); Alternative: C'est à dire? = literally: That is to say?

question: It means...
answer: There are many ways to express this: 1) Ça veut dire... = It wants to say... 2) C'est à dire... = That is to say... 3) Ça signifie... = It signifies... 4) Il s'agit... = It means...; The first one is far away the most common way to express this in french.

question: ...a word that means
answer: un mot qui veut dire; literally: a word that wants to say

question: I meant to say... + What I mean...
answer: Je voulais dire... + Ce que je veux dire...; For the first one: Use VOULOIR imparfait to talk about meaning in the past.

question: the meaning + I do not remember the meaning.
answer: la signification + Je ne me souviens pas DE la signification.; SOUVENIR is a verb that triggers DE before its object.

question: What is it for?
answer: Il sert à quoi? = It serves what? (What purpose does it serve?)

question: Can you repeat slowly? / Repeat slowly please.
answer: Est-ce que vous pouvez (or tu peux) répéter lentement? / Répétez (or Répétes) lentement s'il vous (or te) plaît.

question: one more time
answer: encore une fois; NB: When speaking you can use 'ré écouter' to ask to hear something again but this is never written.

question: again
answer: de nouveau

question: What did you say?
answer: Qu'est-ce que vous avez dit? OR Qu'est-ce que vous racontez? (What were you saying?)

question: That makes sense.
answer: C'est logique. OR Ça a du sens ('sohnS'; final S is pronounced).; e.g. Ça a du sens pour toi? = Does it make sense to you?; NB: Ça + a is pronounced as two vowels but very quickly together. It almost (but not quite) sounds like one vowel.

question: It's useful.
answer: C'est utile.; Be careful. This is ok to use for a thing (e.g. a tool is useful). But if you use it for a person (e.g. The politician is useful) then the connotation is that you are using that person to your advantage. It is NOT a compliment when used with a person.

question: It's practical.
answer: C'est pratique. ('pra-teek'); NB: When you use C'est + some adjective you always use the masculine form of the adjective regardless of the gender of the thing you are referring to. So if you don't know the gender of a noun and you want to describe it then you can cheat a bit by saying: C'est + masculine form of the adjective.

question: It's helpful.
answer: There is no idiomatic way to say this in french with an adjective for a person or even for a thing. Instead you have to say: It helps me. e.g. Ça m'aide. = It helps me.; Il m'aide beaucoup. = He helps me a lot.

question: It's pointless. / It's useless.
answer: Ça ne sert à rien.; The verb is SERVIR (to serve) which is conjugated as 'sert' in 3rd person singular.; This is a very idiomatic phrase.

question: It's certain. + It's not certain.
answer: C'est certain. + Ce n'est pas certain.; Alternative: sûr (sure) is a similar adjective.

question: We are sure. + It's secure.
answer: On est sûr(e). + C'est sûr(e).; Use sûr(e) for both cases.; NB: certain(e) is a synonym for sûr.

question: We wanted to make sure that we would keep the apartment.
answer: On voulait ÊTRE SUR DE garder l'appartement.; Alternative: S'ASSURER = to make sure; DE is required between two infinitive verbs.

question: I wanted to be a doctor.
answer: Je voulais être médecin.

question: I think..
answer: je pense...

question: Do you think the same?
answer: Penses-tu la même chose? / Est-ce que tu penses la même chose?; Alternative: Est-ce que tu LE penses aussi?

question: ok / alright (when in agreement) +  ok? / do you agree?
answer: d'accord + d'accord? ('duh-kohr')

question: I agree with her.
answer: Je suis d'accord avec elle.; ÊTRE D'ACCORD is how you express 'to agree'.; en accord = in agreement

question: How are you? (informal)
answer: Comment vas tu? / Comment ça va?

question: How are you doing? (formal)
answer: Comment allez vous?

question: What's the difference between 'Comment allez vous?' and 'Vous allez bien?'?
answer: They mean the same thing but the former uses the interrogative form (so no upward intonation required - it's obviously a question); the latter uses the affirmative form (just a statement) so you must say with upward intonation to make it sound like a question.; The latter (reversal of subject verb) is more polite.; Remember that the N at the end of bien is always silent.

question: How was your day?
answer: Comment ta journée s'est passé(e)?

question: What's wrong? + What happened?
answer: Qu'est-ce qui ne va pas? + Qu'est qui c'est passé?; NB: ce qui is pronounced "ski" in conversation.

question: It's ok / it's going alright
answer: ça va! + ca va? (sa-va)...it is used as both question (is it going ok?) and response (it's going ok); the literal translation is "it goes" and it is conjugated in that way e.g. il/elle/on va

question: so-so/ok + kind of (meaning a little bit)
answer: comme ci comme ça + en quelque sorte; En quelque sorte can only be used in this sense. It cannot be used to say: a kind of music.; Alternative expressions that are neutral (not positive or negative): ça va + pas trop mal

question: and you? (informal + formal)
answer: et toi? + et vous?

question: I hope you are doing well (for emails/texts)
answer: J'espère que tu vas bien.; Alternative: se porter bien = to be doing well

question: How do you close a casual email?
answer: Progressively more casual: À plus tard OR À plus OR À + (with the actual plus symbol)

question: How do you close a semi-formal letter?
answer: Chaleureusement ('warmly' for more casual correspondence) + Amicalement + Cdlt + SVP + STP; Alternative: Cordialement always works.

question: How do you close a formal letter?
answer: Cordialement + Sincères salutations (only for business correspondence; super polite; similar to 'best regards') + Veuillez recevoir` Madame` Monsieur` mes salutations distinguées.

question: For a formal letter: How do you express that you look forward to hearing a response?
answer: En vous remerciant par avance pour votre réponse; More formally: En vous remerciant par avance pour votre réponse` je vous prie Madame` Monsieur` d’agréer l’expression de mes sincères salutations. (Replace 'je vous prie' with 'nous vous prions' if writing on behalf of a company or couple.)

question: For a formal letter: How do you start the letter?
answer: En tant qu'habitante de votre commune je vous écris pour vous faire part d'une situation qui mérite votre attention.

question: For a formal letter: Please (do something).
answer: Je vous prie de bien + INFINITIVE. e.g. Je vous prie remplacer les produits défectueux. = Please replace the defective products.

question: For a formal letter: I ask that you...
answer: Je vous demande de (bien vouloir) + INFINITIVE.; Adding 'bien vouloir' makes it even more polite - more like 'i ask that you are willing to...'; e.g. Je vous demande de (bien vouloir) me rembourser. = I ask (kindly) that you reimburse me.; e.g. Je vous demande de en conséquence de payer. = I ask that you pay accordingly / therefore.

question: For a formal letter: I would appreciate it if you...
answer: Je vous saurai gré de + INFINITIVE.; e.g. Je vous saurai gré de annuler la commande. = I would appreciate it if you would cancel the order.

question: For a formal letter: I'm sorry for the inconvenience.
answer: Je regrette cet inconvénient.

question: For a formal letter: Please accept...
answer: Veuillez agréer... OR Je vous prie d'agréer...; e.g. Je vous prie d'agréer l'expression de mes sentiments les meilleurs. = Please accept the expression of my best feelings.

question: For a formal letter: Please accept my apologies.
answer: Je vous prie de bien accepter mes excuses.; Alternative: Nous vous prions de bien accepter nos excuses. = Please accept our apologies.; les excuses = best translation for the apologies

question: to endure a situation
answer: subir une situation

question: a family name / a first name
answer: un nom / un prénom

question: My name is x.
answer: Je m'appelle x. OR...informally: Moi c'est x.

question: But my friends call me x.
answer: Mais mes amis m'appellent x.; Or is a formal way to say 'but' in writing.

question: a nickname
answer: un surnom; Take care because this is a 'faux ami'. It does not mean surname (British English for last name).

question: What is your name? (informal)
answer: Comment tu t'appelles? / Quel est ton nom?; nom is masculine so QUEL and ton must agree with it

question: What is your name? (formal)
answer: Comment vous vous appelez? / Quel est votre/ton nom?; nom is masculine so QUEL and VOTRE must agree with it

question: I am x years old (this year).
answer: J'ai x ans (cette année).; The number + ans is spoken very quickly; it's also fully linked together (e.g. 44 ans = 'catr-von-ca-TRON' where the end of the number has a liaison with ans); ans is a very quick nasal sound 'on' on the end; 'This year' is a duration so use année. Ans is used for counting (e.g. years old).

question: How do you pronounce when saying you or someone's age?
answer: there is always a linking between number and 'ans'; 'ans' is pronounced 'oh' super nasal

question: How old are you (informal)?
answer: Quel âge a tu?; Use QUEL because âge is masculine and singular here.

question: What are their ages?
answer: Quels sont leurs âges?; Use QUELS because âge is masculine and we are using the plural here.

question: I am X meters tall.
answer: Je mesure ('meh-zoor') 1`8 mètres.; MESURER triggers avec.

question: I am a software engineer.
answer: Many options: 1) Je suis injénieure logicieles/software. 2) Je suis développeure/développeuse. 3) ingénieure informatique = engineer of computer science ("IT"); programeur/programmeuse is an outdated term.

question: What is the formal name for a software engineer - if you write it?
answer: Ingénieur en développement logiciel or Ingénieur en génie logiciel

question: I have a health issue. + I have a serious medical condition.
answer: J'ai des problèmes de santé. + J'ai une condition médicale très sérieuse/grave.

question: I am healthy + I am sick.
answer: Je suis en bonne santé. + Je suis malade.; Use 'en bonne santé' to describe the health of a person.; Generally: sain is used for objects. santé is used for people.

question: not healthy / not good for your health (like for food)
answer: pas sain; Do not use this to say that a person is not in good health.

question: I eat healthily.
answer: Je mange sainement. OR Je suis un régime sain. (= I follow a healty diet.); The second phrase is probably more idiomatic.; sainement is an adverb that describes an activity (verb) that is good for a person's health (santé).; Generally: sain is used for objects. santé is used for people.

question: less calories (e.g. for a diet)
answer: un faible nombre de calories

question: organic
answer: organique OR bio; Bio is more commonly used (than organique) to describe healthy/natural food.; When speaking in terms of science and chemistry... organique and biologique have the same meanings as in english.

question: What do you say when someone sneezes?
answer: á tes souhaits (a-te-sway) ...familiar / á vos souhaits ...formal

question: I must be careful. (e.g. to avoid catching virus) + I pay attention to the stairs.
answer: Je dois faire attention. + Je fais attention aux escaliers.; faire attention + À + noun

question: No problem.
answer: pas DE problème OR (Il n'y a) pas de soucis (no worries; 'soo-see'); Use DE because PAS is a quantity.

question: Don't worry. / No worries.
answer: T'inquiète (pas). OR Ne vous inquiétez (pas).; inquiéter = to worry; This is a common saying so often the 'ne' and 'pas' are dropped/implied.

question: to stay + to take away (when ordering at a café) + to pick up
answer: sur place + emporter + pour récupérer (literally: to recover); EMPORTER means 'to take out' and can apply to many things.

question: Hold on (when putting someone on hold)
answer: Ne quittez pa ('nuh-key-tay-pa'); literally you (formal) do not leave; the verb is quitter

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Je suis desolé(e).; Add the extra E if you are a woman because it is an adjective that modifies JE.

question: I was wrong.
answer: Je me suis trompé(e)/tort(e).

question: I had the wrong idea (about something).
answer: J'ai une idée faussée. OR Je n'ai pas une bonne idée de la question.; faussée is a form of faux = false

question: Well done! / Good job! (when someone succeeds at something)
answer: Bien joué! ('zhoo-ay'); loosely translated: they played it well; Alternative: Bon travaille!

question: It's magnificent. + It's marvelous.
answer: C'est manifique. (There is no G!) + C'est merveilleux. ('mare-vay-yo')

question: idiomatic ways to say: It's exciting! or I'm excited!
answer: 1) C'est enthousiasmant! = It's exciting news!; 2) Je suis content(e) pour toi. or Je suis impatient(e) pour toi.; In french you do not say that a person is excited (excitant) unless you mean aroused. 3) C'est passionnant pour moi. = It is exciting for me. e.g. Le travail est passionnant pour moi.

question: idiomatic way to say: I enjoy... e.g. I enjoy swimming.
answer: Je prends du plaisir à + INFINITIVE; e.g. Je prends du plaisir à nager.

question: Was I right/correct?
answer: Est-ce que j'avais bon?; Generally the word good (bon/bonne) is used to mean correct.; Alternatively you can use the adjective exact(e). C'est exact. = That is correct.; Do NOT use 'correct' which technically exists in french but is extremely anglo.

question: You are right/correct.
answer: Tu as raison ('ray-zon').; Avoir raison is the way to express someone being correct.; Technically you could ask: Ai-je raison? = Am I right? This is correct french but a bit formal.

question: You are reasonable. + The price is reasonable.
answer: Tu es raisonnable. + Le prix est réalisable.; Raisonnable is an adjective that describes a person. Réalisable is an adjective that describes an object.

question: the correct choice / the correct response
answer: le bon choix / la bonne réponse

question: at the same time
answer: en même temps; NB: temps is almost always plural - it always ends with S.

question: your free time
answer: ton temps libre

question: Are you available? + Is there a job opening available?
answer: As-tu disponible? + Est-ce qu'il y a un poste disponible?; You could also use libre in casual conversation: Je suis libre vendredi.

question: Can you hear me? (when on a call)
answer: Vous m'entendez? OR Tu m'entends?; Do not use pouvoir. Keep it simple.

question: I know how to prepare coffee.
answer: Je sais préparer le café; Use SAVOIR for knowing some information.

question: I do not know. (when you don't have the information)
answer: Je ne sais pas.; Pronounced 'shay-pah' in conversation. The subject pronoun JE can be shortened to the sound "sh" (in front of any verb) and the vowel is dropped completely so you lose an entire syllable.

question: I do not know. (when you're not familiar with the person/topic)
answer: Je ne connais pas.; Use CONNAÎTRE for familiarity - not for information.

question: I did not know that.
answer: Je ne LE savais pas.; Use SAVOIR because we are talking about information instead of familiarity. Use the general article LE (meaning it) to reference the information.

question: I didn't know what to do. vs I didn't know what I had to do.
answer: Je ne savais pas QUOI faire. vs Je ne savais pas CE QUE je devais faire.

question: I am aware of X.
answer: J'ai conscience DE X.; Alternative: Je suis au courant DE X.

question: I heard/understood incorrectly.
answer: J'ai mal entendu.; Use the adverb MAL and the verb ENTENDRE (to hear).

question: a misunderstanding
answer: un malentendu; This is literally 'heard incorrectly'. J'ai mal entendu. = I heard/understood incorrectly.

question: Do you understand English? (informal/formal)
answer: Comprends-tu anglais? / Comprenez-vous anglais?

question: You speak English well. + I speak french poorly.
answer: Vous parlez BIEN anglais. + Je parle MAL français.; bien = the adverb for good (well); mal = the adverb for bad (poorly)

question: I did not understand much.
answer: Je ne comprenais pas grand chose.; This is the most idiomatic way to express this... using imparfait and pas grand chose (instead of beaucoup)

question: I did not understand everything. + I understood most of the sentences.
answer: Je ne comprenais pas tout. + Je comprenais la plupart des phrases.; la plupart + DE + the thing ... because it is a quantity.; NB: In this case 'la plupart des phrases' is a plural noun - not singular.

question: I understood a lot.
answer: J'ai très BIEN compri.; Do not use beaucoup in this case.

question: I did not understand. + I did not understand well.
answer: Je n'ai pas compris. + Je n'ai pas BIEN compris.; Adverbs are placed between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé (with PAS).; NB: The subject pronoun JE can be shortened to the sound "sh" (in front of any verb) and the vowel is dropped completely so you lose an entire syllable. e.g. Je n'ai pas compris. ("shay-pah-cohm-prhee")

question: I do not understand what they say.
answer: Je ne comprends pas ce qu'ils disent.; QUE contracts with any word starting with a vowel.

question: I do not understand them. + I cannot understand them.
answer: Je ne LES comprends pas. + Je ne peux pas LES comprendre.; In the latter there are two verbs POUVOIR + COMPRENDRE. LES (them) relates to comprendre - not pouvoir. So the pronoun LES is placed before comprendre - not before pouvoir.

question: It's still difficult for me (despite...).
answer: Ça reste difficile pour moi.; Translating STILL depends on the context (e.g. the continuation of a time period vs emphasis). In this case 'ça reste' is a good choice even though we are using still for emphasis.

question: I still only understand some sentences.
answer: Je continue de ne comprendre quelques phrases.; Translating STILL depends on the context (e.g. the continuation of a time period vs emphasis).; In this case use the verb CONTINUER (to continue). Use DE to link to an additional verb. Use NE to negate the infinitive.

question: I still can't hear the difference.
answer: Je n'entends toujours pas la différence.; Translating STILL depends on the context (e.g. the continuation of a time period vs emphasis).; In this case TOUJOURS (with NE + PAS to negate) is a good choice.

question: My ears are not used to french.
answer: Mes oreilles ne s'habituent pas au français.

question: My oral comprehension is not good.
answer: Mon comprehension oral n'est pas très bonne.;  Adding pas to an adjective totally negates it and makes it negative instead of neutral / not positive. e.g. pas parfait = the opposite of perfect e.g. pas formidable is very negative instead of just neutral.

question: Did you understand the exercise?
answer: Familiar: T'as pige l'exo?; Formal: Tu as comprends l'exercise?; NB: T'as is a contraction of the subject TU and the verb AS. This contraction is really common in conversation but you should not do it in formal communication.

question: I continue to try. + I continue to do something.
answer: Je continue D'essayer. + Je continue À faire quelque chose.

question: I am getting better (at some skill). + I will get better (at some skill).
answer: Je m'améliore. + Je vais m'améliorer.; SE AMÉLIOR = to improve (oneself). We must use the verb reflexively in this case because the object (what is improving) is not explicit.; Alternative: Je deviens (DEVENIR = to become) meilleure.

question: I will improve (speaking french). + I will improve (dancing).
answer: Je vais améliorer mon français. + Je vais améliorer ma danse.; AMÉLIOR = to improve. We do not use the verb reflexively in this case because the object (dancing/speaking) is explicit.

question: to get worse
answer: empirer NB: You must use a reflexive pronoun (SE EMPIRER) if you mean that you are getting worse.; Alternative: DEVENIR pire (literally: to become worse). This is a very familiar/casual way to express this. You do not need to use a reflexive pronoun with DEVENIR because the verb assumes that the subject is also the object.

question: The crowd is worsening. (formal and informal versions)
answer: Soutenu (formal): La foule s'empire. (SE EMPIRER) + Familiére (informal):La foule devient pire.

question: It got worse.
answer: Ça s'est empiré.; SE EMPIRER in passé composé.

question: I get worse. (formal and informal versions)
answer: Soutenu (formal): Je m'empire. (SE EMPIRER) + Familiére (informal): Je deviens pire.

question: I will get it (eventually).
answer: Je compredrai.; I will understand - using futur simple. This is a good way to express this sentiment.; Remember that the subject pronoun JE can be shorted to sound like "sh" (in front of any verb) so you lose at least one syllable: Je comprends. ("shcohm-prah").

question: It takes time to understand.
answer: Ça prend du temps pour comprendre.; This is an idiomatic expression in french that is very similar to the expression in english.

question: how quickly the people speak
answer: à quel point les gens parlent vite; à quel point is an idiomatic phrase that emphasizes the frequency or volume of something - how much something (some verb) happens

question: I like X. + I really like X. + I really really like X.
answer: J'aime X. + J'aime bien X. + J'adore X.; All of these phrasings are appropriate at any level of speaking/writing (informal and formal). But generally AIMER (alone) is used for people: Je t'aime. AIMER BIEN and ADORER are used for objects including compound verbs.

question: I like to dance. + I like red wine.
answer: J'aime bien danser. + J'aime bien le vin rouge.; You do not need any preposition after aimer or adorer to join with another verb. e.g. J'adore danser.

question: I don't like rose wine. + I don't like to sing.
answer: Je n'aime pas DE vin rosé. + Je n'aime pas chanter.; Use AIMER alone with objects in negation works. In cases where the verb is not negated it is more common to use AIMER BIEN and ADORER (instead of aimer alone) with objects.

question: I don't like peanut butter.
answer: Je n'aime pas le beurre de cacahouète.

question: I don't like to have too many things in the apartment.
answer: Je N'aime PAS AVOIR trop de choses dans l'appartement.; When you are negating a verb you do not need to add DE after PAS.

question: I like cocktails a lot.
answer: J'aime BEAUCOUP les cocktails.; This is how you express that you like something a lot.; Beaucoup is modifying the verb in this case (instead of indicating a quantity of the thing that is liked). You are not saying 'I like a lot of cocktails'. So there is no DE between beaucoup and the noun (les cocktails).

question: I like a lot of cocktails.
answer: J'aime BEAUCOUP DE cocktails.; Beacoup is a quantity in this case (instead of modifying the verb aimer). You are not saying 'I like cocktails a lot.' So you must use BEAUCOUP DE.

question: My husband likes to cook a lot.
answer: Mon mari aime BEAUCOUP cuisiner.; In this case beaucoup is an adverb (modifying the verb: cuisiner). So we do not use preposition DE.

question: I like both.
answer: J’aime bien les deux.; Always use an article before a noun (deux). Use AIMER BIEN or ADORER for objects. Use AIMER (alone) for people.

question: I like it.
answer: J'aime bien. This is the best option. Omit the pronoun (for the thing that you like) completely in this case.; You could also say: J'aime ça. But that is not idiomatic french.

question: She likes her. + She likes it (la fromage).; Explain the exception in choosing the object pronoun.
answer: Elle l'aime. + Elle aime bien. OR Elle aime bien ça. (NOT Elle l'aime.) This is a special case where we sometimes omit the object pronoun completely in french. AIMER is intended to be used for people (not objects). So in the first sentence we can replace her with the pronoun LA. In the second sentence the object is an inanimate object so we use ça (or omit it completely) instead of using the COD pronom (la/le).

question: He hates her. + He hates it (la fromage).; Explain the exception in choosing the object pronoun.
answer: Il la deteste. + Il deteste ça. (NOT: Il la deteste.); This is a special case where we sometimes omit the object pronoun completely in french. DETESTER is intended to be used for people (not objects). So in the first sentence we can replace her with the pronoun LA. In the second sentence the object is an inanimate object so we use ça (or omit it completely) instead of using the COD pronom (la/le).

question: I enjoy writing.
answer: Je prends du plaisir à écrire.; The best way to express this sentiment in french is: PRENDRE + DU PLAISIR + À + the desired thing or action; This is an exception to how generally connect two verbs because it uses À instead of DE.

question: I enjoy it.
answer: J'y prends du plaisir.; Use pronom Y to represent the object because PRENDRE DU PLAISIR triggers À before the object when you are not using a pronoun.

question: I really like it when the people around me are having a good time.
answer: J'aime bien / J'adore quand les personnes autour DE moi passent un bon moment.; Use autour DE because all directional prepositions use DE (e.g. à côté DE).; Use MOI (instead of me) because there is a preposition before this pronoun.

question: I really like being surrounded by others (indicating you are a social person).
answer: J'aime bien / J'adore quand des personnes m'entourent. This uses the verb ENTOURER (to surround). Use ME pronoun (instead of MOI) because there is no preposition between ENTOURER and its object.; Less idiomatic alternative: J'adore être entouré(e) PAR des personnes. = I like being surrounded BY people.

question: I enjoyed their culture.
answer: J'ai bien aimé leur culture.; Use aimer bien to express enjoyment. If you use profiter de (e.g. Je profite de leur culture...) then you must explain exactly what benefit you receive from experiencing the culture.

question: I like to be immersed in a new culture.
answer: J'aime bien m'immerger dans une nouvelle culture.; Use the verb SE IMMERGER (to immerse oneself).; 'dans une culture' would be a bit vague. It is better to specify what culture you are talking about in this case.

question: I really like being surrounded by the parisian culture.
answer: J'aime bien / J'adore être entouré(e) PAR DE la culture parisienne.; NB: Using 'de la culture' (instead of just 'de culture') leaves the expression a bit open in a good way. There is a sense that you might enjoy other cultures too. For example if you said: J'adore être entouré(e) PAR la culture parisienne. (without de) ...This connotes that your enjoyment is limited (or more targeted) to this specific culture - not extended to others.

question: I know of him. + I know of it (le gorgonzola).; Explain the exception in choosing the object pronoun.
answer: Je LE connais. + Je connais. (NOT Je le connais.); This is a special case where we sometimes omit an object pronoun completely in french. CONNAÎTRE is intended to be used for people (not objects). So in the first sentence we can replace him with the pronoun LE. In the second sentence the object is an inanimate object so we use ça (or omit it completely) instead of using the COD pronom (la/le).

question: Do you like X? (formal and informal)
answer: Aimez-vous X ? / Aimes-tu X ?

question: a formal way to ask: Do you like it? (used by venders when presenting an item).
answer: Ça vous plaît ?

question: The bedroom pleases me. (a common way to express pleasure in french)
answer: La chambre me plaît. PLAIRE is the verb. Add the reflexive pronoun (me) when the person being pleased is implied.; PLAIRE is irregular: je plais + tu plais + il plaît + nous plaisons + vous plaisez + ils plaisent

question: I please my boss.
answer: Je plais À mon chef.;PLAIRE is the verb. It is irregular. Use À when the person being pleased is explicit.

question: Who is your (formal) favorite actor / actress (masculine)?
answer: Quel est votre acteur préféré / actrice préféréE ?

question: Who is your (informal) favorite singer (masculine)?
answer: Quel est TON chanteur préféré / TA chanteuse préféréE ?

question: Who is your (formal) favorite band?
answer: Quel est votre groupe préféré ?; le groupe is masculine

question: Do you have a a preferred neighborhood?
answer: Avez-vous un préference de quartier?

question: You adore the band The Donnas.
answer: Tu adores le groupe The Donnas.; use the article and noun - no preposition

question: I adore clothes.
answer: J'adore vêtements.

question: I appreciate jazz and rock.
answer: J'apprécie le jazz et le rock.; verb: apprécier

question: How do you express 'I appreciate you'?
answer: Do not translate directly. Just say: J'apprécie. (without an object pronoun)

question: I appreciate your point of view.
answer: J'apprécie ton/votre point de vue.

question: I appreciate the meal.
answer: Le repas est trés apprecié.; In this case you must explicitly express the object (the meal). So you cannot use the verb apprécier. Instead use the adjective (apprecié) to describe the meal.

question: I'm a fan of Wu-Tang.
answer: Je suis fan de Wutang.; use DE preposition before the object

question: I am passionate about hiphop/punk.
answer: Je suis passionné de musique hip hop / de musique punk.; use DE preposition before the object

question: idiomatic way to say: His passion is jazz.
answer: Le jazz le passionne.

question: My musical tastes are quite broad.
answer: Mes goûts musicaux sont plutôt larges.

question: What kind of music do you listen to to relax?
answer: Quel genre de musique écoutes tu pour te détendre?

question: I am a costume-lover.
answer: Je suis amatrice de costumes.; use DE preposition before the object; un costume = a man's suit or a costume (depends on context)

question: I am crazy about...
answer: Je suis fou/folle (m/f) DE danse.; Use DE before the object.

question: leisure/hobbies
answer: les loisirs

question: interests + an interest
answer: les goûts ('goo') is idiomatic french for interests + un intérêt is commonly used to me an interest - like a hobby; NB: If you pronounce the T it is a different word: une goutte (a drop e.g of rain)

question: an area of interest
answer: un centre d'interêt

question: my interest in art
answer: mon intérêt POUR l'art

question: I'm interested in modern art and sculpture.
answer: Je m'intéresse À l'art moderne et à la sculpture ('skool-toor'; do NOT pronounce the P.).; This uses the verb intéresser reflexively. Use à before the object.

question: It interests no one. (a way to say that something is boring)
answer: Ça n'intéresse personne.

question: What makes you feel good?
answer: Qu'est-ce qui fait que tu te sens bien?; Use QUI instead of que because there is no explicit subject.

question: What is it that interests you?
answer: Qu'est-ce qui t'intéresses?; Use QUI instead of que because there is no explicit subject.

question: What is it that interests you about X?
answer: Qu'est-ce qui t'intéresses DANS X?; NB: ce qui is pronounced "ski" in conversation.

question: Travelling is one of my hobbies.
answer: Voyager fait partie de mes loisirs.

question: interested
answer: intéressé(e); This is a common pattern with adjectives. Elle est intéressée. = She is interested. Elle est intéressant. = She is interesting.

question: interesting
answer: intéressant; This is a common pattern with adjectives. Elle est intéressée. = She is interested. Elle est intéressant. = She is interesting.

question: It is interesting that...
answer: C'est intéressant que... ; This triggers the subjonctif tense for the phrase that follows because it is expressing an opinion.

question: He is allergic to shellfish + walnuts + hazelnuts.
answer: Il est allergique (with soft g) AUX crustacés ('cru-sta-sets') + noix ('nua') + noisettes ('nu-ah-zet').

question: What is the difference between these words and how are they pronounced differently: noix + noir
answer: noix = walnut ('nwa' because the X is silent) + noir = black ('nwar' because the R is not silent)

question: Go ahead. (when you are opening the door for someone or letting them go ahead of you)
answer: Vas y. (informal; pronounced 'vah-zee') + Allez y madame/monsieur. (formal; pronounced 'ah-lay-zee')

question: How was it? (informal)
answer: Ça a été? (sa-EH-tay) ...really common and shortened; There is an implied 'bien' in the phrase. The full formal version might be "(Est-ce que) ça a (bien) été ?"

question: It's nice.
answer: C'est sympa.; This comes from the word sypathique which means friendly/pleasant/nice - not sympathetic.
