question: It's great. Give at least 3 options.
answer: C'est génial. C'est super. C'est formidable. Incroyable! C'est magnifique. C'est fabuleux. C'est extraordinaire. C'est top (like the English word).; NB: pas top = not very good

question: It's perfect. + It's cool.
answer: C'est parfait. + C'est chouette ('shweht').; Chouette (same m/f) means brilliant or cool but in a kind way.; You could also say: C'est cool. ...but this is very anglais.; NB: la chouette = owl.

question: It tastes great.
answer: C'est délicieux. ('day-lee-sow')

question: It was good.
answer: C'etait bien.; literally: It went well. This is idiomatic french.; Bien is an adverb (well) that describes a verb. So we do not use bon/bonne/bons/bonnes (the adjective for good) in this case.

question: It was a good day.
answer: C'etait une bonne journée.; We use the feminine journée because we are referring to the things that happened during the day (duration). Do NOT say: C'etait un bon jour. That would imply that there is something special about the day regardless of what happened - like a lucky date.

question: It was a good weekend.
answer: C'était un bon week-end (masculine).; Use bon/bonne/bons/bonnes because good is an adjective that modifies the noun. We do not use bien (well) which would need to modify a verb.

question: It will be X. + It would be X.
answer: Ça sera X. (futur simple) + Ça serait X. (conditionnel)

question: It's not bad.
answer: C'est pas mal.; Take care because 'pas mal' can also mean: quite a lot.

question: It's bad.
answer: C'est mauvais. ('say-mow-vay')

question: blah (when you have a negative reaction to something)
answer: bof

question: It's horrible.
answer: C'est horrible. ('se-toe-reebl') OR Quelle horreur!

question: It sucks./Its rubbish.
answer: C'est nul(le).; nul(le) = zero as an adjective

question: I am disappointed.
answer: Je suis déçu.

question: What a disappointment!
answer: Quelle déception!; the disappointment = la déception

question: a deception
answer: une tromperie; NB: déception = disappointment (faux ami)

question: idiomatic way to express: I'm fed up. / Enough is enough.
answer: J'en ai assez.; literally: I have enough of it.

question: idiomatic way to express: I can't get enough (of something).
answer: Je n'en sais jamais assez.; Literally: I can't know enough about it.

question: What is an alternative way to express 'not interesting' (that avoids ennuyant and ennuyeux)?
answer: C'est monotone.

question: the boredom
answer: l'ennui

question: It's boring.
answer: C'est ennuyant(e) ('uh-nee-yohn(t)') OR ennuyeux ('uh-nee-yow') / ennuyeuse ('uh-nee-yooz'). Both words mean boring (not annoying).; ENNUYANT(E) is a newer and more commonly-used word than ENNUYEUX/EUSE. And there are some cases where ennuyeux/euse sounds bizarre. So defer to ennuyant(e).; Alternative definitions: ENNUYANT(E) describes something that is temporarily boring/annoying. ENNUYEUX/EUSE describes something that is actively or persistently boring/annoying.

question: Two idiomatic ways to express: It was boring.
answer: 1) neutral: Ça m'a laissé froid. (literally: It left me cold.) 2) very harsh/dismissive: Je me suis fait chier. (literally: I shat myself ...because it was so boring.)

question: She is bored.
answer: Elle s'ennuie.; Use the reflexive form SE ENNUYER ('uhn-noowee-yay'). The middle syllable has two vowel sounds but they are squished together and pronounced rapidly almost as a single syllable.

question: When I am bored I read.
answer: Quand je m'ennuie je lire.

question: What do you do when you are bored?
answer: Qu'est-ce que tu fais quand tu t'ennuies?; Use S'ENNUYER.

question: The best way to express: It's annoying.
answer: C'est chiant(e).; This is slightly informal. It connotes that the thing pisses you off / is shitty. It is appropriate for most situations - formal and informal. But if you are in a very formal situation then choose a different expression.

question: She is annoying (like rubbing you the wrong way).
answer: Elle est désagréable.; Use this when the person is speading a bad energy.

question: He is annoying (like a pain in the ass).
answer: Il est pénible.

question: She is making me (physically) uncomfortable.
answer: Elle me met mal à l'aise.

question: to bother / to annoy
answer: Three verbs: 1) DÉRANGER (to bother/mess up; the opposite of RANGER = to put things back in order) 2) ÉNERVER = to annoy 3) GÊNER (to bother/hinder/trouble). Gêner connotes a physical sensation but it can be used figuratively.

question: It bothers me. + It doesn't bother me./I don't mind.
answer: Ça me dérange. + Ça ne me dérange pas.; Use DÉRANGER reflexively to express this.; NB: Ça m'embète. = It's annoying / not cool / bothering me. (more colloquial)

question: It bores me. + It doesn't bore me.
answer: Ça m'ennuie. + Ça ne m'ennuie pas.; ENNUYER is commonly used to describe something that bothers/annoys - even though the translation is closer to 'to bore'.

question: It worries me. + It doesn't worry me.
answer: Ça m'inquiète. + Ça ne m'inquiète pas.

question: The boss doesn't care. / It doesn't bother the manager.
answer: Ça ne dérange pas le patron.; DÉRANGER = to bother

question: The sound annoys me.
answer: Le son me gêne.; Use GÊNER (to hinder) reflexively to express this.

question: the annoyance + the embarrassment
answer: l'énervement (masculine) + la gêne (from GÊNER = to hinder); Watch out because énervé(e) means angry - not annoyed.

question: embarrassed + embarrassing
answer: embarrassé(e) + embarrassant; This is a common pattern with adjectives. Il est embarrassé. = He is embarrassed. Il est embarrassant. = He is embarrassing.

question: to annoy + to be annoyed
answer: énerver + s'énerver; This can only be used to describe the person affected - not the cause of the annoyance. For example énervé(e) means angry - not annoyed. The best way to express that something is annoying: C'est chiant(e).

question: the anger + angry
answer: la colère + colèrique/en colère OR énervé(e); Watch out because ÉNERVER means 'to annoy'. It does not mean 'to anger'.

question: to harass + the harassement
answer: harceler + le harcèlement; an harasser = un(e) harceleur / harceleuse

question: to be very bothered (to the point of 'losing it')
answer: décomposé(e); This is a step further than dérangé(e)

question: to have fun
answer: se amuser

question: I have fun watching movies. / It makes me happy to watch movies.
answer: Je m'amuse quand je regarde des films.; Use the reflexive form SE AMUSER to express this.

question: What do you do for fun?
answer: Qu'est-ce que tu fais pour t'amuser? OR Qu'est-ce que tu fais pour le plaisir?;Use S'AMUSER.

question: It tastes good. + It's delicious. + It's appetizing.
answer: C'est bon/bonne. + C'est délicieux/délicieuse. + C'est appétissant(e).

question: It's very tasty/flavorful.
answer: C'est très gouteux.

question: the flavor
answer: la saveur (the specific type of flavor; e.g. strawberry ice cream) OR le goût ('tastiness' in general)

question: We ate well.
answer: Nous avons (très) bien mangé.; Bien is the adverb that modifies the verb manger. Generally the adverb is placed before the verb it modifies. Because bien is an adverb it does not adapt to agree (in number or gender) to the verb it describes - unlike adjectives.

question: I am hungry.
answer: J'ai faim ('fah'; Same pronunciaion as fin. The M is silent.).; la faim = the hunger; It's really important to not pronounce the M in faim. Otherwise it sounds like femme.

question: You are thirsty.
answer: Tu as soif. ('swaf'); NB: This kind of statement is commonly pronounced: T'as soif/peur/etc. In spoken french people often contract the subject TU and the verb AS. But you should not do that in formal communication.

question: to be right / They are right.
answer: avoir raison / Ils ont raison.

question: to be wrong / We are wrong.
answer: avoir tort / Nous avons tort.

question: to make mistakes
answer: faire des fautes

question: a mistake + a typo / an error
answer: une faute + une erreur

question: A familiar term used to describe something wrong with a computerized device.
answer: un bug; This is a familiar term that means something like 'on the fritz' - when sometimes it works and sometimes it does not. This term in French is not used in the same way that 'bug' is used in English for software development.

question: idiomatic way to say: It's my fault.
answer: C'est ma faute.

question: hopefully...
answer: aven un peu de chance

question: The chances are good that...
answer: Il y a de bonne chance que...; Do not try to say something like: Mes chances sont éléves. That is not idiomatic french.

question: to take a chance + I will take my chance at skiing.
answer: tenter ma/ta/sa chance + Je tenterai ma chance POUR faire du ski.; TENTER means something like try/test.

question: Good luck!
answer: Two options: 1) Bon Courage! is generally used to encourage someone when the activity is physical and they have some control over the situation. 2) Bonne chance! is used more for intellectual activities and when the outcome is generally dependent on luck.

question: to have good luck + She has good luck.
answer: avoir DE LA chance + Elle a DE LA chance.

question: You have a lot of luck. (two ways)
answer: Tu as beaucoup DE chance. + Tu as bien DE LA chance.; In the first case you saying the person literally has (AVOIR) a quantity of something (beacoup DE chance). In the second phrase you are using the verb 'avoir DE LA chance' (to have luck) and simply adding BIEN to modify the verb.

question: lucky (m/f)
answer: chanceux / chanceuse

question: by chance / randomly
answer: au hasard ('oh-ehs-ah'; almost like O.S.A. but the A at the end is soft)

question: a random choice
answer: un choix aléatoire; NB: aléatoire can only be used to connote mathematical randomness. For example you cannot say des choses aléatoire to mean 'some things'.

question: idiomatic way to express random stuff that doesn't really matter
answer: tout et n'importe quoi

question: Why?
answer: Pourquoi? ('poor-kwa')

question: What is the difference between Pour quoi? and Pourquoi?
answer: Pour quoi? translates to What for? - respond with POUR + INFINITIVE = in order to X.; Pourquoi? translates to Why? - responde with PARCE QUE + SUBJECT + VERB.

question: because
answer: parce que ('par-se-kuh') OR car (shortened version) OR puisque (when the reason more like an obvious justification); Use parce que (instead of à cause de or grâce à) for most scenarios and especially when you follow with a phrase. e.g. Because I went to the store... = Parce que je suis allé(e) au magasin...; NB: car is short for parce que and can be used when speaking and writing.; NB: Comme can be used to mean 'because'. e.g. Comme il fait beau... = Because the weather is nice...

question: Because of X...
answer: Use one of two expressions depending on the context. 1) À cause de + noun: used when the consequence is negative. 2) Grâce à + noun: (literally 'thanks to...') used when the consequence is positive.; NB: Use à cause DES + plural noun. Use grâce AUX + plural noun.

question: with negative connotation: Because of technology... + Because of cars...
answer: À cause DE LA technologie... + À cause DES voitures...; Use DE for singular nouns and DES for plural nouns.

question: with positive connotation: Thanks to technology... + Thanks to donations...
answer: Grâce À LA technologie... + Grâce AUX dons....; Use À for singular nouns. Use AUX for plural nouns.

question: due to...
answer: due à...; e.g. La perte est DUE À la maladie. = The loss is due to disease.; Alternative: C'est dû à quoi? = What is this due to?

question: idiomatic way to say: That's why...
answer: C'est pour ça...; e.g. That's why I was late. = C'est pour ça j'étais en retard.

question: for example
answer: par exemple ('par-ex-ompl'); This is abbreviated as ex: (not e.g.).

question: a written example
answer: un exemple écrit / un modèle écrit; Exemple is also the correct word when you describe a sample problem.

question: also + in addition to...
answer: aussi ('oh-si') + en plus...; Alternative: additionnellement... = additionally...

question: idiomatic way to express: last but not least...
answer: enfin et surtout...

question: like this
answer: comme ça

question: How do you ask: Is it X?
answer: Est-ce X? ('ehsss'); Remember that Est-ce (Is it?) is the inverse of C'est (It is.) So... It is difficult. = C'est dificil. Is it difficult? = Est-ce dificil?.; You construct the simple question by replacing C'est with Est-ce.

question: How do you ask: Was it X?
answer: Est-ce que c'était X?; It is possible to ask this with simple inversion: Était-ce X? (akin to Est-ce X? au présent) but this is very bizarre in French. Do not use it. If you need to ask the question with the past tense (Was it x?) then use the common form with Est-ce que + the affirmative form of what you want to ask.

question: How do you ask: Is that X?
answer: Est-ce que c'est X?; Literally: Is it that it is X?; e.g. Is that bizarre? = Est-ce que c'est bizarre?

question: What is this and how do you pronounce it?: Est-ce que...?
answer: This is a super common and informal way to begin a yes/no question.; The whole thing is pronounced 'ehssss-kuh' - the s sound is long at the beginning.; Est-ce que... indicates the beginning of a yes/no question - it is not asking 'how' or 'what'.; A potential translation of est-ce que: Is it that which...?; NB: The subject and verb NEVER reverse if you use Est-ce to ask the question (Est-ce + subject + verb); If you want to speak more formal french then use the reversal of subject and verb (plus upward intonation) to pose a question (instead of using Est-ce que...?).

question: How do you ask: What is ...?
answer: Generally: Qu'est-ce que ...? ('kes-kuh'); This is always followed by subject + verb. Do not invert the order when forming the question.; NB: Do not always use QUE to translation 'what'. In french it matters whether you are asking for a subject that is doing the action (use QUE) or a direct object with a preposition (use QUOI).

question: What is this and how do you pronounce it?: Qu'est-ce que...?
answer: The whole thing is pronounced 'kes-kuh'. It is a contraction of QUE + EST-CE QUE.; This is generally how you ask: What is...? The response is NOT yes/no. You are asking for a noun.; NB: In french it matters whether you are asking for a subject (QUE) or a direct object (QUOI).

question: What happened?
answer: Qu'est-ce qui s'est passé?; NB: ce qui is pronounced "ski" in conversation.

question: What did I say?
answer: Qu'est-ce que j'ai dit?

question: What are we eating? We are eating X.
answer: Qu'est-ce qu'on mange. On mange DU X.; NB: 'Que' and 'on' merge together using apostrophe ('kohn'). And always use DU when prefacing something being eaten.

question: What do you study? (formal and informal)
answer: Qu'est-ce que vous étudiez / tu étudie?; tu étudie is pronounced 'too-uh-tood' ...present singular verb forms are usually short with downward intonation

question: What are you doing this evening? (formal and informal)
answer: Qu'est-ce que vous faites / tu fais su soir?

question: What's up?
answer: Quoi de neuf?; Literally: Of what is new? Neuf means 'new' in some circumstances.; Use DE QUOI (instead of QUE) because the 'what' is the direct object and requires a preposition. 'You' is the subject. 'What' is the object.

question: What is it like? (when you are asking someone to describe a location etc.)
answer: De quoi ça a l'air?; Use DE QUOI in this case.

question: What do you need?
answer: De quoi as tu besoin?; Use DE QUOI (instead of QUE) because the 'what' is the direct object and requires a preposition.

question: What else?
answer: Quoi d'autres? ('qwa-doh-truh'); Use DE QUOI (instead of QUE) in this case.

question: How do you ask: Which is ...?
answer: Quel est...? ('kel-ay-...') but it adapts to the gender and number of what you are asking about so there are four possbilities: Quel? (masc sing) Quelle? (fem sing) Quels? (masc plural) Quelles? (fem plural); All four forms are pronounced exactly the same: 'kel'.

question: What is your (informal) profession?
answer: Quelle est ton profession?; Use QUELLE because profession is feminine and singular.

question: What kind/type is it? (e.g. type of car or dance or music)
answer: Quel genre est-il? ('kel-jon-ray-til'); Use QUEL because genre is masculine and singular.

question: What type of jackets do you have?
answer: Quel genre de veste avez-vous? OR Vous avez quel genre de veste?; If you use Quel then you have to invert the subject verb; OR you can make a statement (subject + verb) and use intonation to make it a question

question: What color is the dress?
answer: DE quelle couleur est la robe?; Use DE QUEL instead of QUEL because we use a preposition in english: What is the color OF the dress? The presence of the preposition in english indicates that we need to use DE QUEL... in French.

question: What colors are you (formal) wearing?
answer: DE quelles couleurs vous portez?; Use QUELLES because couleures is plural and feminine.; couleur is pronounced 'kool-oor' like heurre

question: Who is ...? / Who is it?
answer: Qui est ...? ('kee-ah-...')/ Qu'est-ce? ('kes'); It doesn't matter whether the 'who' is the subject or direct object of the verb. Always use QUI.

question: Whose is ...?
answer: À qui est ce sac?; To change from 'who' to 'whose' just add the preposition à.

question: How is...?
answer: Comment ...? ('como')

question: Where is ...? / Where is it?
answer: Où est ...? ('ooh-ay-...') / Où est-il? ('ooh-ay-eel')

question: What is the difference between où and ou?
answer: où (with accent) means where; ou (without accent) means or; They sound the same ('oo').

question: When is ...? / When is it?
answer: Quand est ...? ('kon-ah-...')/ Quand est-ce? ('kon-tes'); NB: quand is a general word for 'when' whether you are making a question or a statement. lorsque is a slightly more formal word that you can use instead of quand.

question: When do you (informal / formal)...?
answer: Quand est-ce que tu/vous...?; NB: Quand ends in consonant sound (D) and est-ce begins with vowel sound (E) so you must link the words when speaking ('koh-Des-kuh'...)

question: How many times per week / per month?
answer: Combien de fois par semaine / par mois?; NB: Do not answer this question with 'beaucoup de fois' because it is not idiomatic. Use 'souvent' instead.

question: How often?
answer: À quelle frequence?; Alternatives: Tout les combien de temps ...? Quand ...?

question: I go to the cinema a few times per month
answer: Je vais plusiers fois par mois au cinema.; Take care on the order: adverb of frequency + actual frequency + object; Use 'plusieurs fois' instead of 'quelques fois' because the latter is not idiomatic.

question: How many years?
answer: Combien D'années?; Use combien for how many and how much. Use combien DE because you are asking about a quantity of something. Use années instead of ans because the quantity is indefinite/inexact.

question: How many people will live in this house?
answer: Combien de personnes vont vivre (futur proche) dans cette maison?

question: What are the three levels of speaking/writing in French? How are questions formed at each level?
answer: 1) soutenu: formal e.g. using inversion to form a question  2) passe partout: can be used anywhere in both formal and informal situations. e.g. using Est-ce que... to form a question. No inversion.  3) familiére: informal - only use with close friends e.g. using quoi to form a question. No inversion.

question: What are three ways to ask a closed (yes/no) question?
answer: 1) soutenu (formal with inversion): VERB + DASH + SUBJECT ? (e.g. Vas-tu? = Are you going?); Often uses a dash between verb and subject with added T for pronunciation as needed.; 2) Passe partout (aka interogative/courante): EST-CE QUE + SUBJECT + VERB? Remember that a noun ALWAYS follow EST-CE QUE. No inversion of subject/verb when using est-ce que! (e.g. Est-ce que tu vas? = Are you going?); 3) Familiére (aka affirmative): SUBJECT + VERB?; You must use intonation to make it sound like a question. Only use this structure with friends in very casual situations.

question: What are three ways to ask an open (non-yes/no question)?
answer: It is the same three options as closed questions. To make the question open we add an interogative word (que + quand + où + pourquoi + comment...). Add it at the beginning of the soutenue and passe partout formats. Add it at the end of the familiére format.; 1) Soutenue: MOT INTERROGATIVF + VERB + DASH + SUBJECT ? e.g. Où vas-tu? = Where are you going? 2) Passe Partout: MOT INTERROGTIF + EST-CE QUE + SUBJECT + VERB? e.g. Où est-ce que tu vas? = Where are you going?; 3) Familiére: SUBJECT + VERB + MOT INTERROGATIF? e.g. Tu vas où? = You go where?; NB: When using the familiar form you will typically use DE QUOI instead of QUE to signify 'what' because we need a preposition. e.g. You know OF what?

question: What would you say? Ask this in three ways: soutenue + passe partout + familiére.
answer: 1) soutenu (inversion): Que dirais-tu? QUE = what when using inversion to ask a question. 2) passe partout (qu'est-ce que / est-ce que): Est-ce que tu dirais? 3) familiére (quoi): Tu dirais quoi?

question: What is it? Ask this in three ways: soutenu + passe partout + familiére.
answer: 1) soutenu: Qu'est-ce? (rarely heard); 2) passe partout: Qu'est-ce que c'est? ('kes-kuh-say') literally means: What it is? It does not require a preposition (e.g. of what? + for what?) because the it/what is the subject. So we use QUE (instead of QUOI) in this case.; 3) Familiére: C'est quoi?

question: What is it about? (like when you see someone with a book and you are curious what it is about) Ask this in three ways: soutenu + passe partout + familiére.
answer: 1) soutenu: De quoi s'agit-il? (rarely heard); 2) passe partout: Qu'est-ce que ça raconte?; 3) familiére: Ça raconte quoi?

question: What are you doing? Ask this in three ways: soutenu + passe partout + familiére.
answer: 1) soutenu: Que fais tu?; 2) passe partout: Qu'est-ce que tu fais?; 3) familiére: Tu fais quoi?

question: Do you (formal) know of / are you familiar with X?; Ask this in two ways: soutenu + passe partout.
answer: 1) soutenu (inversion): Connaissez-vous X? 2) passe partout (interogative; est-ce without inversion): Est-ce vous connaissez X?

question: What did you (informal) do last weekend?; Ask this in two ways: soutenu + passe partout.
answer: 1) soutenu (inversion): Qu'as tu fait la semaine dernière?; 2) passe partout (interogative; est-ce without inversion): Qu'est-ce que tu as fait la semaine dernière?; NB: QUE contracts with a following word that starts with a vowel.

question: What did you do last week?; Ask this in two ways: passe partout + familiére.
answer: 1) passe partout (interogative; est-ce without inversion): Qu'est-ce que tu as fait la semaine dernière?; 2) familiére (quoi without inversion): Tu as fait QUOI la semaine dernière?; NB: dernier/dernière (m/f): When placed before the noun it means the last in a series but when placed after the noun it means the previous one.

question: What did you do last month?; Ask this using an extra tonique pronoun for emphasis.
answer: Qu'est-ce que tu as fait le mois dernière` toi?; Tonique pronouns are used in repetition to show emphasis. In this case TU is already stated. Adding TOI at the end is a common structure when people are speaking casually.

question: Is it the rainy season?; Ask this in two ways: soutenu + passe partout.
answer: 1) soutenu (inversion): EST-CE la saison des pluies?; 2) passe partout (interogative; est-ce without inversion): EST-CE QUE c'est la saison des pluies?

question: Your name is Marc. + Is your name Marc? (using soutenu/inversion)
answer: Tu t'appelles Marc. + T'appelles-tu Marc?; When using inversion with a reflexive verb the reflexive pronoun is placed before all verbs.

question: Why do you wake up early? (using soutenu/inversion)
answer: Pourquoi TE réveilles-tu tôt?; When using inversion with a reflexive verb the reflexive pronoun is placed before all verbs.

question: How do you use a proper noun (instead of a pronoun) when asking a question using the soutenu/formal form? e.g. Is Patrick Irish?
answer: Patrick est-il irlandais?; To use the soutenu form when the subject is not a pronoun you must repeat the subject as a pronoun for the inversion: SUBJECT NOUN + VERB + DASH + SUBJECT PRONOUN.

question: Use the soutenu (inversion) form to ask: Is she french? + Is Sarah french?
answer: Est-elle française? (simple inversion when subject is a pronoun) + Sarah est-elle française? (insert pronoun to enable inversion and place the proper noun at the beginning of the question)

question: Use the soutenu (inversion) form to ask: Is he orange? + Is the cat orange?
answer: Est-il orange? (simple inversion when subject is a pronoun) + Le chat est-il orange? (insert pronoun to enable inversion and place the proper noun at the beginning of the question)

question: What is a euphonic T? When do you use it?
answer: euphonic T = a T that is inserted between words to aid in pronunciation. The major use case is asking a question using inversion (soutenu). If the verb ends in a vowel then you insert the T so that the pronoun subject is easier to pronounce. e.g. Does he have a dog? = A-t-il un chien? because we cannot write A-il.

question: Do we need a cat? Use inversion/soutenu to ask the question. Use on (instead of nous).
answer: A-t-on besoin d'un chat?; Explanation: We need a cat. = On a besoin d'un chat. Using inversion: A-on besoin d'un chat. But we cannot hyphenate two vowels together. So we add the euphonic T to aid in pronunciation: A-t-on; This happens when we use inversion to ask a question and the conjugated verb ends in a vowel (which is often the case in passé composé).

question: Does she speak german? Use inversion/soutenu to ask the question.
answer: Parle-t-elle allemand?; Explanation: She speaks German. = Elle parle allemand. Using inversion: Parle-elle allemand. But we cannot hyphenate two vowels together. So we add the euphonic T to aid in pronunciation: Parle-t-elle; This happens when we use inversion to ask a question and the conjugated verb ends in a vowel (which is often the case in passé composé).

question: Did he eat the bird? Use inversion/soutenu to ask the question.
answer: A-t-il mangé l'oiseau?; Explanation: He ate the bird. = Il a mangé l'oiseau. Using inversion: A-il mangé l'oiseau. But we cannot hyphenate two vowels together. So we add the euphonic T to aid in pronunciation: A-t-il; This happens when we use inversion to ask a question and the conjugated verb ends in a vowel (which is often the case in passé composé).

question: Did the tiger eat the bird? Use inversion/soutenu to ask the question.
answer: Le tigre a-t-il mangé l'oiseau?; The tiger ate the bird. = Le tigre a mangé l'oiseau. Using inversion: Le tigre a-il mangé l'oiseau. But we cannot hyphenate two vowels together. So we add the euphonic T to aid in pronunciation: Le tigre a-t-il; This happens when we use inversion to ask a question and the conjugated verb ends in a vowel (which is often the case in passé composé).

question: You (formal) watched the movie. + Did you watch the movie? (using soutenu/inversion)
answer: Vous avez regardé le film. + Avez-vous regardé le film?; When using inversion and the verb is passé composé you hyphenate with the auxiliary (not the past participle).

question: Is the chicken good? Ask this using passe partout form.
answer: Est-ce qu'il est bon le poulet?; NB: The QUE and subject IL get pushed together with apostrophe to avoid two vowels together. qu'il ('keel') is pronounced as a single syllable. Always ignore an apostrophe for pronunciation.

question: Specify pronunciation of: Quand est-ce que tu vas? + Quand es tu libre? Explain the difference.
answer: Quand est-ce que tu vas? ('qan-Tuh-skuh-too-va') + Quand es tu libre? ('qan-Ehs-too-leebr'); Add a T liaison between QUAND and EST-CE. But there is never a liaison between QUAND and a VERB (e.g. es). Pronounce the two words separately without liaison in the second case.

question: How do you know whether to use QUE or QUOI when asking 'what'?
answer: In french it matters whether you are asking for a subject that is doing the action (use QUE) or a direct object with a preposition (use QUOI)... even though often times in english we omit that preoposition. An example with QUE: What is the thing on the table? = QU'est-ce que la chose sur la table? The thing is the subject that is doing the action (being on the table). So we use QUE to refer to the thing when asking the question.

question: Would you agree to X?
answer: Etês-vous d'accord avec X?

question: At what time do you wake up? ...go to bed?
answer: À quelle heure vous reveillez-vous? ...vous couchez-vous?

question: idiomatic way to ask: Do you want to eat? (formal and informal)
answer: Ça vous / te ('tuh') dit ('dee') DE manger?; This is very idiomatic french. The structure doesn't translate exactly but it means: Do you want to do + DE + INFINITIVE.; A server might ask 'Ça vous dit?' to take your order.

question: idiomatic way to ask: Do you want to go to the movies? (formal and informal)
answer: Ça vous/ te ('tuh') dit ('dee') d'aller au cinéma?; The structure doesn't translate exactly but it means: Do you want to do + DE + INFINITIVE. DE changes to D' because the infinitive verb starts with a vowel.

question: How much is it?
answer: C'est combien? / Ça fait combien? ('sah-fay-kom-bien')/ Combien ça coûte? ('kom-bien-sa-coot'); Ça fait is a really common way to say 'It is' or 'It must be'. It is used in situations similar to - but different from - il faut.

question: How much is X?
answer: Combien coûte ...? ('kom-bien-coot')

question: How much do I owe you?
answer: Je vous dois ('dwa') combien?

question: It costs... + It is worth...
answer: Ça coûte... + Il vaut... (from the verb VALOIR)

question: the cost is high
answer: Le coût est très cher. OR Le coût est plus élevé.; élevée means raised in the sense of heightened and also in terms of a person being raised by their parents

question: idiomatic way to say: It's worth it. + It's not worth it.
answer: Ça vaut ('voh') le coup ('koo'). + Ça ne vaut pas le coup.; vaut is from VALOIR (to be worth).; You can use this in many ways. e.g. Ça vaut le fatigue. = It's worth the hard work / being tired.

question: I'm worth it.
answer: Je vaux le coup.; The verb is VALOIR. The saying is: Ça vaut ('voh') le coup. We replace the subject Ça with Je and reconjugate the verb.

question: It's worth learning it.
answer: Ça vaut ('voh') le coup de l'apprendre. OR Ça vaut ('voh') la peine de l'apprendre.; This is based on the phrase: Ça vaut le coup. = It's worth it.

question: My labtop is expensive but it is worth it.
answer: Mon ordinateur est cher mais IL vaut le coup.; The saying is: Ça vaut ('voh') le coup. Il replaces Ça in this case.

question: idiomatic way to say: a good value for the price
answer: un bon rapport qualité prix

question: idiomatic way to say: It's priceless.
answer: Ça n'a pas de prix.; Literally: It does not have a price.

question: Do you have to work?
answer: Est-ce que tu dois travailler?

question: What does he do for work?
answer: Quest-que il fais dans la vie? or... pour le travail?; Alternative: Il travaille dans quoi?  Use DE QUOI (instead of QUE) because the 'what' is the direct object and requires a preposition (for).

question: How do you pay the rent?
answer: Comment payerez-vous le loyer?; le loyer ('lwa-yay') is the thing you pay. louer ('loo-ay') is the verb to rent.

question: How much do you want to spend?
answer: Quelle est votre budget?

question: to earn a living
answer: gagner sa vie; e.g. Elle gagne sa vie en tant que directrice marketing.

question: to win
answer: gagner = to win/earn/gain; Alternative: remporter la coupe / la médaille = to win the cup / the medal

question: idiomatic way to say: It paid off.
answer: Pari gagné.; le pari = gamble/bet

question: idiomatic way to say: You beat me (at something).
answer: Tu as été plus rapide (or meilleur) que moi.; There is no way to directly translate 'beat' in this case. You cannot use gagner (to win/gain) in this case.; Alternative: ZLATANER is a verb invented after Zlatan Ibrahimovich played for PSG. It means to beat/destroy something in a light/joking way (non-threatening). e.g. Je vais te zlataner. = I will destroy you.

question: Let's go!
answer: Allons y! ('ah-lohn-z') OR C'est parti!; These can mean let's go! + let's get going! +  ...and their off!; Though parti is the past participle or partir - it is only used to describe things happening in the present.; Alternative: On y va! (technically: Let's go there.)

question: It's finished. (like when a show is over or you are at the end of a meal)
answer: C'est fini.

question: with + without
answer: avec + sans

question: somehow
answer: d'une certaine manière

question: What does this mean? Tu as des manières.
answer: You are acting gay / effeminate.; This is how you describe the stereotypical mannerisms of a gay man. It is derogatory in both english and french.

question: in order to
answer: pour (e.g. I read in order to learn. = Je lis pour apprendre.); Alternative: DE + manière + À + INFINITIVE; e.g. I eat in order to grow. = Je mange de manière à grandir.

question: once
answer: une fois

question: only
answer: seulement / uniquement; NB: d'un(e) seul(e) = only one

question: alone
answer: seul(e); It means alone or the only one when placed before the noun. It means lonely when placed after the noun.

question: a single word + a lonely person
answer: un seul mot + une personne seule; The placement of the adjective changes the meaning of the phrase.

question: about
answer: Different words are used in different contexts.; ENVIRON is the word to use for roughly (e.g. about 10 years); À PROPOS works in most situations where you mean about some topic. It's not always idiomatic but everyone will understand what you mean.; DE is used when you express that you talking about something or someone (e.g. Je t'ai parlé de lui. = I told you about him.); SUR is also used (e.g. sur lui = about him); Il s'agit... = It's about...; concernant = regarding

question: regarding
answer: concernant

question: I read lots of books about history.
answer: Je lis beaucoup de livres à propos d'histoire.

question: I just read an article. It's about a phenomenon.
answer: Je viens de lire un article. Il s'agit d'un phenomène.; Il s'agit DE quelque chose. is the way you generically say that something is about a subject. It is always 'Il s'agit...'. Even if the 'thing' that you are referring to is feminine or plural you still use 'Il s'agit...' - similar to 'Il faut...'

question: It's about a person close to you.
answer: Il s'agit d'une personne proche de toi.; Il s'agit DE quelque chose. is the way you generically say that something is about a subject. It is always 'Il s'agit...'. Even if the 'thing' that you are referring to is feminine or plural you still use 'Il s'agit...' - similar to 'Il faut...'

question: I heard about the book. + I heard about it.
answer: J'ai entendu parler DU livre. + J'EN ai entendu parler.; Use ENTENDRE + PARLER + DE when you hear 'about' something - the something is an indirect objedct.; Use EN to replace the object with a pronoun because we use the preposition DE following entendre parler.

question: I heard about him. + I heard things about him.
answer: J'ai entendu parler DE LUI. + J'ai entendu DES choses SUR LUI.; Use ENTENDRE + PARLER + DE when you hear 'about' something - the something is an indirect objedct.; Use EN to replace the indirect object referenced with DE. Use SUR LUI to reference a person being talked about.

question: I heard that that country is beautiful.
answer: J'ai entendu DIRE QUE ce pays est très beau.; Use ENTENDRE + DIRE when you heard that something was said - because the something is a direct object in this case. This is different from hearing about something - which uses ENTENDRE + PARLER + DE instead.

question: already
answer: déjà; The phrase 'd'ores et déjà' is another way to say 'already' or 'starting now'. ores is an old word that mean 'hours'.

question: ready
answer: prêt(e); adjective that describes a person; e.g. Je suis prêt(e). = I am ready.; NB: Prét a mange. = Ready to eat.

question: not yet
answer: pas encore ('pah-Zehn-kohr'); encore can mean 'yet' or 'even'

question: almost
answer: presque

question: almost all people
answer: presque toutes les personnes; Use toutes because personnes is plural and feminine.

question: most people
answer: la plupart des personnes; NB: This is a plural subject in french. e.g. La plupart des personnes SONT intelligents. Think of 'la plupart' as translating to 'most of them'. It acts like a plural subject even though it looks singular. So it uses SONT instead of EST.

question: Most of the friends are here.
answer: La plupart des amis SONT ici.; Think of 'la plupart' as translating to 'most of them'. It acts like a plural subject even though it looks singular. So it uses SONT instead of EST.

question: adequate / a decent amount of something
answer: convenable

question: to be enough (verb)
answer: suffire; 'to suffice' is a good translation. SUFFIRE is the verb used in the very common saying: Ça suffit. ('sah-soo-fee').

question: idiomatic way to say: It's enough.
answer: Ça suffit. ('sah-soo-fee'); You could say: C'est suffisant. But that is not as idiomatic.

question: enough (adjective)
answer: suffisant(e) OR assez; NB: assez means different things in different contexts. e.g. assez effrayant means quite scary - not scary enough.; The adverb that means sufficiently is: suffisamment. This follows a rule for transforming adjectives to adverbs: If adjective ends in -ANT or -ENT then remove -NT and add -AMMENT or -EMMENT respectively.

question: There are not enough days in the summer.
answer: Il n'y a pas ASSEZ de jours durant l'ete.

question: rather bad
answer: assez mal; This is a case where assez is used to mean something other than 'enough'.

question: in about 10 days
answer: environ (= approximately) 10 jours; Alternative: À l'horizon 2055... = In approximately 2055... or By 2055... (from the perspective of some date in the future)

question: a week + a weekend
answer: une semaine + un week-end

question: this week
answer: cette semaine; this could mean the previous week or the following week (same as english) so you must listen for context

question: monday + tuesday + wednesday; Specify pronunciation.
answer: lundi ('luhn-di') + mardi ('MAR-di' ...remember to let the r catch in the throat a bit) + mercredi ('MEH-cri-di'); NB: Add À in front of the word to make it a salutation. e.g. À lundi! = See you on Monday!; If you are simply saying the word for tomorrow or a day of the week - then just use the word without à in front of it. e.g. On va aller demain. = We will go tomorrow. On va aller mercredi. = We will go on Wednesday.

question: thursday + friday + saturday + sunday; Specify pronunciation.
answer: jeudi ('zshooh-di' ...the j is really soft) + vendredi ('VON-dra-di') + samedi ('sam-di') + dimanche ('DEE-monsh') NB: Add À in front of the word to make it a salutation. e.g. À samedi! = See you on Saturday!; If you are simply saying the word for tomorrow or a day of the week - then just use the word without à in front of it. e.g. On va aller demain. = We will go tomorrow. On va aller Dimanche. = We will go on Sunday.

question: How do you make a day of the week plural?
answer: les dimanches; same as any other word - add S

question: On Saturday... + On Sunday night
answer: Samedi... + Dimanche soir...; Do not use a preposition in front of a day's name.

question: Maybe I will see you on Wednesday.
answer: Pout-être je te verrai (futur simple) mercredi.; Futur simple is idiomatic here. But it's also true that we generally avoid using futur proche with 'maybe' because conditionnel is a better choice for something that might happen in the future.; Remember days of the week are not capitalized and do not require a preposition (à or en) in front of them.

question: How do you know whether to use jour vs journée / soir vs soirée / an vs année / etc?
answer: Generally the former (jour/matin/soir/an) is for talking about that period of time as a subject - on this day or in that year. Generally the latter (journée/matinée/soirée/année) is for talking about the duration of time - how it is spent.

question: all day long + all morning long + all night long + all year long
answer: toute ('toot') la journée + matinée + soirée + année.; Use toute because all three are feminine singular.; matinée in french is the duration of the morning. It is a faux ami because in English we use this word to refer to a performance in the afternoon.

question: during the day/morning/night/year
answer: pendant la... journée + matinée + soirée + année; The preposition pendant triggers this form (which emphasizes the duration) instead of jour/soir/an.

question: one time per day/morning/night/year
answer: une fois par... jour + matin + soir + an

question: one time in the day/morning/night/year
answer: une fois dans la... journée + matinée + soirée + année; The preposition dans triggers this form instead of jour/soir/an.

question: a month + a year
answer: un mois ('mwa') + un ans ('ahn'); NB: If you are counting use un ans. If you are talking about a duration of time use une année.

question: january + february + march; Specify pronunciation.
answer: janvier ('zhahn-veeay') + février ('fay-vReeay') + mars ('mars' like the planet in Englisy); fèvrier has an R. janvier does not.

question: april + may + june; Specify pronunciation.
answer: avril ('ah-vreel') + mai ('may' same as English) + juin ('zshoo-uhn')

question: july + august + september; Specify pronunciation.
answer: juillet ('zhoo-yay') + août ('ahoot' as one syllable) + septembre ('suh-ptohMbr')

question: october + november + december; Specify pronunciation.
answer: octobre ('oak-tohbr') + novembre ('noe-vohMbr') + décembre ('day-sohMbr'); octobre does NOT have an M. But septembre novembre and decembre do have M.

question: June 21
answer: le 21 juin; Dates always have an article in front and they are always masculine.

question: March 1
answer: le premiere mars; the 1st of a month is always spoken as 'le premiere' - never with a number. The other dates in a month always use numbers (e.g. le deux or le 2).

question: Friday December 2
answer: vendredi 2 décembre; !! no 'le' in front of the date when the date is preceded by the day of the week.

question: on Thursday afternoon
answer: LE jeudi après-midi; Use the article in this case.

question: in april
answer: EN avril; en is the translation for in when talking about a month or year

question: It was August.
answer: C'était EN août. OR C'était le mois D'août.; A preposition (en or de) is required. You cannot say: C'était août. Or C'était le mois août.

question: the beginning of May
answer: le début mai; NB: la quiazaine is a half of the month. la 1ème quiazaine (days 1-15) and la 2ème quiazaine (days 16-31)

question: mid June
answer: mi-juin; mi- works for any time period where you want to express the middle; Do not use 'demi' in this case.

question: the end of July
answer: fin juiliet

question: a season
answer: une saison

question: a winter + a spring + a summer + an autumn
answer: un hiver + un printemps + un été + un automne (do NOT pronounce the M in automne); all masculine

question: in winter + in spring + in summer + in autumn
answer: en hiver + au printemps + en été + en automne

question: adjectives for each season of the year
answer: hivernal + printanier + estival + autommal

question: It is winter.
answer: C'est l'hiver.; Do not use 'il y a...' or 'il fait...' for this statement.; Do not forget the article.

question: before + after
answer: avant + après

question: then...
answer: puis... or ensuite...; This is only for when you are describing things that really happen sequentially. Use alors for other cases especially when you are implying causation.

question: soon
answer: bientôt ('byohn-toe')

question: now
answer: maintenant ('mont-uh-no'; 3 syllables); Alternative: dès maintenant = starting from now; Alternative: désormais (= starting now) can be used in place of actually... + today... + right now...

question: at this moment (when you mean right now)
answer: pour l'instant OR EN ce moment; Alternative: aujourd'hui même

question: at that moment (in the past when you are telling a story)
answer: À ce moment-là; NB: This is slightly different than how you express 'in this moment' in present tense: EN ce moment

question: at that moment (in the future)
answer: au moment de + infinitive

question: this morning (today) + that morning (back then)
answer: ce matin + ce matin là

question: today + not today; Specify pronunciation.
answer: aujourd'hui ('ohn-jour-dwi') + pas aujourd'hui ('paZ-ohn-jour-dwi'; Make the liaison with pas.); The first syllable is a strong O sound.; NB: De nos jours... = Nowadays...

question: tomorrow + tomorrow morning
answer: demain ('duh-ma') + demain matin ('duh-ma-ma-ton');  NB: Add À in front of the word to make it a salutation. e.g. À demain! = Until tomorrow!; If you are simply saying the word for tomorrow or a day of the week - then just use the word without à in front of it. e.g. On va aller demain. = We will go tomorrow. On va aller mercredi. = We will go on Wednesday.

question: yesterday
answer: heir ('ee-air')

question: the day before yesterday + before yesterday
answer: The spelling for these two is exactly the same: avant hier. But if you mean the actual day before yesterday (2 days ago) it is pronounced 'a-van-tière' like one word. But if you mean the time in general that was before yesterday then it is pronounced 'a-van ee-ehr' like two separate words.

question: the previous day + the day before...
answer: la veille ('vay') + la veille ('vay') DE...; VEILLE is close to - but different than - the feminine version of the adjective for old: vieille ('vee-yay')

question: the day after X + the days after X
answer: le lendemain de X + les jours d'après X; les jours d'après = the following days

question: the day after(wards)
answer: le jour suivant OR le jour d'après; NB: d'après can also mean 'according to' e.g. d'après toi = according to you. But selon que is a better way to express 'according to'

question: the day after tomorrow
answer: le surlendemain

question: that day (some day in the past) + that week (some week in the past)
answer: ce jour-là + cette semaine-là

question: that month (some month in the past) + that year (some year in the past)
answer: ce mois-là + cette année-là

question: these last days
answer: ces derniers jours

question: 10 years ago
answer: il y a 10 ans

question: 3 days ago (meaning the reference point is the present)
answer: Il y a 3 jours.; You can only use the 'il y a' structure when the reference point is the present. For example if you want to say: It happened 3 days before the graduation. You cannot say 'three days ago...'. In this case you must switch to other formats like 3 jours avant / auparavant / plus tôt.

question: 3 days before (some event; meaning that the reference point is in the past or future)
answer: 3 jours avant OR 3 jours auparavant OR 3 jours plus tôt; You cannot use: il y a 3 jours (= 3 days ago) because that only works when the reference point is the present.

question: a month from now
answer: DANS un mois OR après un mois

question: in a few months
answer: dans quelques mois; Use quelqueS becuase mois is plural.

question: What is the difference between 'en quelques jours' and 'dans quelques jours'?
answer: EN quelques jours = over the course of a few days; DANS quelques jours = starting in a few days from now

question: some years later
answer: plusieurs années plus tard

question: one more week
answer: une semaine de plus  (pronounce the S at the end)

question: It leaves me four more years to study french.
answer: Ça me laisse 4 ans de plus (pronounce the S) pour étudier le français.

question: Not so long ago...
answer: Il n'y a pas si longtemps...

question: shortly after...
answer: un court temps après que...; NB: APRÈS QUE does not technically trigger the subjonctif - that is the grammar rule that should be followed in exams. But people typically use the subjonctif following après que (like avant que) in oral and written french.

question: Two ways to say: when I was young...
answer: 1) quand j'étais jeune... 2) lorsque j'étais jeune; lorsque is a slightly more formal way to say 'when'; Alternative: Quand j'étais gosse... = When I was a kid...

question: When I was 19 years old...
answer: Quand j'avais 19 ans...;Use imparfait because age is part of the setting in the past - like telling a story.

question: In my 20s/30s/40s...
answer: Dans ma vingtaine/trentaine/quarantaine...; Alternative: Quand j'avais une vingtaine/trentaine/quarantaine d'années... = When I was in my 20s/30s/40s...

question: back in the day (common french expression)
answer: à l'époque OR autrefois; une époque = an era

question: In the past...
answer: Dans le passé...

question: in the 19th century
answer: PENDANT le 19ème siècle (masculine); You must use pendant (instead of dans) because the century is a duration of time. So literally: during the 19th century

question: in the 1900s
answer: DANS les années 1900; Use dans here because you are referencing a group of years. If - instead - you are referencing a specific year then use EN. (e.g. in 1982 = en 1982).

question: the early 90s
answer: au début des années 90

question: a decade
answer: une décennie

question: in 1988
answer: EN 1988; Use en when referencing a specific/single year. Use DANS when referencing a more vague time frame (e.g. in the 80s).

question: from 1995 to 1997
answer: de 1995 à 1997; de / à are also used like from / to for email and mail

question: starting at 19h + beginning in 1990
answer: à partir de 19h + à partir de 1990

question: as soon as...
answer: dès + noun OR dès que + phrase; e.g. dès qu'on commence = as soon as we start; 'dès que' is an alternative to 'à partir de...' (= starting from); Dès is pronounced the same as des but has a totally different meaning.

question: as soon as I go out...
answer: dès que je sors...; as soon as = dès + noun OR dès que + phrase

question: from the start (quickly/rapidly)
answer: dès le début; as soon as = dès + noun OR dès que + phrase

question: between now and the end of the week
answer: d'ici la fin de la semaine; d'ici... = from now until...

question: between now and 3 days from now
answer: d'ici trois jours

question: 2 more days
answer: deux jours de plus

question: just
answer: juste

question: until
answer: jusqu'à (usually in terms of distance); Sometimes 'tant que' can be used to mean until in a temporal way e.g. until someone does something

question: until 2019
answer: jusqu'en 2019

question: until I was 7 years old
answer: jusqu'à mes 7 ans

question: so far
answer: jusqu'ici OR jusqu'à présent

question: 5 years before / after X
answer: 5 ans avant / après

question: before studying French...
answer: avant D'étudier le français...; The structure for this: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE; This structure does not work for après. When you say 'after doing X' that 'doing' must have happened in the past so it would need to be conjugated in a past tense (instead of DE + infinitive).

question: before moving to NYC...
answer: avant DE s'installer à NYC; The structure for this: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE; This structure does not work for après. When you say 'after doing X' that 'doing' must have happened in the past so it would need to be conjugated in a past tense (instead of DE + infinitive).

question: before the water stopped
answer: avant QUE l'eau s'est arrêté; The structure for this: AVANT + subject or phrase. If it is a phrase then the phrase should be in the subjonctif because AVANT QUE triggers subjonctif.; We cannot use AVANT + DE because what follows is a noun/phrase.; We use the reflexive form of the verb (S'ARRÊTER) because some subject has to stop the water - it can't be ambiguous. In this case the water is stopping itself. Or we could be explicit that someone turned off the water - then we could use the non-reflexive form: ARRÊTER.

question: after studying French...
answer: après mes études de français... OR après avoir étudié (literally: after my french studies or after having studied); You can NOT use après + de + infinitive (like you can for avant). So we have to change the structure to either use a noun or by conjugating the verb in the past tense. Use passé composé because you are obviously describing a sequential step in the past.

question: after moving to NYC...
answer: après mon installation à NYC... OR après avoir s'installé (literally: after my move to NYC or after having moved); You can NOT use après + de + infinitive (like you can for avant). So we have to change the structure to either use a noun or by conjugating the verb in the past tense. Use passé composé because you are obviously describing a sequential step in the past

question: after passing the B1 exam...
answer: après avoir réussi l'examen B1...; You can NOT use après + de + infinitive (like you can for avant). So - even though you might be talking about something in the future - conjugate the verb in the past tense with passé composé.

question: I ate the food IN one hour.
answer: J'ai mangé la nourriture EN une heure.; Use EN for the quantity of time that it takes to complete something.

question: for (in the service of something)
answer: pour; Generally you can use the word 'pour' to replace the word 'for'. But this is not always true - especially when talking about time ranges.

question: for/during (the duration of some time frame completely in the past)
answer: pendant; Use pendant with verbs in the past tense. If the time frame is specified you will probably use passé composé. If the time frame is in the past but ambiguous then you will probably use imparfait.; Pendant is exclusively for time frames that started and ended in the past without relation to the present.; e.g. Je l'ai fait pendant 2 semaines. = I did it for 2 weeks.; NB: There are exceptions. Use pour if the time frame was pre-determined.

question: for (the duration of some time frame completely in the future)
answer: pour

question: for (the duration of some time frame that is ambigous - when you do not know if it occurs in the past present or future)
answer: pour

question: for (the duration of some time frame that overlaps with the present but was pre-determined)
answer: pour; e.g. Je suis ici pour trois jours.; Use present even though the time frame extends into the future.

question: for / since (the duration of some time frame that started in the past and overlaps with the present)
answer: depuis ('duh-pwi') or depuis que; Use depuis with verbs in the present tense. It is exclusively for time ranges that started in the past and continue in the present.; e.g. Je le fais depuis 2 semaines.= I have been doing it for/since 2 weeks.; NB: Sometimes we need to use depuis with past tense verbs but only when the action continues into the present.

question: for (the duration of some time frame strictly in the future)
answer: pour; Use pour only for time frames that are 100% in the future.

question: Which word (pendant or depuis or pour) would you use to describe an election term or the duration of a visa?
answer: pour; The hint here is that the duration is pre-determined.

question: Which word (pendant or depuis or pour) would you use in this sentence? I ran for one hour.
answer: J'ai couru PENDANT une heure.; Use pendant because the activity was strictly in the past and the duration was not pre-determined.

question: Which word (pendant or depuis or pour) would you use in this sentence? In the mornings I run for one hour.
answer: Le matin je cours pendant une heure.; Use pendant because 'in the mornings' is an indicator that it will happen again. This - in combination with present tense - forces the use of pendant.

question: Which word (pendant or depuis or pour) would you use in this sentence? I run for one hour last night.
answer: Je cours pendant une heure heir soir.; Use pendant because 'last night' is an indicator of the past. Even though the verb tense is in present we use pendant in this scenario.

question: When do you use DEPUIS vs DEPUIS QUE?
answer: They both mean for/since (some time frame that started in the past and continues into the present). Use DEPUIS when what follows is only the time frame (not a complete phrase) e.g. I have danced for 10 years / a long time. = Je danse DEPUIS 10 ans / long temps.; Use DEPUIS QUE when what follows is a complete phrase with subject and verb. e.g. I have danced since I began walking. = Je danse DEPUIS QUE j'ai commencé à marcher.

question: while
answer: PENDANT QUE; When you use 'pendant que' then you typically use présent or imparfait; e.g. Quelqu’un est venu pendant que je dormais. = Someone came (passé composé) while I was sleeping (imparfait).; e.g. Ils sortent pendant que je dors. = They go out (présent) while I sleep (présent).; NB: alors que is an alternative to pendant que but it is only used in special contexts.

question: I saw a film during my stay in Paris.
answer: J'ai vu un film pendant mon séjour à Paris.; Use pendant because the time frame began and ended in the past.

question: I will be in France for 5 years.
answer: Je serai en France pour cinq ans.; Use pour because the time frame is strictly in the future with no relation to the present.; Use ans (instead of années) because the quantity is exact.

question: I have been here for several years.
answer: Je suis là depuis plusiers années.; Use depuis because the time frame continues to the present (like since).; Use années (instead of ans) because the quantity is indefinite/inexact.

question: over the years
answer: à travers les années / au fil des années

question: How long have you (formal) studied french?
answer: Depuis combien de temps ètudiez-vous le français?; Use depuis because the time frame continues to the present (like since).; You could substitute 'quand' for 'combien de temps' in this case.

question: When answering a question about 'how long'... It's been 3 weeks.
answer: Ça fait trois semaines.; Ça fait is a really common and casual way of expressing that something has been happening.; Alternative: Cela fait trois semaines. = That makes 3 weeks.

question: It hasn't been a long time.
answer: Ça ne fait pas longtemps.; Ça fait is a really common and casual way of expressing that something has been happening.

question: It's been a while since I was in an office.
answer: Ça faisait longtemps (ou un moment) que je n'avais pas été dans un bureau.

question: idiomatic way to say: It's been a while.
answer: Ça fait un moment.; close to: It's been a minute. You could use longtemps instead of un moment.

question: I've danced since I was 3 years old.
answer: Je danse depuis que j'ai 3 ans.; This makes sense in french. But it is more common to say: Je fais de la danse. Like faire de la musique.

question: It has been a year since I spoke German.
answer: Il y a un an QUE j'ai parlé allemand.

question: He worked as a waiter for 4 years in total (not necessarily consecutively).
answer: Il a travaillé comme serveur 4 ans AU TOTAL.

question: I've been visiting France regularly for 10 years.
answer: Je viens en France régulièrement depuis 10 ans.; Use VENIR instead of VISITER.; Use DEPUIS with present tense to talk about an activity that started in the past and continues into the present.

question: How long did you stay in the Phillipes?
answer: Combien de temps resteras-tu (resterez-vous) rester aux Philippines?; resteras/resterez are futur simple; Use AUX because Philippines is plural.

question: Cook the meat for 20 minutes.
answer: Fais cuir la viande pour 20 minutes.

question: We have class for 4 hours.
answer: Nous avons classe pendant 4 heures.; Use pendant because a repetitive activity is implied.; NB: Use classe to talk about the time you are at school. Use cours to talk about the type of class you are taking. e.g. un cours de tango (literally: a course of study); Alternative: Nous allons en cours pendant 4 heures.

question: Since 2020...
answer: Depuis 2020...

question: Two months since I was in class.
answer: Deux mois DEPUIS QUE je suis en classe.; Use present tense in this case.; NB: Use classe to talk about the time you are at school. Use cours to talk about the type of class you are taking. e.g. un cours de tango (literally: a course of study)

question: Two ways to say: It was 20 years ago that I was a scientist.
answer: 1) Il y a(vait) 20 ans QUE je suis scientifique. 2) Ça fait 20 ans QUE je suis scientifique.; NB: Use present tense in both cases.

question: I was 19 years old when I started living alone.
answer: J'AVAIS (imparfait) 19 ans quand j'ai commencé (passé composé) à vivre seul.; The first phrase is in imparfait because it describes state of being/setting. The second phrase is passé composé because it describes a discreet action.

question: It was 10 months ago.
answer: C'etait il y a dix mois. (imparfait + il y a + time); It is also possible to say: Il y avait dix mois.

question: the food from 100 years ago
answer: la nourriture D'il y a 100 ans; Simply add DE in front of il y a...

question: in an instant + within a week (2 phrases that indicate something happening in the near future)
answer: dans un instant + dans une semaine; NB: It is likely to use futur proche tense with these phrases.

question: an instant ago + one week ago (2 phrases that indicate something happening in the near past)
answer: il y a un instant + il y a une semaine; NB: It is likely to use passé recent tense with these phrases.

question: I have been studying for 6 months. + I have not studied for 6 months.
answer: J'étudie depuis six mois. + Je n'ai pas étudié depuis six mois.; When the statement is positive use present tense with depuis. But when you negate this kind of phrase you have to use passé composé. We still use depuis because the lack of action continues in the present.; NB: The negated structure implies that the action was happening before it stopped happening.

question: I have been reading a book for 1 month. + I have not read a book for 1 month.
answer: Je lis un livre depuis un mois. + Je n'ai pas lu un livre depuis un mois.; When the statement is positive use present tense with depuis. But when you negate this kind of phrase you have to use passé composé. We still use depuis because the lack action continues in the present.; NB: The negated structure implies that the action was happening before it stopped happening.

question: It's been raining for 10 days.
answer: Il pleut depuis dix jours. Use jours in this case - not journées.

question: rarely
answer: rarement; NB: For these kinds of freqency adverbs place them after the verb. e.g. Il court rarement. (He runs rarely.)

question: once in a lifetime
answer: une seule fois dans une vie; seul(e); It means alone or the only one when placed before the noun. It means lonely when placed after the noun

question: sometimes
answer: parfois OR des fois; 'Quelques fois' is less idiomatic.; Never use quelque(s) jour(s) to mean sometimes or to mean 'on some days' - as in 'on a random day'. quelques jours = a grouping of a few consecutive days (e.g. J'ai étudié pendant quelques jours.)

question: How would you express: There are some (not consecutive) days when...
answer: Il y a des jours quand... OR Des fois...; The latter option means At times... / Sometimes....; You have to be careful to avoid 'quelques jours' which literally means a collection of several consecutive days.

question: multiple times + many times
answer: plusieurs fois + souvent; Do not say 'beacoup de fois' to mean many times. It is not idiomatic. Use souvent instead.

question: often + frequently
answer: souvent + fréquemment; Alternative: habituellement = usually; NB: souvent (often) is an adverb that does not have an adjective counterpart. Jamais (never) is the same.

question: most of the time
answer: la plupart du temps; do not forget the article before plupart - it is incorrect to start a sentence with 'Plupart du temps...'

question: above all / most importantly
answer: surtout ('sewwww-rhtoo') OR principalement; Surtout can be used to mean 'mostly' but 'above all' is the more common use case.; Surtout is a great word to understand the difference between french U sound (the first syllable - low in the mouth - lips in tight O shape) and OU sound (the second syllable - higher in the mouth - like english 'oo').

question: usually + ...per usual
answer: d'habitude + ...comme d'habitude

question: habits + unusual activities
answer: des activités habituelles + des activités peu habituelles; The addition of PEU negates the adjective instead of minimizing it.

question: a bad habit
answer: une mauvaise habitude

question: still + I am still sick
answer: toujours + Je suis toujours malade.; The translation of STILL depends on the context. Toujours is one possibility but it can also mean always.

question: They still want to go to Greece.
answer: Ils veulent toujours aller en Grèce ('gres').; Grèce is feminine.

question: always
answer: toujours; toujours can also mean still

question: never
answer: jamais; JAMAIS is a negative adverb. It replaces PAS when using NE + PAS form.; NB: Jamais is an adverb that does not have an adjective counterpart.

question: finally + eventually
answer: finalement / en fin + au final

question: recently
answer: récemment OR depuis peu de temps; récent(e) = recent.

question: currently
answer: actuellement; Take care because this is a 'faux ami'. It does not mean actually in English.

question: suddenly
answer: soudain

question: all of a sudden
answer: tout à coup; NB: This is a fixed french expression that uses TOUT regardless of the number/gender of what it refers to.

question: immediately / right away
answer: tout à l'heure + tout de suite ('tootd-sweet') + directement;  NB: These are fixed french expressions that uses TOUT regardless of the number/gender of what it refers to.

question: except
answer: sauf OR excepté OR à l'exception de

question: aside from / exluding
answer: à part

question: besides
answer: mise à part OR d'ailleurs

question: the next part
answer: la partie suivante

question: a (small) part of
answer: une (petite) partie DE; partie is the noun and it is feminine; NB: This can also mean political party.

question: idiomatic way to say: most of the parts
answer: la plus grande partie

question: The room is one part of the café.
answer: La salle fait partie DU café.; Use FAIRE. de + le = du

question: entirely + the entire book
answer: entièrement + le livre entier

question: maybe + probably
answer: peut-être ('poo-ehtr') + probablement ('proh-BA-BLUH-mon'); There are more pronounced syllables than you might expect in pro-ba-ble-ment.

question: the current situation
answer: la situation présente (not courant)

question: in this case... + just in case...
answer: dans ce cas ('don-suh-kah') + au cas où ('oh-kah-oo'); In both cases the S is silent.

question: generally
answer: généralment

question: primarily / mainly
answer: principalement

question: even without...
answer: même sans...; Même can be translated as 'even' so it is used for both equivalency and for emphasis (e.g. even though... + even when...).

question: even through / even if...
answer: même si...; Même can be translated as 'even' so it is used for both equivalency and for emphasis (e.g. even though... + even when...).

question: despite / in spite of
answer: malgré; e.g. Malgrè les problèmes...

question: regardless
answer: malgré tout OR quand même; These can both mean regardless or anyway when you are making a contrast.; Quand même is a french expression. The closest literal translation is 'all the same'.

question: He did it regardless/anyway.
answer: Il l'a quand même fait.; quand même is the correct phrase to use in this case. If instead you want to use the word 'anyway' to make a conversational bridge then use the word bref instead.

question: even when...
answer: même quand; It's a literal translation.; Be careful because if you reverse the order it means something different: quand même = regardless.

question: otherwise
answer: sinon; Literally: if not... (si + non)

question: instead
answer: à la place OR au lieu de

question: on the contrary...
answer: au contraire...

question: on the other hand...
answer: Tout au contraire... OR D'autre part...; Alternatively you could use d'un côté (on the one hand) and then d'un autre côté (on the other hand). But you MUST use both of these. You cannot just use one of them - as you can in English.

question: in comparison to
answer: par rapport à OR en comparaison à (or avec)

question: to compare + the comparison
answer: comparer + la comparaison; COMPARER uses prepositions similary in french and english: comparer X avec Y (to compare X with Y) + comparer X à Y (to compare X to Y) + comparer X et Y (to compare X and Y)

question: What if...?
answer: Et si...?

question: nevertheless
answer: néanmoins + toutefois (can also mean however)

question: however (conversational bridge/conjunction when making a contradiction)
answer: Lots of options: cependant + en revanche + par contre + toutefois; NB: Cependant can also mean then (at that time in the future).

question: What does pourtant mean?
answer: It is a conjunction used to contrast or emphasize. So it can mean yet + even though + nevertheless + but even so.

question: anyway... (conversational bridge)
answer: bref... OR tout de même... OR m'enfin bon...; Both of these work when you are just making a conversational bridge. But if you mean something like: He did it regardless. Then you should use quand même or malgré.; NB: tout de même is a fixed french expression that uses TOUT regardless of the number/gender of the antecedent to which it refers.

question: actually... (conversational bridge)
answer: en fait ('ohn-fehT'). The final T is optional - some pronounce it some do not. This is the how you differentiate the sounds of on fait ('ohn-fay'; means we do) and en fait ('uhn-feht').

question: basically... (conversational bridge)
answer: en gros

question: So... / Therefore... (conversational bridge hinting at causation)
answer: Many options: 1) alors... 2) donc... ('donk') Watch out because DONK means fuck or damn. 3) du coup ('dewww-koo') This can mean 'as a result'. This is a great word to understand the difference between french U sound (the first syllable - low in the mouth - lips in tight O shape) and OU sound (the second syllable - higher in the mouth - like english 'oo'). 4) C'est pour ça que... 5) si bien que... 6) de sorte que... 7) à tel point que... 8) C'est pourqoui... 9) en conséquence... is a little formal.

question: of course
answer: bien sûr

question: obvious + obviously
answer: évident(e)/clair(e) + évidemment

question: on purpose
answer: exprès OR intentionnellement (= intentionally); NB: This is an adverb. On purpose is another way of saying purposefully.

question: They did it on purpose.
answer: Ils en ont fait exprès.

question: especially
answer: EN particulier / particulièrement; e.g. especially in Rennes = en particulier à Rennes ('rhen')

question: specific
answer: Use the word for precise: précis(e); e.g. une chose précise = a specific thing; literally: precise

question: properly
answer: proprement; This adverb is used the same way in conversational french and english. e.g. when you do something 'properly' you do it completely or maybe even to excess

question: To clarify/To be clear...
answer: Pour clarifier...

question: also known as (aka)...
answer: encore appelé...

question: another one / one more
answer: un(e) autre

question: to others (other people) + the other friends; Specify pronunciation.
answer: aux autres ('oh-zotr'; x makes liaison) + les autres amis ('lay-zot-rah-mee'; An entire syllable is dropped at the end of autres!)

question: the rest + the rest of my friends
answer: le reste OR la suite + le reste DE mes amis; Use suite if you are talking about a sequence. Suite has many different meanings/uses in french including following and sequel.

question: the rest of the cake + There is cake left over.
answer: le reste DU (de + le) gâteaux + Il reste des gâteux.; The verb RESTER can also be used to indicate food left overs

question: I don't know about the rest.
answer: Je ne sais pas POUR le reste.; Je ne sais pas is pronounced "shay-pah". The subject pronoun JE can be shortened to the sound "sh" (in front of any verb) and the vowel is dropped completely so you lose an entire syllable.

question: Absolutely!
answer: tout à fait;  NB: This is a fixed french expression that uses TOUT regardless of the number/gender of what it refers to.

question: Absolutely not!
answer: pas DU tout! (literally: not at all) OR Absolument pas! OR Ça va pas non. OR Surtout pas.; Ça va pas no is very idiomatic. It is spoken in an understated way but the meaning is something like 'you must be crazy'.; PAS is an adjective (not an adverb) in this case. So we do not generalize the object. DU tout remains instead of changing to DE tout.

question: What are the four forms of 'all'. Specify pronounciation.
answer: tout ('too' sing masc) + toute ('toot' sing fem) + tous ('too' pl masc) + toutes ('toot' pl fem); For pronunciation you really only need to know if you are in a masculine 'too' or feminine 'toot' situation.

question: When is TOUS pronounced 'toos'?
answer: only when there is no word that follows it. e.g. Bonjour tous! the S is pronounced. e.g. Tous les chats. The S is not pronounced because other words follow.

question: everyone
answer: TOUT le monde; It also means everybody.; Use TOUT because le monde is masculine singular. You should also use the singular form of a verb when tout le monde is the subject.

question: everything
answer: tout (generally); If it is unclear exactly what things you are referencing then defer to the singular masculine form (TOUT). This means you use the singular form of a verb when TOUT is the subject.; But if you are referring to some group of things already mentioned than you need to select from tout/toute/tous/toutes depending on the number and gender of the 'everything'.

question: Everything is fine.
answer: TOUT va bien.; Use the masculine singular version (tout) when you mean everything in general. This also requires that we use the singular form of a verb (va not vont).

question: everything in moderation
answer: tout avec moderation; Use TOUT (masculine singular) when you mean everything in the general sense.

question: all of France
answer: TOUTE le France; Use TOUTE because France is singular and feminine

question: all the men + all the people
answer: TOUS les hommes (pl masc) + TOUTES les personnes (pl fem)

question: we all
answer: nous TOUS (masc pl)... unless all of the people are women: nous TOUTES (fem pl)

question: the luggage... everything follows.
answer: les bagages (pl masc)... TOUS suivent.; Use tout/toute/TOUS/toutes as a noun to represent 'everything'. Choose tous because it references a noun that is plural masculine.

question: the suitcases... everything follows.
answer: les valises (pl fem)... TOUTES suivent.; Use tout/toute/tous/TOUTES as a noun to represent 'everything'. Choose toutes because it references a noun that is plural feminine.

question: He is all/completely alone.
answer: Il est TOUT seaul.; 'all' is an adverb that modifies a masculine singular adjective (seul). So we select TOUT.; NB: We always use TOUT as an adverb in the masculine cases regardless singular/plural and regardless of what letter the adjective (that is modifies starts with).

question: She is completely content.
answer: Elle est TOUTE contente.; 'completely' is an adverb that modifies a feminine singular adjective (contente). Select TOUTE in this case.; NB: If the adjective being modified starts with a vowel or silent H then change TOUTE to TOUT.

question: She is entirely/completely emotional.
answer: Elle est TOUT émue.; 'entirely/completely' is an adverb that modifies a feminine singular adjective (émue). Normally we would select TOUTE for that case. But émue starts with a vowel so we use TOUT instead.

question: She is completely/totally honest.
answer: Elle est TOUTE honnête.; 'completely/totally' is an adverb that modifies a feminine singular adjective (honnête). The H is honnête is NOT silent - it is aspirated. So we do not change from TOUTE to TOUT.

question: The men are completely astonished.
answer: Les hommes sont TOUT étonnés.; 'completely' is an adverb that modifies a masculine plural adjective (étonnes).; NB: We always use TOUT as an adverb in the masculine cases regardless of singular/plural and regardless of what letter the adjective (that is modifies starts with).

question: The women are completely alone.
answer: Les femmes sont TOUTE seules.; 'completely' is an adverb that modifies a feminine plural adjective (seules). Select TOUTES in this case.; NB: If the adjective being modified starts with a vowel or silent H then change TOUTES to TOUT.

question: The women are completely happy.
answer: Les femmes sont TOUT heureuses.; 'completely' is an adverb that modifies a feminine plural adjective (heureuses). Normally we would select TOUTES for that case. But heureuses starts with a silent H so we use TOUT instead.

question: You are my everything.
answer: Tu es mon TOUT.; 'all' is used as a stand-alone noun here. In that case we use TOUT when singular and TOUTS when plural (regardless of gender - which is ambiguous).

question: These are the wholes that we want to divide.
answer: Ce sont des TOUTS que nous voulons diviser.; 'all' is used as a stand-alone noun here. In that case we use TOUT when singular and TOUTS when plural (regardless of gender - which is ambiguous).

question: That's all.
answer: C'est TOUT. ('too'); 'all' is being used as a pronoun here - gender ambigous. The pronoun stands for something that is singular so we select TOUT.

question: They (all men) are at the store.
answer: TOUS sont au magasin.; 'all' is being used as a pronoun here. It stands for something that is masculine plural so we select TOUS.

question: They (all women) are at the party.
answer: TOUTES sont à la fête.; 'all' is bieng used as a pronoun here. It stands for something that is feminine plural so select TOUTES.

question: all of us + all of them (men) + all of them (women)
answer: nous tous + eux tous + elles toutes; The plural pronouns of 'all' (tous + toutes) are often used with tonique pronoms.

question: every man / all men
answer: tout homme or chaque homme; This is idiomatic french. Homme is singular (not like men in english). Every/all is being used as an adjective. Select TOUT because the noun it modifies (homme) is masculine singular.

question: every day + every night
answer: tous les jours + tous les soirs (literally: all days/nights); Use TOUS because 'every' is an adjective and the nouns it modifies are masculine plural.

question: I went out every day (in a week). + I went out all week long.
answer: Je sortais TOUS les jours. + Je suis sortie TOUTE la semaine.; The first statement is habitual so use imparfait. Each of the days is a whole day. You are talking about a frequency (more than a duration) so use JOUR instead of JOURNÉE.; The second statement is not habitual (even though it means the same thing). So use passé composé. The week is the duration within which you went out.

question: every Monday
