answer: La maison est PIRE (fem sing) que la appartement.; Use pire(s) - instead of plus mal - because 'worse' is an adjective describing the noun 'the house'.; pire/pires are both pronounced 'peer'.

question: The cats are worse than the dogs.
answer: Les chats sont PIRES (masc plural) que les chiens.; Use pire(s) - instead of plus mal - because 'worse' is an adjective describing the noun 'the cats'.; pire/pires are both pronounced 'peer'.

question: The houses are worse than the apartments.
answer: Les maisons sont PIRES (fem sing) que les appartement.; Use pire(s) - instead of plus mal - because 'worse' is an adjective describing the noun 'the houses'.; pire/pires are both pronounced 'peer'.

question: Explain the two words that mean: worst
answer: Use the same adverb or adjective that you would choose for 'worse'. And you must add an article (le/la/les) because 'the worst' is always a noun.; The two options: 1) LE PLUS MAL when you are describing someone/thing that is the worst at doing some verb. Adverbs do not adapt (in number and gender) to the verb. It is the opposite of le mieux (the best). 2) LE/LA/LES PIRE(S) are adjectives used to describe a noun - when some thing is 'the worst' of the group. Adjectives must adapt (in number and gender) to the noun they describe. These are the opposites of le meilleur / la meilleure / les meilleurs / les meilleures.

question: In addition to le pire / la pire / les pires... what is another way to express 'the worst'?
answer: le PLUS mauvais / la PLUS mauvaise / les PLUS mauvais(es) can be used when 'the worst' references a noun. e.g. La maison est la pire (fem sing). = La maison est la PLUS mauvaise (fem sing).

question: Chloé sings the worst.
answer: Chloé chante LE PLUS MAL.; Use le plus mal (instead of le/la/les pire(s)) because 'worst' refers to the verb 'sings'. Le plus mal does not need to agree (in number and gender) with a noun.

question: Simone and Camille sing the worst.
answer: Simone et Camille chantent LE PLUS MAL.; Use le plus mal (instead of le/la/les pire(s)) because 'worst' refers to the verb 'sing'. Le plus mal does not need to agree (in number and gender) with a noun.

question: The banana is the worst. + The tea is the worst.
answer: La banane est la pire (fem sing). + Le thé est le pire (masc sing.); Use le/la/les pire(s) because 'worst' references a noun instead of an action.

question: The tomatoes are the worst. + The lemons are the worst.
answer: Les tomates sont les pires (fem plural). + Les citrons sont les pires (masc plural).; Use le/la/les pire(s) because 'worst' references a noun instead of an action.

question: conjugate 'to be'
answer: être: je suis + tu es ('ay') + il/elle/on est ('ay') + nous sommes + vous êtes ('vooz-eht')+ ils/elles sont ('ssson')

question: When is est (conjugated 'to be') pronounced as 'ayt' instead of 'ay'?
answer: when the adjective following it starts with a vowel; e.g. Ils est intelligente; If the t in est was not pronounced is would be two vowels together and that is not how french is spoken; But otherwise the t at the end of est is never pronounced.

question: When is et (and) pronounced as 'ayt' instead of 'ay'?
answer: Never. Never make the t sound - even when the next word starts with a vowel; e.g. Elle est grande et intelligente - the pronounciation of et does not change.

question: conjugate 'to have'
answer: avoir: j'ai + tu as + il/elle/on a + nous avons + vous avez + ils/elles ont

question: conjugate 'to do'
answer: faire: je fais + tu fais + il/elle/on fait + nous faisons + vous faites + il/elles font

question: What is the difference between FAIRE and SE FAIRE?
answer: faire: to do + se faire: to get done; Making the verb reflexive (in this case) is a way to emphasize the verb or to describe pain (e.g. Mes genoux me font mal. = My knees are hurting me.).

question: What is the radical of a verb?
answer: The radical is the base of a verb - it generally does not change as the verb is conjugated.; NB: For group 1 (-er) and group 2 (-ir) verbs the radical is the part of the infinitive minus ER and IR.; Conjugation for group 3 verbs is more difficult. Some of those verbs have multiple radicals. e.g. ALLER uses the radicals: all (nous allons) + v (je vais) + ir (nous irons)

question: How do you conjugate group 1 verbs (regular -ER verbs) in present tense?
answer: endings: je -e (only pronouce the radical) + tu -es (silent) + il/elle/on -e (silent) + nous -ons (pronounced like nasal 'on') + vous -ez (pronounced like 'ay') + ils/elles -ent (-ent is ALWAYS silent in verbs but it forces the pronunciation of the previous letter)

question: What is the intonation on the conjugated forms for first person singular (je)?
answer: the intonation is always downward and shortened; e.g. je travaille sounds like 'ju tru-vay' not 'ju trav-a-ye'.

question: How do you pronounce the ending for the nous form of -ER verbs?
answer: the ending for nous is -ons ('ohn' very nasal without much of an 'n' sound on the end); this is the same sound as the on in il/elle/on ..when we use the casual form of 'we' when speaking

question: What is the only verb ending in -ER that is totally irregular?
answer: aller (to go)

question: What are some variations or small irregularities that occur when conjugating -ER verbs and which forms to they impact? (disregard the totally irregular verb ALLER)
answer: 1) In some cases there is an accent change in the second syllable when conjugating -ER verbs au présent (e.g. acheter + préférer); 2) For -YER verbs the Y can stay a Y or it can change to I before adding the endings. Either spelling is 100% correct but the pronunciations are slightly different. If we keep the Y in the spelling then the 'y' sound is heard more in the pronunciation.; When there are irregularities in conjugating -ER verbs au présent all forms are impacted EXCEPT nous and vous forms - those two forms are conjugated exactly as you would expect for -ER verbs.

question: How do you conjugate group 2 verbs (regular -ir verbs) in present tense?
answer: endings: je -is ('ee') + tu -is ('ee') + il/elle/on -it ('ee') + nous -issons ('ee-soh'; nasal and pouty) + vous -issez ('ee-say') + ils/elles -issent ('ees' -ent is ALWAYS silent in verbs but it forces the pronunciation of the previous consonant); NB: Sortir is not a regular -IR verb.

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to finish'.
answer: finir (regular -ir verb): je finis + tu finis + il/elle/on finit + nous finissons + vous finissez + ils/elles finissent ('fi-nees'; The double S changes the sound of the I and -ent is always silent on verbs.)

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to choose'
answer: choisir (regular -ir verb): je choisis + tu choisis + il/elle/on choisit + nous choisissons ('shwa-Zee-Sohn'; The single S makes a Z sound. The double S makes a Z sound because in between vowels.) + vous choisissez ('shwa-See-Say') + ils/elles choisissent; Alternative: OPTER

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to grow up'
answer: grandir (regular -ir verb): je grandis + tu grandis + il/elle/on grandit + nous grandissons + vous grandissez + ils/elles grandissent ('gran-dees'; -ent is silent on verbs); NB: Avoid confusion with GROSSIR whish means to put on weight.

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to see'.
answer: voir: je vois ('vwa') + tu vois + il voit + nous voyons + vous voyez + ils voient

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to receive'.
answer: recevoir; past participle: reçu; NB: This is VOIR with a prefix. So the conjugation of RECEVOIR (using radical REÇ) mirrors the conjugation of VOIR (using radical V). Except the nous and vous forms use radical REC (without cedille). je reçois + tu reçois + il reçoit + nous recevons + vous recevez + ils reçoivent

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to like'.
answer: aimer: j'aime + tu aimes + il/elle/on aime + nous aimons + vous aimez + ile/elles aiment

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to want'.
answer: vouloir: je veux ('voo' at the top of the mouth - NOT the deep U sound) + tu veux ('voo') + il/elle/on veut ('voo') + nous voulons ('voo-lon') + vous voulez ('voo-lay') + ils/elle veulent ('vuhl'; the -ent is not pronounced in verbs); NB: veux and veut are NOT pronounced 'voo'; VOUS - the subject pronoun - is pronounced 'voo'; VEUX and VEUT are pronounced like something between 'vuh' and 'voo' (same as PEUX) so that it is possible to distinguish them from VOUS; past participle: voulu

question: How do you pronounce... I want + I go + I see?
answer: Je veux ('voo' but higher in the mouth similar to 'vuh') + Je vais ('vay') + Je vois ('vwa')

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to go'.
answer: aller: je vais + tu va + il/elle/on va + nous allons + vous allez +ils/elles vont

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to come'.
answer: venir: je vien ('vyon') + tu viens ('vyon') + il/elle/on vient ('vyon') + nous venons ('vo-non') + vous venez ('ve-nay') + ils/elles viennent ('vyen'; NB: The double N changes the sound of the vowel that precedes the pair. 'vy' becomes 'vyeh'.)

question: Conjugate the verb for 'to do' / 'to make' (something).
answer: faire: je fais ('fay') + tu fais ('fay') + il/elle/on fait ('fay') + nous faisons + vous faites + ils/elles font ('fon')

question: to rejuvinate (e.g. a building or face) + rejuvitated
answer: refaire + refait(e)

question: to refresh (e.g. a building or face) + refreshed
answer: rafraîcher + rafraîchi(e)

question: to renovate (a building or face) + renovated
answer: rénover + rénové(e)

question: the insulation (in a building)
answer: la isolation; bien/mal isolé(e) = well/poorly insulated; Watch out because this is a faux-ami.

question: Idiomatic way to say: You sound like X. (e.g. my mother + a politician)
answer: On croirait entendre X.; Use On (not Tu/Vous). This is a way to make a joke / rib someone.

question: to make someone feel a certain way / to make something change
answer: RENDRE; Meanings include: to render + to produce some effect; RENDRE is also used to mean 'to pay' when we express: to pay a visit to someone + to pay hommage to someone; We do not use FAIRE for these scenarios in french.

question: He makes me sick.
answer: Il me rend malade. = He makes me sick.; RENDRE = to produce some effect; Other examples where RENDRE is the correct verb: They make me tired + confused + crazy + nervous.

question: That accent makes/drives me crazy.
answer: Cet accent me rend fou/folle (m/f).; RENDRE = to produce some effect

question: Artists make life better.
answer: Des artistes rendent la vie meilleure.; RENDRE = to produce some effect

question: The sun makes me tired.
answer: There are two ways to express this: 1) Using RENDRE: Le soleil me rend fatigué(e). 2) Using the verb FATIGUER (to fatigue) in a reflexive way: Le soleil me fatigue.

question: It makes me sad.
answer: Ça me rend triste.; RENDRE = to produce some effect

question: It makes me feel good.
answer: Ça me fait du bien.; This is the idiomatic to express the sentiment. Do not use SENTIR in this case.; Alternative: Ça me rend heureuse.

question: It feels good to be alone.
answer: Ça fait du bien d'être seul(e).; Ça fait du bien de + infinitive = It feels good to...

question: It makes me think.
answer: Ça me fait réfléchir.; Generally RÉFLÉCHIR is not used reflexively. And that is the case here. The pronom ME refers to the verb FAIRE as in 'it makes me... do something'.

question: conjugate 'to take'
answer: prendre is irregular; je prends ('pruh') + tu prends ('pruh') + il/elle/on prend ('pruh') + nous prenons ('pruh-non' ...nasal ending)+ vous prenez ('pruh-nay') + ils/els prennent ('prehn'); NB: The double N in prennent changes the sound of the first syllable.; past participle: pris

question: to make a decision
answer: prendre une décision; Use prendre - not faire - in this case.

question: to decide + to decide to do something
answer: décider is the infinitive; past participle: décidé; I decide to do something = Je décide + DE + INFINITIVE VERB. e.g. I decide to try. = Je décide d'essayer.; Generally use DE to connect two verbs (conjugated verb + DE + infinitive verb). In some specific cases we use À instead of DE.

question: You decide to run.
answer: Tu décide DE courir.; Generally use DE to connect two verbs. In some specific cases we use À instead of DE.

question: She told me to wait.
answer: Elle m'a dit D'attendre.; Generally use DE to connect two verbs. In some specific cases we use À instead of DE.

question: I agree to go.
answer: J'accepter DE aller.; accepter = agree to;Generally use DE to connect two verbs. In some specific cases we use À instead of DE.

question: We ask to leave.
answer: On demande DE partir.; Generally use DE to connect two verbs. In some specific cases we use À instead of DE.

question: to order (food)
answer: commander; NB: When you are actually ordering food you use PRENDRE e.g. Je prends des fraises. = I'll take some strawberries. But the verb that describes the action of ordering is COMMANDER - not PRENDRE.

question: to get back on the road
answer: REprendre la route; Use the verb prendre. Emphasize the repetitiveness of the action by adding RE prefix.

question: to keep + to save
answer: garder (to keep) + sauver (to save)

question: conjugate 'to be able to'; often used as a helper verb (e.g. I can wait. You can work.)
answer: pouvoir: je peux ('juh pooh') + tu peux ('pooh') + il/elle/on peut ('pooh') + nous pouvons ('pooh-von') + vous pouvez ('pooh-vay') + ils/elles peuvent ('puhv'; the -ent is NOT pronounced in verbs)

question: conjugate 'to have to' / 'must' (do something)
answer: devoir followed by infinitive of action verb: je dois X ('dwa') + tu dois X ('dwa') + il/elle/on doit X ('dwa') + nous devons X ('duh-von') + vous devez X ('duh-vay') + ils/elles doivent X ('dwav')

question: I must read.
answer: Je dois ('dwa') lire.; Use the verb devoir and add the infinitive form of whatever you must do (e.g. lire).

question: I must go to the store.
answer: Je dois aller au magasin.;  Use the verb devoir and add the infinitive form of whatever you must do (e.g. aller).

question: How do you pronounce: They must eat.?
answer: Ils doivent manger. ('eel-dwa-manj-ay'); remember -ent is often dropped when pronouncing the third person plural

question: to need (something)
answer: avoir besoin DE (quelque chose); NB: Use avoir besoin DE... when a thing/object is needed. If you need to do something - then use the verb devoir + INFINITIVE instead.

question: I need the coffee. + You need the table.
answer: J'ai besoin du café (de + le = du). + Tu as besoin de la table.; NB: Use avoir besoin DE... when a thing/object is needed.

question: We need a boat. + She needs a dress.
answer: On a besoin d'un bateau. + Elle a besoin d'une robe.; NB: Use avoir besoin DE... when a thing/object is needed.

question: He needs privacy.
answer: Il a besoin d'intimité.

question: I would need X.
answer: J'aurais besoin X.; Use conditionnel version of AVOIR BESOIN.

question: What is the difference between DEVOIR and AVOIR besoin?
answer: Sometimes they can be used interchangeably but generally DEVOIR preceeds a verb and AVOIR BESOIN precedes a noun.; If you use DEVOIR followed by a noun then it means to owe - not to need.

question: I owe you a euro.
answer: Je te dois un euro.

question: Which three verbs are only conjugated in the 3rd person singular (il/elle)?
answer: falloir (to be required) + pleuvoir (to rain) + valoir (to be worth)

question: conjugate 'to know' (some information) AND give the past participle.
answer: savoir; past participle: su; conjugation: je sais + tu sais + il/elle/on sait + nous nous + vous savons + ils/els savent ('sav')

question: How do you pronounce: They know the answer.
answer: Ils savent ("ee-sahv") la réponse.; In conversation the subject pronouns IL and ILS are shortened to sound like "ee".

question: How do you pronounce: He knows the answer.
answer: Il sais ("ee-say") la réponse.; In conversation the subject pronouns IL and ILS are shortened to sound like "ee".

question: to know (to be familiar with)
answer: connaître (+ noun); Do not use DE or AVEC. e.g. Elle connaît la ville. (She knows - is familiar with - the city.); connaître can mean to know a someone personally or to know OF that person.

question: I didn't know that.
answer: Je ne le connaissais/savais pas.; Use imparfait because you didn't know it before but now you do know it - something that was true in the past but is different now and it describes the context (not a discreet action)

question: If I didn't already know Frida...
answer: Si je ne connaissais pas déjà Frida...; Both PAS and DÉJÀ are necessary adverbs.; Use imparfait because you are describing the context (not a discreet action).; NB: When you use CONNAÎTRE to describe knowing a person it means that you actually knew the person (not just knowing 'of them'). To be more clear you should say: Si je ne connaissais pas déjà l'art de Frida...

question: I haven't seen/heard of that (before).
answer: Je n'ai jamais entendu parler de ça.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.; In this case passé composé is the best choic in french. Though in English we use plus que parfait (had seen/heard).; The 'before/already' is implied in french. We do not need to add 'déja' for this specific expression.

question: I haven't seen her in a long time. + I hadn't seen her in a long time (e.g. before we met last night).
answer: Je l'ai pas vu longtemps. (passé composé) + Je ne l'avais pas vu longtemps. (plus que parfait)

question: I studied at this school before.
answer: J'ai déja étudié à cette école avant.; Use DÉJA to express 'already'. It modifies the verb so it is placed between the auxiliary and the past participle in passé composé.

question: I went to the store already. + I already went there.
answer: Je suis déjà allé(e) au magasin. + J'y suis déja allé(e).; Passé composé is a good choice in this case because the statement is straightforward in the past. The speaker is not using past perfect (had been). Perfect means 'completed' when dealing with verb tenses.; Déja should fall between the two parts of the verb in both cases in french.; Déja is the word to use for a direct translation of 'already' or for when we use the word before to mean already. e.g. I went to the store (before).

question: I have seen it before. / I have already seen it.
answer: Je l'ai déja vu.; In this case always use passé composé and déja (the adverb) is placed between the auxiliary and past participle.

question: Were you (informal) in the Netherlands? + Were you there?
answer: Est-ce que tu as été aux Pays-Bas ('pay-ee-bah')? + Est-ce que tu Y as été?; Use pronom Y to reference a location.; Passé composé is a good choice in this case because the question is straightforward in the past. The speaker is not using past perfect (had been).

question: Were you (informal) in the Netherlands before/already? + Were you there before/already?
answer: Est-ce que tu as DÉJA été aux Pays-Bas? + Est-ce que tu Y as DÉJA été?; Déja always lies between the two parts of the verb.; Déja is the word to use for 'already' or for 'before' in situations where it can be replaced with 'already'.

question: Have you gone/been to Germany before/already?
answer: Est-ce que tu étais DÉJA allé(e) en Allemagne?; In this case ALLER and plus que parfait are the best choices in french.; Déja is the word to use for 'already' or for 'before' in situations where it can be replaced with 'already'. Déja always lies between the two parts of the verb.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.

question: Have you gone/been there before/already?
answer: Est-ce que tu Y étais DÉJA allé(e)?; Use pronom Y to reference a location.

question: Did you go there?
answer: Two options: 1) Est-ce que tu y est allé(e)? 2) Y est-tu allé(e)?

question: conjugate 'to hate'
answer: détester: je déteste + tu détestes + il/elle/on déteste + nous détestons + vous détestez + ils/els détestent

question: to hate eating
answer: détester manger; No preposition is required after détester to join with another verb. Just conjugate the first verb.

question: to hate someone
answer: haïr quelqu'un

question: conjugate 'to appreciate'
answer: apprécier: j'apprécie + tu apprécies + il/elle/on apprécie + nous apprécions + vous appréciez + ils/elles apprécient

question: How do you remember which verb tenses use a radical and which tenses use the entire infinitive as their base (before adding the ending for each form)?
answer: Use a radical - not necessarily the same one - in the past and present (passé composé + imparfait + présent). Use the full infinitive - or variation on the infinitive - in the future (futur proche + futur simple + conditionnel).; NB: The endings for the imparfait ('past-like') and conditionnel ('future-like') are exactly the same BUT their bases are different.

question: How do you remember which verb radical to use in imparfait vs futur simple/conditionnel?
answer: There is no hard rule. Generally for irregular verbs... the radical in the past tenses does NOT have an R at the end. But the radical in the future tenses does have an R at the end.; e.g. DEVOIR... je DEVais (imparfait) je DEVRais (conditionnel); e.g. POUVOIR... je POUVais (imparfait) je POURRais (conditionnel); e.g. AVOIR... j'AVais (imparfait) j'AURais (conditionnel); e.g. ALLER... j'ALLais (imparfait) j'IRais (conditionnel)

question: I go to the office at 8am.
answer: Je vais au bureau à 8 heures.

question: that last week / the previous week
answer: la semaine dernière / la semaine précédente; you could make the latter plural: les semaines précedentes - the previous weeks; NB: dernier/dernière (m/f): When placed before the noun it means the last in a series but when placed after the noun it means the previous one.

question: the last (of something) / the new (of something)
answer: la dernier X / la nouveau X; nouveau/nouvelle is one of the adjectives that comes before the noun it modifies.

question: in the last lesson
answer: au dernier cours; NB: dernier/dernière (m/f)

question: a lesson
answer: une leçon / un cours (more like 'a class')

question: I have french lessons every Sunday online.
answer: J'ai des cours de français tous les dimanches en ligne.

question: We watch football (soccer). / We watch a game of football.
answer: On regarde DU foot. / On regarde un match de foot.; plural of match = matchs

question: I wanted to go to more (football) matches.
answer: Je voulais aller à plus de matchs.; Use imparfait of VOULOIR (instead of passé composé) because it is a state of being and whatever you wanted in the past is different from what you want at this moment. Also it is much more polite to express this with imparfait - just as we would use conditionnel (voudrais) to express what we want in the present.

question: a game (like a boardgame)
answer: un jeu; pronounced just like the word for I (je)

question: a game piece (like a figure in chess)
answer: le pion; This can also refer to a guard or boarding school master: le pion / la pionne

question: a video game
answer: un jeu video; NB: This is called e-sport when done competitively.

question: the olympic games
answer: les jeux olympiques ('lay-zhoo-Zo-lim-peek'); There is a Z liaison between jeux and olympiques.; Often people abbreviate: J.O. ('zshee-oh' - like 'geo').

question: a ball
answer: It depends on what kind of ball: 1) une balle: ball for tennis + golf + cricket  2) un ballon: for football + rugby + basketball 3) une boule: something physically shaped like a ball

question: a bubble
answer: une bulle

question: a team + the women's/men's team
answer: un équipe + l'equipe féminin/masculin

question: the opposing team
answer: l'équipe adverse

question: the stadium
answer: le stade

question: a field (where a sport is played)
answer: un terrain is the most generic way to refer to this; Alternative: une pelouse (= a lawn) is used for football

question: to play with words / to play with fire
answer: You can make a literal translation in these cases. JOUER + AVEC.; jouer avec les mots / jouer avec le feu

question: What are the three major ways to express doing some activity?
answer: 1) FAIRE + DU / DE LA / DES / D' + some activity  2) JOUER + AU / À LA / AUX  + game/sport 3) JOUER + DU / DE LA / DES / D' + music/musical instrument; à + le = au; à + les = aux; de + le = du; de + les = des; d' is used when the following word starts with a vowel

question: to play sports + to play football (soccer)
answer: faire du sport + jouer au foot OR faire du foot; With football you can use either JOUER or FAIRE.

question: I play tennis.
answer: Je joue ('zshoo') au tennis.; JOUER + À because tennis is a sport/game.; Tennis is masculine singular. à + le = AU.; The present tense conjugations of jouer (e.g. je joue) have only one syllable - despite the multiple vowels - and they sound exactly the same as the word for cheek (une joue); NB: Technically you can use DE with tennis as well: Je fais DU tennis.

question: You play pétanque.
answer: Tu joues ('zshoo') à la pétanque.; JOUER + À because pétanque is a sport/game.; Pétangue is feminine singular so à la remains À LA.

question: We play chess.
answer: Nous jouons ('zshoo-ohn'; pronounced almost as a single syllable) aux échecs.; JOUER + À because chess is a sport/game.; Échecs is plural. à + les = AUX.

question: They play cards. + They play poker.
answer: Ils jouent ('zshoo') aux cartes. + Ils jouent au Poker ('poe-kehR'; The R is pronounced in this case because it is not a french word.); JOUER + À because cards is a sport/game.; Cartes is plural. à + les = AUX.

question: He plays piano.
answer: Il joue ('zshoo') du piano.; JOUER + DE because we are talking about music/musical instrument.; Piano is masculine singular. de + le = du

question: She took piano lessons (e.g. as a kid).
answer: Elle prenait des leçons de piano.; Use imparfait because this is part of a routine in the past.; Alternative: Elle avait des leçons de piano.

question: His friend plays the flute.
answer: Son ami joue ('zshoo') de la flûte.; JOUER + DE because we are talking about music/musical instrument.; Flûte is feminine singular.

question: She plays the drums / the guitar.
answer: Elle joue ('zshoo') de la batterie / de la guitare.; JOUER + DE because we are talking about music/musical instrument.; Drums and guitar are both feminine singular in french.

question: I do not know how to play the violin.
answer: Je ne se pas faire du violin.; Use SAVOIR (not connaître) to talk about knowing how to play an instrument.

question: They play hip-hop music.
answer: Ils font de la musique hip-hop.; We do not use the verb JOUER in this case. Use FAIRE + DE instead.; La musique is feminine singular.

question: My friends played music (with instruments); Specify the pronunciation.
answer: Mes amis ont ('a-mee-ont'; NO liaison) fait de la musique.; Never make a liaison between a subject (that is not a pronoun) and its verb. If the subject is a pronoun then you can make the liaison.; We do not use the verb JOUER in this case. Use faire de la musique instead.

question: We played some games.
answer: On a joué à quelques jeux.; Use quelqueS because games is plural.

question: He played soccer.
answer: Il jouait au football.; Use imparfait to describe someone's hobby in the past.

question: He plays with a doll.
answer: Il joue à la poupée.; Playing with a toy is expressed like playing a game: JOUER + À + article + noun.

question: I dance. + I ski.
answer: Je fais DE LA danse. + Je fais DU ski.; Use FAIRE + DE.; La dance is feminine singular. Le ski is masculine singular. de + le = du.

question: He rides a bike.
answer: Il fait du vélo.; Use FAIRE + DE. Le vélo is masculine singular. de + le = du.

question: She rides horses.
answer: Elle fait de l'équitation.; Use FAIRE + DE. l'équitation makes the contraction because it starts with a vowel.

question: to do gymnastics + to do yoga
answer: faire de la gymnastique + faire du yoga; Use FAIRE + DE. DE + LE = DU.

question: to go hiking + to go climbing
answer: faire de la randonnée (feminine) + faire de l'escalade (feminine)

question: I go to the gym.
answer: Je vais à la salle du sport.; NB: un gymnase = a place where athletes perform gymnastics

question: to exercise + to do cardio
answer: faire de l'exercice + faire du cardio; Alternatives: pour endurance (for endurance) / rester en forme (to stay in shape)

question: Idiomatic way to say: He did cheerleading after school.
answer: Il faisait l'entrainement de cheerleading après être allé à l'école.; Use imparfait because it is describing a daily routine in the past.

question: to listen to the music
answer: ècouter de la musique; remember to always use a preposition and an article (DE LA) after écouter

question: a guitar + a drum + a bass
answer: une guitare + un tambour + une basse

question: a harp + a trumpet + a violin
answer: une harpe + une trompette + un violon

question: to look after someone
answer: s'occuper de

question: We stay here.
answer: On reste ici.

question: a household
answer: un ménage; This can mean a couple or any group of people that live together.

question: to browse / to go bargain hunting
answer: chiner; a bargain-hunter = chineur/euse; CHINER = to browse / to go bargain-hunting

question: to go shopping (for luxury clothing or goods)
answer: faire du shopping; This is not running errands - it's specifically for a luxurious experience.

question: to go shopping (for daily food + home goods/furniture + clothing + gifts)
answer: faire les courses; This means running errands

question: Use for housework. + Do not use for housework.
answer: Utilisez pour faire le ménage. + N'utilisez pas pour faire le ménage.

question: the task
answer: la tâche

question: the chores + to share the chores
answer: les tâches ménagéres + partager des tâches

question: to share (e.g. a plate)
answer: partager

question: The responsbility must be shared.
answer: La responsibilité doit être partagée (feminine because subject is singular feminine).

question: to split a bill 50/50
answer: faire moitié moitié OR faire moit moit (both Ts are pronounced; more casual) OR faire 50/50

question: to do housework + to tidy up
answer: faire le ménage + ranger; Use RANGER to mean put things back in their place. Use ARRANGER to mean re-arrange furniture / setup a room.; e.g. ranger des affaires = to get the affairs in order

question: to put together the furniture + to arrange the furniture
answer: MONTER/constuire les meubles + AMÉNAGE (or ARRANGER) les meubles/la maison; SURMONTER can mean 'to mount' or 'to overcome'.; AMÉNAGER can also mean to 'fit out' a space + landscape a terrain + to 'put in' an installation + to develop a neighborhood.

question: to disassemble the furniture
answer: démonter les meubles; MONTER = to assemble (among other things)

question: to open + to cover
answer: ouvrir + couvrir; COUVRIR is typically conjugated similar to OUVRIR.; NB: ROUVRIR (to open again) and RECOUVRIR (to cover again) are often used to simply mean 'to open' or 'to cover'. It is common in french to add R- or RE- prefix to a verb to emphasize it or adjust the meaning. This does not necessarily mean that the verb is performed again.

question: to discover + to reveal
answer: découvrir + révéler; Conjugation is similar to OUVRIR (e.g. past participle: découvert).;

question: the discovery
answer: la découverte

question: to burry + to escavate/uncover
answer: enterrer + deterrer

question: to wrap + to unwrap
answer: emballer + déballer; This only works for packaging or a gift. It does not work for packing/unpacking luggage.

question: arranged well (like for a room) + disorganized
answer: bien rangé(e) / bien organisé(e) + dérangé(e) / désorganisé(e); NB: SE DÉRANGER = to be bothered by something

question: My things are totally arranged in their place
answer: Mes affaires sont toutes bien rangées à leurs places.

question: messy
answer: désordonné(e) OR en désordre; the disorder = le désordre

question: organized (like for a person)
answer: organisé(e)

question: to have a sense of organization (in general) + to have a sense of the organization (the heirarchy of a specific company)
answer: avoir un sens ('sohnS'; S is pronounced) d'organisation + avoir le sens de l'organisation

question: well-situated / in a good location
answer: bien situé(e)

question: well-decorated + well-equipped
answer: bien décoré(e) + bien equipé(e)

question: to clean + the cleaning
answer: nettoyer + le nettoyage; NB: You cannot use 'le nettoyage' on its own. You must specify WHAT is being cleaned during the cleaning. e.g. Il y avait beaucoup de nettoyage À faire chez nous. = There was a lot of cleaning (happening) at our place.

question: to dry
answer: se sécher

question: dry + wet
answer: sec/sèche (m/f) + mouillé(e)

question: to do the laundry (to wash clothes) + to iron the clothes
answer: faire la lessive + repassage; s'occuper du linge = washing AND drying AND ironing clothes

question: to wash the dishes by hand + to wash the dishes in a dishwasher + to wash the dishes in a restaurant
answer: faire la viselle (means by hand) +  mettre dans le lave-vaisselle + faire la plonge (means professionally in a restaurant)

question: to eat without having to do dishes
answer: manger sans la vaisselle

question: to sweep
answer: ramoner; This is the word to use for cleaning a chimney.

question: sewing / tailoring
answer: la couture

question: to mend
answer: recoudre

question: to tinker (in order to repair something)
answer: bricoler

question: to do it yourself
answer: faire les choses soi-même

question: on itself
answer: en lui-même

question: a makeshift job / a do-it-yourself project
answer: le bricolage; e.g. Elle aime le bricolage = She likes doing DIY (activities).

question: to repair + recover
answer: réparer + récupérer; Fix is faux ami. fixer = to choose or to set (something)

question: to repaint (a room)
answer: repeindre

question: to develop (like a product or an argument or an economy)
answer: développer

question: to prefer
answer: préférer; 2 accent aigu!

question: How does préférer change as it is conjugated au présent?
answer: je préfère + tu préfères + il préfère + nous préférons + vous préférez + ils préfèrent; préférer is an -ER verb so the minor variations (changing accent aigu to accent grave) do not impact the nous and vous forms.

question: to return something (e.g. clothes to a store)
answer: retourner OR faire un retour; retourner is only used when you are returning some thing (a direct object) to a place that is different from where the speaker is currently located.; past participle: retourné(e) - retourner uses être in passé composé.; Do not use this when you are talking about the movement of a person. See REVENIR and RENTRER.

question: to return / to go back / to come back (when a person - not a thing - is returning)
answer: There are three verbs to choose from. 1) Revenir (RE + VENIR) is like 'come back' to a location that is the same as where the speaker is currently located.; 2) Rentrer means 'to go back home' wherever home is. It can refer to the actual home/apartment or a city/region.; 3) Retourner can be used similar to English. e.g. On y retournera pour Noël. = We will return there for Christmas.

question: If you could go back (in time)...
answer: Si tu pouvais revenir en arrière...

question: the feedback (like on a job)
answer: le retour; literally: the return or the return trip (from the verb RETOURNER)

question: I'm back.
answer: Je suis de retour.; Literally: I am returned.

question: to dine
answer: dîner

question: We picnic.
answer: On pique-nique. OR On fait un pique-nique.; le pique-nique = the picnic; pique-niquer = to picnic

question: to travel
answer: voyager

question: to concentrate + to concentrate on X
answer: concentrer + se concentrer sur X

question: to think
answer: penser; NB: When you use PENSER in the past you almost always use imparfait (instead of passé composé) because if you thought something in the past then it is likely that you think something different now.; past participle: pensé (regular -ER verb); Alternative: estimer = to estimate (in a loose way). This cannot be used to communicate an 'estimate'. It is a faux amis in that sense.

question: an estimate or quote (for repairs)
answer: un devis; Do not use estimation. That is a faux amis.

question: I am thinking about leaving tomorrow.
answer: Je pense partir demain.; No preposition is required after PENSER to join with another a verb. Just conjugate the first verb.

question: a thought
answer: une pensée

question: to consider (some option)
answer: envisager; Watch out because this verb is used differently in french. For example: it is a thing to consider = C'est une chose à prendre en compte.; à prendre en compte = to take into account

question: to become; Specify pronunciation.
answer: deVENIR ('duh-vuh-NEER'; take care to pronounce differently from DEVINER); The base is venir (to come). The conjugation in present tense is exactly the same.

question: to guess; Specify pronunciation.
answer: deVINER ('duh-VEE-NAY'; take care to pronound); Alternative: IMAGINER (same meaning as english)

question: a guess + a suggestion
answer: une supposition + une suggestion

question: I guessed it.
answer: Je l'ai deviné.

question: to wonder + to wander
answer: s'interroger + errer

question: to imagine + to re-imagine
answer: to imagine: IMAGINER; to re-imagine: REPENSER means to re-imagine or re-think something. REVISITER means to re-imagine or to re-work something (not to physically visit something again)

question: to suggest
answer: proposer (de); e.g. Je vous propose DE faire quelque chose. = I suggest to you to do something.

question: She suggests/proposes to teach French.
answer: Elle propose D'enseigner le français.

question: to believe; Conjugate it.
answer: croire; je crois ('kwa') + tu crois + il croit + nous croyons + vous croyez + ils croient; past participle: cru

question: I believe you.
answer: Je te crois. ('kwa')

question: to make (something) up
answer: inventer

question: to behave
answer: se comporter; le compartment = the behavior

question: to act (on something) + to act (in a play)
answer: agir + jouer/performer (literally: to play / to perform); NB: The verb ACTER exists but it not commonly used to describe actors.

question: to interact with (something)
answer: interagir avec (quelque chose); NB: an interaction = une interaction

question: to belong
answer: appartenir; This is conjugated similar to VENIR. e.g. j'appartiens + tu appartiens + ...; une appartenance = a belonging (e.g. l'appartenance ethnique = the ethnicity)

question: to pass by
answer: PASSER. Use être in passé composé because the verb is being used to indicate physical position.; PASSER can be used to indicate passing by something or spending time doing something. But it should not be used to talk about spending money.

question: to spend time
answer: PASSER using avoir in passé composé because the verb is not being used to indicate physical position in this case.; PASSER can be used to indicate passing by something or spending time doing something. But it should not be used to talk about spending money.

question: to spend money
answer: dépenser / débourser; Do not use PASSER for this meaning.

question: to buy + to pay
answer: acheter + payer ('pay-yay'; two Y sounds); When you pay any kind of bill (restaurant + doctors office + utility) use PAYER. It describes the one side of the transaction. ACHETER is only used to describe an exchange for a physical thing (e.g. buying clothes).

question: How does acheter change as it is conjugated au présent?
answer: j'achète + tu achètes + il achète + nous achetons + vous achetez + ils achètent; acheter is an -ER verb so the minor variations (adding accent grave è) do not impact the nous and vous forms.

question: to hold
answer: tenir

question: to exagerate
answer: exagérer

question: to summarize
answer: résumer

question: to write a summary/paragraph
answer: faire une rédaction

question: to draft (a piece of writing)
answer: faire un brouillon

question: I take notes.
answer: Je prends des notes.

question: I prepared a lot for the exam.
answer: Je me suis beaucoup préparé pour l'examen.; If you use PRÉPARER without a reflexive pronoun then it means to prepare a meal. You must use SE PRÉPARER to indicate that you are preparing yourself for some task. Using the reflexive form of the verb forces us to use ÊTRE as the auxiliary - instead of AVOIR.

question: How should I prepare for it?
answer: Comment est-ce que je dois ME préparer?; If you use PRÉPARER without a reflexive pronoun then it means to prepare a meal. You must use SE PRÉPARER to indicate that you are preparing yourself for some task.; In this case we are not using inversion so we add est-ce que to make the form correct. You could omit est-ce que but then it would be very familiar...using intonation.; NB: Using inversion instead is correct but - in this case - it is a little bizarre because it sounds so formal: Comment dois-je le préparer?

question: to immerse (oneself) in something
answer: s'immerger

question: You immerse yourself (informal) in French.
answer: Tu t'immerge DANS français.; The masculine version of a nationality is the short form for the language.

question: to fail + the failure
answer: échouer + l'échec; ÉCHOUER is the general verb for failure. RATER is the verb for failing an exam.

question: to take (an exam) + to retake (an exam)
answer: passer (does not mean 'to pass an exam' - just to take the exam) + repasser (to take it again)

question: to pass (an exam) + to fail (an exam)
answer: réussir + rater/echouer; Réussir literally means 'to succeed' but it is the correct verb to use for passing an exam.; Rater means to fail an exam but it is not the general verb for failing (échouer).

question: to cheat
answer: tricher

question: My grades are bad.
answer: Mes notes sont mauvaises.; une note is a grade on an exam

question: They did not succeed (in anything - not necessarily an exam).
answer: Ils n'ont pas réussi.; NB: Be careful when saying someone succeeded in the past tense. Without context this may mean to succeed sexually. Unfortunately it applies more strongly when you are describing the actions of woman vs the actions of a man.

question: I succeeded in answering (the questions).
answer: J'ai réussi À répondre.; RÉUSSIR triggers the preposition À.; NB: Because there is an accent aigu on the É there are two vowel sounds ('ray-oo-seer'). If there were no accent (reussir) then EU together would make a single vowel sound.

question: success
answer: succés ('sook-say')

question: She is successful.
answer: Elle a beaucoup de succés dans ses affaires.; This is a better way to express that someone succeeded at some effort (other than passing an exam). ...instead of using RÉUSSIR.

question: to help... to do something
answer: aider À; AIDER triggers À. e.g. Il m'aide à parler français. = He helps me to speak French.

question: educational
answer: éducatif / éducative (m/f)

question: a school
answer: une école

question: a nursery (where you take babies and toddlers) + a nursery school (ages 3 to 5)
answer: une crèche + une école maternelle

question: an elementary school (ages 6-10) + a middle school (ages 11-14)
answer: une école élémentaire + un collège

question: a high school (ages 15-18) + a university (ages 18+)
answer: un lycée ('lee-say') + une université; NB: une grande école = a university in the 'ivy league' of France;  grand(e): It means 'significant' when placed before the noun. It means 'grown/tall' when placed after the noun.

question: in primary school + in high school
answer: en primaire (spelled differently than the adjective for first) + en lycée; Do not use DANS for any of these.

question: a lecture hall / amphitheater
answer: un amphithéâtre

question: a degree (in education) + I received the degree.
answer: un diplôme + J'ai obtenu un diplôme.; Use OBTENIR (not recevoir) for getting/receiving a degree.

question: a graduation (the ceremony) + to graduate
answer: une remise de diplômes + faire un diplôme

question: the name of the exam that everyone in France takes to gain entrance to university
answer: le bac; This is the reference point for continued study. e.g. BAC + 3 = le license (a bachelor's degree)

question: a bachelor's degree in biochemistry
answer: une licence en bio-chemie; NB: a bachelor's degree in biochemical engineering = une licence en génie de bio-chemie; NB: In France a license/bachelors typically consumes 3 years and is referred to as BAC + 3.

question: a master's degree in business
answer: un master en affaires; NB: In France a masters typically consumes 2 years (after completion of license/bachelors) and is referred to as BAC + 5.; Je suis titulaire d'un Master en affaires. = I have an MBA.

question: a doctorate degree in marketing
answer: un doctorat en marketing; NB: In France a doctorate typically consumes 3 years (after completion of masters) and is referred to as BAC + 8.

question: idiomatic way to say: He attended X university.
answer: Il est allé(e) à l'université du X.; e.g. Il est allé à l'université du Harvard.

question: formal job training that does not include a diploma
answer: une formation

question: It opens doors.
answer: Ça ouvre des portes.; The same saying in English and French.

question: a subject (in school)
answer: une matière

question: in this field (of work)
answer: dans ce milieu OR dans cette branche (feminine; same as for a tree); le milieu literally translates to 'middle' but it is commonly used to mean something like field or area or place

question: the work
answer: le travail; Alternative: les liverables = the work products

question: a job
answer: un poste (a position - connotes something permanent) / une profession / un travail / un métier / un emploi / un job (connotes something temporary) / un boulot / un taff; The former are more formal. The latter are less formal.

question: a work contract
answer: un contrat ('koh-trah') de travail; NB: CDI = contrat à durée indéterminé; CDD = contrat à durée déterminé

question: an intership + an intern + an apprenticeship
answer: un stage + un(e) stagiaire + un apprentissage; réaliser des stages = to do an internship; NB: une alternance = a position where you work part of the time and study part of the time

question: to work
answer: travailler OR bosser (more familiar)

question: to work hard
answer: travailler/bosser dur; Alternative idiomatic saying: travailler comme un forcené = to work like a madman

question: to work remotely
answer: travailler en télétravail OR faire du téletravail; informal: être en TT = to be working remotely. e.g. Je suis en TT aujourd'hui. = I'm working remotely today.

question: to work full-time + to work part-time
answer: travailler à temps plein + travailler à temps partiel

question: to work on some thing (e.g. a project)
answer: travailler SUR quelque chose

question: to be unemployed
answer: être sans emploi / être au chômage; e.g. Je suis sans emploi... is much more common in french than to say: Je ne travaille pas.; l'emploi = the employment

question: the workforce
answer: le monde du travail

question: a career
answer: une carrière; NB: carriériste is a derogatory adjective to describe someone who is concerned mainly with advancement in their profession.

question: She/he is a 'new grad' / recent graduate.
answer: Elle est récemment diplômé(e).; NB: un(e) titulaire (de X) = a holder (of X diploma)

question: She/he is a job seeker / looking for work.
answer: Elle/Il cherche du travail.; Use CHERCHER.

question: He/she is an applicant (for a job).
answer: Il/elle est demandeur/demandeuse.

question: She/he is a candidate (for a job).
answer: Elle/il est candidat(e).; la candidature = the candidacy

question: He/she is employed.
answer: Il/elle est employé(e) / embauché(e) / pris(e).

question: She is retired.
answer: Elle est retraité(e).; Alternative: Elle est à la retrait.

question: to retire + to resign (from a job)
answer: partir à la retraite + démissioner

question: an employee (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) employé(e) OR un(e) salarié(e); The latter is for salaried employees.

question: a manual worker + a worker that is not necessarily manual (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) ouvrier/ouvrière + un(e) travailleur/travailleuse; NB: travailleur/travailleuse can also be used as an adjective to describe someone who is hard-working with positive connotation - it does not mean workaholic.

question: an employer (masc + fem)
answer: un employeur + une employeuse

question: an executive (masc + fem) + a CEO
answer: un(e) cadre (same m/f) + un(e) PDG = président(e) directeur/rice général(e)

question: a shareholder (masc + fem) + an investor (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) actionnaire + un(e) investisseur

question: an industrialist
answer: un(e) industriel(le)

question: a founder (of a company)
answer: un fondateur + une fondatrice

question: the standard of living + for a better standard of living
answer: la cadre de vie + pour un meilleur cadre de vie

question: the management (of some part of a business)
answer: la gestion; e.g. gestion de projet = project management; e.g. gestion de fichiers = file management; This is useful for listing competencies on a CV.; la gestion can also be used to describe the management of any kind of situation

question: many levels of management + a heirarchy
answer: beacoup de niveaux de gestion + une hiérarchie

question: a manager (masc + fem)
answer: There are at least 3 options: 1) un directeur / une directrice: the general title for a manager in a company; 2) un(e) gérant(e): a general manager / the person who runs a shop or part of a business; 3) un(e) responsable des ...: The person in charge of something e.g. the person in charge of vegetables in a restaurant = un/une responsable des légumes

question: She is responsible for the modern way of cooking.
answer: Elle est responsable de la façon moderne de cuisiner.

question: a boss (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) patron(ne) OR un(e) chef(fe)

question: a recruiter + an HR representative
answer: un(e) recruteur + un(e) responsable RH; This uses one of the options for describing a manager of something: un(e) responsable des ...

question: a union (e.g. a worker's union)
answer: un syndicat

question: to employ
answer: employer/recruter/embaucher; employer can also mean 'to use'

question: a job opening/posting
answer: une offre d'emploi; This is NOT an offer letter. The translation is more like 'offering'.

question: to apply for a job + to recruit for a job
answer: postuler à + recruter; e.g. I applied to a job opening. = J'ai postulé à une offre d'emploi.; Alternative to postuler: envoyer beaucoup de candidatures

question: to apply for french citizenship
answer: postuler à la nationalité française

question: to submit (a complaint / an application / a request e.g. to the government)
answer: déposer sa demande; e.g. J'ai déposé ma demande. = I submitted/filed an application.; NB: Do not use déposer for submitting a job application - use postuler for that instead.

question: an acceptance + a refusal (of a job offer)
answer: une acceptation + un refus (S is silent)

question: What are the five standard sections of a french CV?
answer: 1) identity including contact information 2) diplomas listed from newest to oldest (including years) 3) jobs held listed from newest to oldest (including years) 4) competencies / list of skills (e.g. natural and programming languages) 5) a very short list of hobbies/activities - though this could be included in the letter of motivation instead

question: a cover letter
answer: une lettre de motivation; le motif = the motivation / reason for doing something

question: a reference / a letter of recommendation
answer: une lettre de recommendation

question: an update (e.g. for a software version)
answer: une mise à jour; e.g. Je dois installer la mise à jour. = I must install the most recent update.; une mise = an act of putting / a placement

question: updated / up-to-date
answer: mis à jour; e.g. un CV mis à jour = an updated CV

question: to keep someone updated with the lates information (e.g. the time to meet someone)
answer: tenir quelqu'un au jus; This is a french saying.; tenir = to hold

question: What is le CR?
answer: compte rendu = the minutes of a meeting

question: I had a job interview 5 years ago.
answer: J'ai passé un entretien d'embauche il y a 5 ans.

question: There were many questions to which I didn't know the answer.
answer: Il y avait beaucoup de questions auxquelles je ne savais pas répondre.

question: What will you do if I have too much work?
answer: Que ferez-vous si j'ai trop de travail?

question: an advantages + a disadvantage
answer: un avantage (or un bénefice) + un inconvénient; inconvénient is a faux ami. It means disadvantage. incommode = inconvenient or impractical

question: What are the disadvantages of this work?
answer: Quels sont les inconvénients de ce travail?

question: the amount of the salary
answer: le montant du salaire

question: the work hours (when you are expected to be working)
answer: les horaires de travail (flexibilites ou fixes)

question: weekly / per week
answer: hebdomadaire; e.g. temps de travail hebdomadaire = number of hours worked per week

question: a work environment
answer: un environnement de travail

question: seniority (how long someone has worked a job)
answer: l'ancienneté (feminine)

question: online/virtual (e.g. online meeting)
answer: en virtuelle; Alternative: la modalité virtuelle

question: in person (e.g. when a class is onsite instead of online)
answer: en personne OR en présentielle OR en sur site (on-site); Alternative: la modalité présentielle

question: I must be there in person.
answer: Je dois travail en sur site. OR Je dois me présenter en personne.; Alternative: Il faudrait que je me déplace. (SE) DÉPLACER = to move (oneself) from one place to another.

question: live (in real time); e.g. a live broadcast
answer: en (temps) direct OR en temps réel ('ray-elle' NOT 'ray-uhl'); Alternative: If you are seeing a band live: Je vais voir X au concert.; Direct(e) can also be used to describe a person that is direct in their communication. e.g. Elle est directe.

question: to broadcast
answer: diffuser

question: Please respect the right to disconnect. (outside of work)
answer: SVP Respetez la droit à la déconnection.

question: I don't want to be disturbed. (after work; e.g. for oncall)
answer: Je ne voudrais pas être déranger.

question: One can have better work-life balance than other jobs.
answer: On peut avoir MEILLEUR équilibre que des autres métiers.; équilibre is the word to use for a figurative balance.

question: One can have a more flexible schedule than other jobs.
answer: La période de travaille est plus flexible que des autres métiers.

question: The job has more flexibility and a good salary.
answer: Ce travail offre beaucoup de flexibilité et un bon salaire.

question: There is more opportunity to meet interesting/creative people that other jobs.
answer: Il y a plus d'opportunité de rencontrer les personnes interessants et creatifs que des autres métiers.

question: A worker can quit their job at any time. (in the US)
answer: Un traivailleur peut décomissioner de l'enterprise à tout moment.

question: A company can fire a worker at any time. (in the US)
answer: Une enterprise peut licencier un traveilleur à tout moment.

question: I need vacation.
answer: J'ai besoin DE vacances.; avoir besoin triggers DE; vacation (vacances) is always plural in french.

question: My ideal job has lots of vacation.
answer: Mon travail idéal me permet d'avoir beaucoup de vacances.

question: my dream job
answer: le travail de mes rêves

question: to manage a project + to pilot a project
answer: gérer un projet + piloter un projet

question: to facilitate + to escalate (up the management chain)
answer: faciliter + faire remonter

question: to take care of
answer: se occuper de OR prendre soin de; Both of these work for 'to take care' and they both trigger the preposition DE.; SE OCCUPER can also be used for 'to deal with'. It's more about management. PRENDRE SOIN is more about care.

question: I deal with the clients.
answer: Je me occupe DES clients.; SE OCCUPER is a better choice for managing clients. It triggers the preposition DE.

question: I take care of my clothes.
answer: J'ai prends soin DE mes vêtements.; PRENDRE SOIN is a better choice for taking care of clothing. It triggers the preposition DE.

question: to have meetings
answer: avoir des réunions

question: to give a presentation
answer: faire une présentation (feminine)

question: to give a live demo
answer: démontrer en direct

question: a discussion + a conference
answer: un discours + une conférence; a conference center = un centre de conférence

question: to make a suggestion + I suggest that...
answer: faire une suggestion + Je suggère que...; Alternative: je serais plutôt pour... = I would rather...

question: to make a schedule + to make an agenda
answer: organiser un planning + organiser un ordre du jour; NB: agenda is a faux ami - it means personal calendar / schedule in french.

question: to resolve conflict
answer: garder le contrôle de la situation

question: Raise your hand to vote.
answer: Levez la main pour voter.; Use lever (instead of élever) to indicate the rising up of a body part or the rising up of a body in the morning.

question: to create content
answer: créer du contenu

question: to remodel the website
answer: remodeler le site web

question: to code a lot
answer: faire beacoup de codage/programmation

question: idiomatic ways to talk about teamwork
answer: 1) avoir l'esprit d'équipe = to have team spirit 2) travailler en equipée = to work on a team; You can use both verbs to talk about teamwork.

question: idiomatic way to talk about a sense of community and solidarity
answer: esprit de groupe

question: to be flexible / adaptable (when describing yourself in a job interview)
answer: être flexible OR faire preuve d'adaptation; faire preuve = to demonstrate

question: to work under pressure
answer: travailler sous préssion OR gérer le stress (to manage the stress); the pressure = la pression

question: to be good at multi-tasking
answer: être polyvalent(e) = someone who can juggle many jobs

question: to delivery on-time / to respect deadlines
answer: respecter les délais

question: I respect your opinion but...
answer: Je respecte ton opinion mais...

question: to seize every opportunity
answer: saisir toute opportunité

question: pro-active (describing a person)
answer: force de proposition; e.g. Je suis force de proposition.

question: to know how to communicate well
answer: bien savoir commiquer

question: to have hindsight
answer: prendre du recul

question: to have empathy
answer: avoir de l'empathie

question: to develop (new) skills
answer: développer des compétences

question: to grow in experience (in a job)
answer: enricher mon experience

question: to hold a position (in a company)
answer: occuper un poste

question: to progress in my career
answer: évoluer dans ma carrière; ÉVOLUER = to evolve

question: to change jobs + careers
answer: changer de métier + carrière; NB: métier de bouche = hospitality; NB: métier d'avenir = industry/careers of the future

question: to get more responsibility
answer: obtenir plus de responsibilités; tenir = to hold

question: to earn more money + to learn more
answer: pour gagner plus (silent S) d'argent + pour apprendre plus (pronounce the S)

question: to stay in shape
answer: rester en forme

question: to be comfortable with computers
answer: avoir le sens ('sohnS'; S is pronounced) informatique

question: to know how to use certain technologies
answer: savoir utiliser certaines technologies

question: to find a solution
answer: trouver une solution

question: to fix a problem
answer: régler un problème; Alternative: gérer la situation = to manage the situation

question: to address a problem
answer: s'attaquer; e.g. La technologie ne s'attaque pas la cause du problème. = The technology does not address the cause of the problem.; If you really want to express aggressively attacking a problem: entrer dans le vif du sujet = get to the heart of the problem

question: the points to tackle (when solving a problem)
answer: les points à aborder; aborder = to tackle

question: idiomatic way to express that you are struggling with a difficult problem and not finding a solution
answer: Je me casse la tête... sur ce problème.; SE CASSER la tête

question: idiomatic way to express that you are not addressing the real problem
answer: tourner autour du pot = to beat around the bush

question: a technical problem
answer: un problème technique

question: a manufacturing default
answer: un défaut de fabrication

question: by default
answer: par défaut

question: to troubleshoot
answer: dépanner; la panne = the damage / the breakdown

question: to participate
answer: participer; This also means to contribute.

question: to sell + to resell
answer: vendre + revendre

question: to exchange + in exchange for X
answer: échanger + en échange DE X

question: to send (in general) + to mail (using the post office) + idiomatic way to say: send a message/text
answer: envoyer + poster + faire passer un message

question: It's in the mail.
answer: C'est posté. This uses POSTER in passe composé.; For example: J'ai posté la lettre hier. = I mailed (or 'posted') the letter yesterday.

question: to watch / look at
answer: regarder; to watch television = regarder la télé(vision)

question: to look for / I am looking for a jacket (in a store).
answer: chercher / Je cherche ('shersh') une veste.; rechercher is similar but more thorough - perhaps meaning to research or seek

question: to show + to demonstrate
answer: montrer + démontrer; NB: This is different from MONTER (to put together OR to go up) and DÉMONTER (to disassemble).; Alternative: faire visiter e.g. Elle fait visiter son appartement. = She shows her apartment.

question: to celebrate + We celebrate.
answer: fêter + On fait la fête. (literally: we make a celebration)

question: a party animal
answer: un(e) fêtard(e)

question: to arrive
answer: arriver; this is also the verb for 'to happen' e.g. Ç'est arrivé. = It happened.; SE PASSER can also be used to express this.

question: It happens.
answer: Ça arrive. OR Ça se passe.; ARRIVER is typically used for both 'to arrive' and 'to happen'.; You can also use the verb SE PASSER for 'to happen'.

question: Two things happened.; use ARRIVER
answer: Deux choses sont arrivées. OR Deux choses se sont passées.

question: She told me what happened.; use SE PASSER
answer: Elle m'a dit ce qui s'était passé.

question: It takes place on an island.
answer: Ça se déroule sur une île.; SE DÉROULER (to take place) is a slightly better way to talk about setting - compared to ARRIVER and SE PASSER.

question: to talk/to speak + to talk about x + to speak to someone
answer: parler + parler DE quelque chose + parler À quelqu'un; PARLER (to speak) is different from DIRE (to say).

question: I spoke to James about the film.
answer: Je parle À James DU film.; PARLER + À = to speak to (someone); PARLER + DE = to speak about (something); de + le = du

question: to say (something) / to tell (something - that is not a long story); Conjugate it.
answer: DIRE; je dis + tu dis + il dit + nous disons + vous dites + ils disent; past participle: dit

question: You were saying. (imparfait) + You might say. (conditionnel)
answer: Tu disais. + Tu dirais.; Infinitive: DIRE. Remember that the radical/base used in future tenses is usually the one that uses an R.

question: I wasn't going to tell you.
answer: Je N'allais (aller in imparfait) PAS te le dire.; le is a pronoun that stands of the thing that is being told (or not told)

question: I said to myself... (a way to express that I was thinking something)
answer: J m'ai dit. Use DIRE reflexively: SE DIRE.

question: Where do you see yourself in 5 years? I see myself doing X.
answer: Où vous voyez vous dans 5 ans? Je me vois faire X.; Use VOIR reflexively: SE VOIR.

question: to express
answer: exprimer (s'exprimer is to express oneself)

question: to describe + to imply
answer: décrire + impliquer; an innuendo = un sous-entendu

question: to tell (a story)
answer: raconter (une histoire / un récit); pronounced 'ra-kohn-Tay' - 'ra' is like the word 'rad' without the D or the word 'racoon'. The first syllable is NOT 'ray'.; There is only one N and the T is really sharp because it is not followed directly by an R. So the pronunciation is very different from the verb rencontrer (to meet for the first time); Raconter is used much more commonly than dire (to say) when you are talking about something that was told.

question: to notice (something)
answer: remarquer

question: idiomatic way to say: a good tip/note
answer: une bonne remarque; remarquer = to notice / to note (something)

question: to sing + to rap
answer: chanter + rapper; RAPPER can be spelled with one or two Ps.

question: the lyrics + the beat (of a song)
answer: les paroles + le beat; Most words associated with creative work are taken from English.

question: to describe music... upbeat + catchy + danceable
answer: entretenant + entraînant(e) + dansant(e); Dansant(e) is a real and commonly used adjective in french - unlike the english version which sounds forced.

question: to copy + to imitate
answer: copier (literal translation) + recopier (when you copy someone's movements) + imiter (to imitate); IMITER borders on making fun of something. For example the word for mimic (un imitateur) is only used for someone who is imitating as part of a performance to make fun of someone.

question: to begin + to continue + to stop
answer: commencer + continuer + arrêter; ARRÊTER also means 'to arrest' when police take custody of someone.; DÉMARRER is an alternative to COMMENCER.

question: to begin to dance + to continue to dance
answer: commencer À danser + continuer À danser; Both verbs trigger À before the verb. This is an exception from how we generally connect verbs: conjugated verb + DE + infinitive

question: to restart
answer: recommencer

question: We started over from the beginning.
answer: On l'a recommencé du début.

question: to hesitate + to hesitate to ask
answer: hésiter + hésiter À demander; hésiter triggers À before the verb.

question: to ask (for something) + to ask (a question) ...2 different verbs
answer: demander (quelque chose) + poser (une question)

question: She asked me to create a poster.
answer: Elle m'a demandé DE créer une affiche.; DE between demander and créer. No preposition following créer because whatever is a created is a COD.

question: She displays/exudes optimism.
answer: Elle affiche de l'optimisme; Use AFFICHER + de + qqch (to display or exude something) which is related to une affiche (a poster).

question: a request + a demand
answer: une demande (a request) + une requête (a demand); Take care because these are 'faux amis'. The words that sound similar to English words actually have the opposite meaning in French.

question: to require / to demand
answer: exiger (very strong); e.g. J'exige de parler au manager. You would only say this if you were extremely upset/entitled. ; e.g. Mon travail exige que j'ai une tenue correct. = My job requires that I wear the correct outfit. But EXIGER means that the level of the job (or the standards of the job) is such that the object of the verb is inexplicitly required. This is not something that is on a job description or that your boss tells you to do. It means that the level of the job demands a certain type of behavior - one must rise to that occassion.

question: demanding (e.g. a demanding client or professor)
answer: exigeant(e); This comes from the verb EXIGER: to demand a certain level of behavior. It is a very strong adjective.

question: pushy (slang)
answer: gonflé(a)

question: to respond to a question
answer: réprondre À une question; RÉPONDRE triggers the preposition À

question: to deny
answer: nier

question: to be paid
answer: être rémunéré(e); This comes from the verb RÉMUNERER (to remunerate).

question: idiomatic way to say that someone is very generous
answer: être dépensier; like DÉPENSER

question: conjugate payer (to pay) au présent
answer: je paye/paie + tu payes/paies + il paye/paie + nous payons + vous payez + ils payent/paient; Payer is a -YER verb so for all forms (except nous and vous) the Y can stay or it can be changed to I. Both forms are correct.

question: List 5 verbs ending in -YER and explain what is special about their conjugation.
answer: payer (to pay) + essayer (to try) + nettoyer (to clean) + envoyer (to send) + effrayer (to frighten) + s'ennuyer (to be bored); -YER verbs can be conjugated in two ways au présent that are totally correct... for all forms (except nous and vous) the Y can stay or it can be changed to I.

question: to cost + the cost
answer: coûter + le coût

question: to be reimbursed
answer: remboursé(e) OR dédommagé(e); Alternatives: recevoir un remboursement + se faire rembourser

question: I would like to be reimbursed.
answer: Je voudrais me faire rembourser.

question: the refund
answer: le remboursement; le remboursement intégralement = a complete refund 100%

question: I would like to pay with cash + card + check + ApplePay.
answer: Je voudrais payer en liquide OR en espèces + par carte bancaire + par chèque + par ApplePay (or whatever the app is called). Do not say 'par app' when trying to pay with an app. Use the name of it.

question: a wallet + a change purse
answer: un portefeuille + un porte-monnaie

question: money; Give the proper word and the slang word.
answer: Proper: argent + Slang: sous (it is always plural); Je ne plus beaucoup de sous. = I don't have much money.

question: a banknote (like a 100 dollar bill)
answer: un billet ('bee-yay')

question: a coin
answer: une pièce de monnaie

question: change (some coins)
answer: de la monnaie OR des espèces

question: I have savings. (money in the bank)
answer: There are three ways to express this: 1) J'ai des économies. 2) J'ai l'argent de côté. Do not forget the accent to indicate 'on the side' (as opposed to the coast). 3) J'ai l'épargne. une èpargne = a saving(s)

question: an investment (literal or figurative)
answer: un investissement; This is used the same way in french as in english. It can be commitment of money + time + effort.

question: to save money
answer: économiser OR épargner; ÉCONOMISER is more commonly used.

question: When I was young I didn't save money.
answer: Quand j'était jeune je n'épargnais pas.; Use imparfait because this is not a precise event.

question: How do you ask for the check at a restaurant?
answer: l'addition s'il vous plaît

question: the sum / the total
answer: la somme; e.g. la somme DES taxes

question: a salary + minimum wage
answer: un salaire + smic

question: a bonus (on top of a salary)
answer: la prime; NB: Social security benefits in France are usually based on salary - they likely will not reflect income from bonuses.

question: the gross + the net (e.g. of a salary)
answer: le brut + le net; NB: The ending T is pronounced in both words.

question: the profit
answer: le bénéfice; This word also means an advantage or a benefit (the additional perks offered by an employer).

question: financial gains
answer: des gains financiers

question: a monopoly
answer: un monopole

question: a fee
answer: les frais (feminine) OR les honoraires (masculine) OR les charges; All are used exclusively in the plural for this meaning. If you use the singular forms the meaning is slightly different.; alternative: une amende

question: the shipping fees + the delivery fees
answer: les frais d'expédition + les frais de livraison

question: a tax (general) + a tax (on income)
answer: une tax (feminine) + un impôt (masculine)

question: a tip (for a server)
answer: un pourboire; literally 'for a drink'

question: a tip/trick (for doing something fast/well)
answer: une astuce

question: an item number (e.g. SKU)
answer: une référence

question: a warranty
answer: une garantie

question: the sales policy (when purchasing an item)
answer: la politique de vente

question: an order (like an online purchase) + to place an order
answer: la commande + passer une commande

question: to pay a bill
answer: régler une facture

question: a purchase order
answer: le bon de commande

question: a purchase
answer: un achat ('ah-sha'; same pronunciation when plural); This is derived from acheter (to buy).

question: a coupon
answer: un bon de réduction; This is how 'bon'/'bonne' can be used as a noun.; e.g. un bon de livraison = the packing list that comes with a delivery; e.g. une bonne (the good one) des voisons = the good neighbor

question: a credit (on the next order)
answer: un avoir (sur la prochaine commande)

question: a loan
answer: un crédit; prendre un crédit sur 20 ans = to take a 20-year loan

question: a debt
answer: une dette

question: a down payment (on a purchase)
answer: un acompte

question: an invoice
answer: Two possibilities: 1) une facture describes an invoice for a service (e.g. at a hospital) 2) un ticket de caisse describes the itemized receipt you receive at a cash register - not the receipt from the card swipe

question: a receipt (proof of payment when paying for goods or services)
answer: There are three options: 1) un reçu 2) la quittance (for payment of rent) 3) un ticket de caisse.;  None of these is the name for the paper that you receive after swiping a bank card: un ticket de carte

question: the receipt from swiping a card for payment
answer: un ticket de carte; This is different from the itemized receipt that shows what you are being charged for: un ticket de caisse

question: income
answer: Two options: 1) le revenu 2) des recettes (always plural in this case); e.g. Les recettes augmentent. = The revenue is growing.

question: the number / the figure
answer: The word depends on the order of magnitude. 1) le chiffre is a single number (1-9) 2) un nombre is the representation of any number regardless of how large it is

question: a recipe (when cooking)
answer: une recette (singular); NB: This word can be used in its plural form to talk about income.

question: to climb
answer: grimper

question: to drop
answer: faire tomber; e.g. Je fais tomber mon stylo. = I drop my pen.

question: to fall
answer: tomber; e.g. Mon stylo tombe. = My pen falls.; to be timed well = tomber très bien (e.g. Ça tombe très bien. = It is good timing.)

question: to fall in love
answer: tomber amoureux; alternative: avoir le coup de foudre = to fall in love at first sight

question: to collapse (downward)
answer: effondrer; Use this for a building that falls down. It can also be used reflexively: Quand je suis fatigué(e) je m'effrondre.; NB: You cannot use EFFONDRER to describe something that collapses inwardly. Use imploser (to implode) for that.

question: to explode + to implode
answer: exploser + imploser

question: idiomatic way to express: I have to leave right away.
answer: Je m'en vais de ce pas.

question: to leave (a place)
answer: partir; PARTIR is one of the verbs where you can add an RE- prefix for emphasis without literally meaning to leave again (REPARTIR).

question: to leave something (e.g. a tip + a message)
answer: laisser; LAISSER is used in a somewhat passive way. 'To drop' is a good translation for LAISSER.

question: to throw something
answer: lancer

question: to throw something away
answer: jeter (literally: to throw out or put out); When you use jeter you mean to actively throw something out.; If instead you want to say that you are getting rid of something: se débarrasser.; If instead you want to say that you throw an object (like a ball): lancer.

question: to release something (e.g. into the air)
answer: rejeter (connotation is negative) or émettre (connotation can be positive or negative); e.g. une usine rejete des produits chimiques dans l'air.

question: He threw away the toys.
answer: Il a jeté les jouets.; JETER (to throw out) is the correct verb to use. You do not need a preposition or other word following JETER to indicate that you are throwing something in the trash.

question: to take out the garbage + to put something in the garbage can
answer: jeter à la poubelle + mettre à la poubelle

question: to get rid of something
answer: se débarrasser + DE + quelque chose; You must use this verb reflexively. And you must use DE to indicate the physical thing that is going away.

question: I got rid of the lamp. + I got rid of it.
answer: Je me suis débarrasé(e) DE la lampe. + Je m'EN suis débarrassé(e).; SE DÉBARRASSER triggers DE before its object. So use EN when referring to the object as a pronoun.

question: to let something go (like a confrontation)
answer: laisser tomber; This is a very useful phrase for non-tangible things. It is not as useful when talking about physical things.

question: It's better to give up.
answer: Il vaut mieux abandonner.

question: the exit + the departure
answer: la sortie (from the verb SORTIR) + le départ (from the verb PARTIR)

question: to enter
answer: entrer; Use DANS when something is entered. e.g. Je suis entré(e) DANS le musée. = I entered the museum.; NB: RENTRER shares the same base/conjugation as ENTRER. The prefix RE- is used to emphasis the entrance - not necessarily to mean 're-enter'.

question: an entrance
answer: une entrée (from ENTRER)

question: to go too far / to cross the line
answer: dépasser les bornes; This is a french expression.

question: to clear / to get rid of
answer: débarrasser

question: You can get rid of the table.
answer: Tu peux débarrasser la table.

question: Bad habits are difficult to get rid of. + It is difficult to get rid of them.
answer: Il est difficile DE se débarrasser des mauvaises habitudes. + Il est difficile DE s'EN débarrasser.

question: Literature is difficult to learn.
answer: La littérature est difficile À apprendre.

question: It is difficult to explain.
answer: C'est difficile À expliquer.

question: a favor
answer: une faveur

question: to share (also to split a bill)
answer: parteger; On partage? = shall we split it?

question: to give + to give back
answer: donner + redonner

question: There are many things to give to the owners.
answer: Il y a beaucoup de choses À donner AUX propriétaires.; donner + à = to give to (someone)

question: to borrow + to lend (for a short period of time)
answer: emprunter + prêter

question: to barter
answer: troquer

question: to read
answer: lire; past participle: lu

question: to write + to spell
answer: écrire + épeler; The noun for spelling: épellation. It is feminine.; NB: Be sure to avoid pronouncing any S in the verb ÉCRIR - it is not like Spanish (eScribir); RÉDIGER is an alternative to ÉCRIRE. It can mean to 'write up' or 'draw up' an essay or CV for example.

question: to register/subscribe/sign up + to follow (a person on social media or a youTube channel)
answer: inscrire (conjugated like écrire) + abonner (not suivre)

question: to record (a sound or not) + to keep track of (something)
answer: enregistrer + garder une trace de...

question: to sign
answer: signer

question: to take + to learn + to understand
answer: prendre + apprendre + comprendre; Because they are spelled so similarly they are also conjugated simlarly.; NB: comprendre can also mean 'to be comprised of'

question: How does the pronunciation of the letters 'en' change when we conjugate of comprendre?
answer: je/tu comprends + il comprend etc...the EN sounds as expected in french like 'uhn'. But ils comprennent... The double N changes how the E sounds. So ENN sounds like 'ehn'.; NB: This rule works for all words including the conjugations of similar verbs like prendre and apprendre.
