question: What is a very direct / confrontational way to say: You must eat healthily.
answer: Vous devez manger sainement.; This is much more direct than: Il faut manager sainement. or Il faut que vous manger sainement.

question: What are three progressively direct / confrontational ways to say: You must go to the doctor.
answer: Most generalized using FALLOIR + INFINITIV: Il faut aller chez médecin.; Slightly more targeted and with higher sense of urgency using FALLOIR + SUBJONCTIF: Il faut QUE tu ailles (subjonctif) chez le médecin.; Most direct/confrontational using DEVOIR: Tu doit aller chez le médecin.

question: Using FALLOIR what are two ways to say: You/One must rest.
answer: 1) Il faut SE reposer. (more generalized / less aggressive); 2) Il faut TE/VOUS reposer. (still generalized but slightly more personalized / confrontational and with higher sense of urgency); SE REPOSER is reflexive. This means that there is an additional layer of subtlety that can be used simply by changing whether or not the reflexive pronoun is conjugated after Il faut...; NB: Il faut que... and Vous devez... would both be more direct / confrontational than the two options for reflexive verbs that use Il faut...

question: I must wait.
answer: Il faut que j'attende.; It is more common to express this using FALLOIR (instead of using DEVOIR).; Il faut que triggers the subjonctif so j'attende is in the subjonctif form.

question: You had to do your homework before going out.
answer: More targeted with high sense of urgency: Il fallait (FALLOIR in imparfait) que tu fasses (subjonctif) tes devoirs avant de sortir.; More generalized alternative: Il fallait faire tes devoirs avant de sortir. This translates more to 'it was required to do our/your homework...'; FALLOIR alone signifies a general requirement. FALLOIR + QUE is a very targeted and personal statement.

question: Using falloir in imparfait: It was required to sleep. + I (emphasis on I) really needed to sleep.
answer: Il fallait dormir. + Il fallait que je dorme (subjonctif).; FALLOIR alone signifies a general requirement. FALLOIR + QUE is a very targeted statement with a higher sense of urgency.

question: Using falloir in conditionnel: We should sleep. + I should sleep.
answer: Il faudrait dormir. + Il faudrait que je dors (subjonctif).; FALLOIR alone signifies a general requirement. FALLOIR + QUE is a very targeted statement with a higher sense of urgency.

question: It was required that I come home before midnight.
answer: Il fallait que je revienne (subjonctif form of REVENIR) avant minuit.

question: It is important that the muscles are warm before stretching.
answer: C'est IMPORTANT QUE les muscles soient (subjonctif) chauds avant les étirements.; Any kind of opinion like this (e.g. It is critical that...) triggers the subjonctif.

question: He left even though I told him to stay.
answer: Il est parti BIEN QUE je lui aie (subjonctif) dit de rester.; BIEN QUE = though / although / even though / altogether. It always triggers the subjonctif.; When you use the subjonctif in the past tense you must use passé composé. You cannot use imparfait.

question: I dance tango. + I dance ballet.
answer: Je danse LE tango. + Je danse LA danse classique.; DANSER does not use a preposition. So the object only requires it's article (le/la/l') - not du/de la.

question: I learn tango so that we may dance together.
answer: J'apprends le tango POUR QUE nous dansions (subjonctif) ensemble.; POUR QUE = so that / in order that. It always trigger the subjonctif.; Alternatives that also trigger the subjonctif: afin que (so that) + en sorte que (so that) + vu que (given that).

question: We will leave now so that you are on time.
answer: Nous partirons maintenant afin que tu sois (subjonctif) à l’heure. AFIN QUE = so that. Like POUR QUE (and other alternatives) it triggers the subjonctif.

question: We have to leave before it gets dark.
answer: Nous devons partir avant qu’il fasse (subjonctif) nuit.; We have to use AVANT QUE (instead of avant de) because the subjects of the two phrases are different. And AVANT QUE always triggers the subjonctif.

question: We began to eat lunch after Paul arrived.
answer: Nous avons commencé de déjeuner après que Paul soit (subjonctif) / est (indicative) arrivé.; NB: APRÈS QUE does not trigger the subjonctif technically in proper french (so use indicative on an exam). BUT this is not how french is actually spoken and written. Everyone (even if they know it is technically incorrect) uses subjonctif after APRÈS QUE.; We have to use APRÈS QUE (instead of après de) because the subjects of the two phrases are different.

question: before i got on the plane
answer: avant que je sois rentré dans l'avion; Use AVANT QUE (instead of avant de) because what follows is a complete phrase.; AVANT QUE triggers the subjonctif. RENTRER (like entrer) uses être in passé composé.

question: before going to the beach (in the present) + before going to the beach (in the past)
answer: avant D'aller à la plage + avant D'être allé(e) à la plage; au présent: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE of the verb; au passé: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE of auxiliary + PAST PARTICIPLE (which adjusts to gender/number when être is the auxiliary)

question: before visiting X (in the present) + before visiting X (in the past)
answer: avant DE rendre visite à X + avant D'avoir rendu visite à X; au présent: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE of the verb; au passé: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE of auxiliary + PAST PARTICIPLE (which adjusts to gender/number when être is the auxiliary)

question: before getting up (in the present) + before getting up (in the past)
answer: avant DE se lever + avant DE s'être levé(e); au présent: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE of the verb; au passé: AVANT + DE + INFINITIVE of auxiliary + PAST PARTICIPLE (which adjusts to gender/number when être is the auxiliary)

question: before covid + before having covid
answer: avant le covid + avant d'avoir le covid; There is no DE required after avant when what follows is a noun. When a verb follows we must add DE.

question: after going to the beach
answer: après être allé(e) à la plage (no preposition DE with après); The formula is: APRÈS + INFINITIVE of auxiliary + PAST PARTICIPLE; In french translate 'after doing...' as 'after HAVING done...' (auxiliary as a gerund + past participle). In french we almost always assume this is happening in the past tense - there is not an option for using présent (like there is for 'before doing something').; NB: We can only use this formula when the subject of this phrase and the independent phrase are the same. e.g. After going to the beach... I took a nap. If the subjects of these two phrases are different then you have to use après que instead.

question: after visiting X
answer: après avoir rendu visite à X (no preposition DE with après); The formula is: APRÈS + INFINITIVE of auxiliary + PAST PARTICIPLE; In french translate 'after doing...' as 'after HAVING done...' (auxiliary as a gerund + past participle). In french we almost always assume this is happening in the past tense - there is not an option for using présent (like there is for 'before doing something').; NB: We can only use this formula when the subject of this phrase and the independent phrase are the same. e.g. After visiting my aunt... I went home. If the subjects of these two phrases are different then you have to use après que instead.

question: after drinking X
answer: après avoir bu X; The formula is: APRÈS + INFINITIVE of auxiliary + PAST PARTICIPLE; In french translate 'after doing...' as 'after HAVING done...' (auxiliary as a gerund + past participle). In french we almost always assume this is happening in the past tense - there is not an option for using présent (like there is for 'before doing something').; NB: We can only use this formula when the subject of this phrase and the independent phrase are the same. e.g. After getting up... I brushed my teeth. If the subjects of these two phrases are different then you have to use après que instead.

question: after getting up
answer: après s'être levé(e) (no preposition DE with après); The formula is: APRÈS + INFINITIVE of auxiliary + PAST PARTICIPLE; In french translate 'after doing...' as 'after HAVING done...' (auxiliary as a gerund + past participle). In french we almost always assume this is happening in the past tense - there is not an option for using présent (like there is for 'before doing something').; NB: We can only use this formula when the subject of this phrase and the independent phrase are the same. e.g. After getting up... I brushed my teeth. If the subjects of these two phrases are different then you have to use après que instead.

question: I was running all week.
answer: J'ai couru toute la semaine.

question: neither you nor I
answer: ni toi ni moi; When negating in french it triggers the pronom tonique which disambiguates between gender in the 3rd person.; Alternative: aucun des deux = neither of the two

question: It is not X Y or Z.
answer: Three options when making a negated list. 1) Use ou: Ça n'est pas X Y ou Z. 2) Use et: Ça n'est pas X Y et Z. This is possible in french. 3) Use ni (stronger tone): Ça n'est pas X ni Y ni Z.

question: either... or...
answer: soit... soit...; Use the same word twice. It looks like the subjonctif form of être but it is not.

question: whether or not... (e.g. I don't know whether or not I succeeded.)
answer: Je ne sais pas SI j'ai réussi ou non.; There is no equivalent for 'whether'. Generally one states the first option and then adds 'ou non' (literally: or not).

question: in order to speak and take
answer: POUR parler et POUR prendre; When you list items connected by ET then articles and prepositions must be listed on both sides - not just once.

question: the cat and dog
answer: LE chat et LE chien; When you list items connected by ET then articles and prepositions must be listed on both sides - not just once.

question: the people
answer: les gens + le peuple + les personnes

question: a character + the main character + a caricature
answer: un personnage + le personnage principal + une caricature

question: an aquaintance + a contact (a person you know)
answer: une connaissance + un contact; a confident = un(e) confident(e)

question: a colleague + a peer
answer: un(e) collègue + un(e) pair

question: the associates (the people that someone hangs out with)
answer: les fréquentations

question: a friendship
answer: une amitié

question: a friend
answer: un(e) ami(e) (m/f; pronounced same); Alternative: le copain / la copine (If you add petit(e) then it means boyfriend/girlfriend.); NB: Avoid using mon ami(e) / mes amis when talking about platonic friends because it sounds like boyfriend/girlfriend in french. Instead use un(e) ami(e) or des amis.

question: a good friend + an old friend (known for a long time)
answer: un(e) bon(ne) ami(e) + un(e) vieil(le) ami(e); Like english use the word for 'old' to describe both someone who is old and someone who you have known for a long time.

question: best friends
answer: des meilleurs amis; Alternatives: un(e) vrai(e) ami(e) = a true friend + un(e) pote = buddy/pal; un(e) pote homo = a gay friend

question: 2 to 3 friends
answer: des amis; It's not idiomatic to say deux ou trois amis.

question: idiomatic way to refer to a classmate - a person that you went to school with and were friendly with but who is not necessarily as close to you as a friend
answer: two options: 1) un copain/une copine (m/f) is more modern 2)un/une camarade (literally: comrade) is less modern but still used

question: idiomatic way to refer to someone you work with but who is not necessarily a friend
answer: un/une collègue

question: 2 steps to the train
answer: à deux pas du train

question: a street + a pedestrian street
answer: + une rue + une rue piétonne; des piétons = the pedestrians

question: a road + an alley
answer: une route + la ruelle; La route is a bit of a 'false friend'. It means the pavement itself - not the route.

question: an avenue + a boulevard
answer: une avenue + un boulevard

question: on the avenue + on the boulevard
answer: DANS l'avenue + SUR le boulevard; Whether to use SUR or DANS has to be memorized.

question: on the road + on the street
answer: SUR la route + DANS la rue; Whether to use SUR or DANS has to be memorized.

question: in the plaza + in the street + in the photo
answer: SUR la place + DANS la rue + SUR la photo; Whether to use SUR or DANS has to be memorized.

question: I live at XX Bond Street. + I live at XX Park Boulevard.
answer: J'habite` XX Rue Bond. + J'habite` XX Boulvard Park.; This is how you give your address. Use the same structure regardless of whether you live on a rue (feminine) or a boulevard (masculine).

question: I live on Bond Street. + I live on Park Boulevard.
answer: J'habite DANS la Rue Bond. + J'habite AU Boulevard Park.; Use dans for a street. Use au for a boulevard.

question: I live on that street. + I live on that boulevard.
answer: J'habite DANS cette rue. + J'habite AU ce boulevard.Use dans for a street. Use au for a boulevard.

question: a pathway + a bike path
answer: un chemin + une piste cyclable

question: a path (for your career)
answer: parcours; This can also mean path (un chemin) or journey (un voyage) but it can additionally be used to describe a path in life or work.

question: a journey + a chase
answer: un voyage + une chasse; voyage de noces = honeymoon

question: a sidewalk
answer: un trottoir

question: the traffic
answer: le trafic is the general term. Without further context this means the trafficing of forbidden goods (e.g. le trafic de drogues / d'armes). But if you add an adjective then it can mean the movement of vehicles (e.g. le traffic aérien = the air traffic). But if you mean car traffic then you must use a different word: la circulation.

question: a traffic jam
answer: un embouteillage ('uh-bow-tay-ahj'); Alternative and very familiar option: un bouchon (like bottleneck)

question: rush hour + the rush (busy time) at a restaurant or party
answer: les heures de pointe + un coup de feu

question: a parking lot + a parking meter
answer: un parking + un parcomètre; un parking can also mean parking spaces

question: to drive (a car); Conjugate it.
answer: conduire (conjugated similar to dire): je conduis + tu conduis + il conduit + nous conduisons + vous conduisez + ils conduisent; past participle: conduit; CONDUIRE can also mean to travel by car. e.g. On a conduit de X à Y. = We drove from X to Y.

question: We drove. + We were driving.
answer: On a conduit. + On conduisait.; NB: You can use the verb 'to drive' in french the same as you do in english. e.g. On a conduit (we drove) means that we were all on a roadtrip.

question: to operate (or turn) an engine/machine
answer: diriger; This can also mean to drive in the sense of leading.

question: a leader (m/f)
answer: un(e) dirigeant(e); This comes from the verb DIRIGER (to operate or turn an engine).

question: to lead
answer: There are two major options: 1) DIRIGER: to direct someone or something to accomplish a goal. 2) MENER: This can mean to bring someone along to accomplish a goal. It is also used to talk about causation (MENER + À). e.g. Le problème mène à une solution. = The problem leads to a solution.

question: to cause... + to lead to...
answer: causer + mener à; If you use MENER without the preposition Á then is just means to lead someone or something.

question: The leak caused a problem.
answer: La fuite a posé un problème.; POSER is a common way to suggest causation - as opposed to CAUSER.

question: The disease caused the symptoms.
answer: La maladie a provoqué les symptômes.; PROVOQUER is a common way to suggest causation - as opposed to CAUSER.

question: to fly
answer: voler; This works for describing a bird or a person in an airplane.; VOLER also means 'to steal'.

question: a bicycle + a motorcycle
answer: un vélo + une moto

question: a car + a taxi
answer: une voiture + un taxi; a flat tire = un pneu crevé

question: to park (a car)
answer: garer

question: a truck + a van
answer: un camion + un van; NB: un van is a van used for travelling.

question: a police van + a firetruck + a garbage truck
answer: une camionnette + un camion de pompier + un camion poubelle

question: a bus
answer: un bus; 'boos' the S is pronounced even though it is a final consonant because the origin of the word is foreign

question: a subway + a subway station
answer: le métro + la station de métro; You can use 'un métro' to mean a subway stop.

question: a train + a train station
answer: un train ('tron') + la gare ('gahr' rhymes with car); NB: gare à toi (or anyone) = a warning to someone like you are watching them and there might be consequences if they do something

question: a boat
answer: un bateau; -eau and -eaux is pronounced like a really strong 'oh' - like the word chateau; plural for all words that end in -eau is to add an X; So boats is les bateaux.

question: a sailboat + a submarine
answer: un bateau à voile + un sous-marin

question: a cruiseship + a container/cargo ship
answer: un paquebot + un cargo

question: an airplane + a flight + an airport
answer: un avion + un vol + un aéroport (4 syllables! 'ah-yah-ro-por')

question: How do you pronounce Charles de Gaulle airport?
answer: aéroport (4 syllables! 'ah-ay-ro-pohr') Charles ('shahrl') de Gaulle ('gohl'; hard O like bateau and chateau)

question: a license plate (on a car)
answer: la plaque d'immatriculation

question: an engine
answer: un moteur

question: by sea + on the sea
answer: par la mer + sur le large

question: by foot + by bike + by horse
answer: À pied + À velo + À cheval

question: by car + by train + by subway + by plane
answer: EN voiture + EN train + EN métro + EN avion

question: public transport
answer: les transports en commun

question: The public transport in my city is really developed.
answer: Les transports en commun sont bien développés dans ma ville.

question: She opened her studio to the public.
answer: Elle a ouvert son studio au public.

question: one-way + roundtrip
answer: aller simple + aller-retour

question: a trip
answer: un trajet

question: the luggage + a suitcase
answer: les bagages (plural masculine) + une valise

question: a forest + into the great outdoors
answer: une forêt + au grand air

question: the vineyard + the orchard
answer: le vignoble ("veen-yo") + le verger

question: the nature
answer: la nature

question: the tropics
answer: les tropiques; alternative: un climat tropical (a tropical climate)

question: the mountain(s) + the hill
answer: la montagne / les montagnes + la colline

question: the volcano
answer: le volcan

question: a rock + a pebble
answer: un rocher + un caillou

question: the ocean + the sea

question: When does a color adjective not agree in gender/number with its noun?
answer: 1) When the color is derived from a noun. e.g. les chaussures ivoire = the ivory shoes. There are some exceptions that do adapt in gender/number (e.g. rose and violet).; 2) Compound colors (using more than one adjective related to the color) are invariable - they never agree in gender/number with their noun. e.g. la robe vert jaune	= the yellow-green dress; 3) More than one color in play: It depends. Agreement happens when there is group of items and some of them are red and some of them are yellow (e.g. des fleurs rouges et jaunes = the red and yellow flowers). Agreement does not happen if you have a group of items that are multi-colored (e.g. des fleurs rouge et jaune = the red-yellow flowers).

question: a ticket

question: a subway ticket + a bus ticket + a theater ticket + a museum ticket
answer: un ticket de métro + de bus + de théâtre + de musée; Use ticket instead of billet for these events.; Treat it like a quantity: un ticket DE + event (without an article).

question: a plane ticket + a train ticket + a theatre ticket

question: a beef / beefs
answer: un bœuf ('ohf') / des bœufs ('oh'); The F is pronounced in the singular form but not in the plural form. NB: The overlapping oe symbol is perhaps from Latin. Think of it as OE. OEU is pronounced 'oh' - like water.

question: When you enter a restaurant how do you ask for place to eat/drink?

question: Can you make a recommendation? ...to a waiter in a restaurant
answer: Qu'est-ce que vous me conseillez? / Qu'est-ce que vous me recommandez?

question: I recommend it (to you).
answer: Je te le recommande.

question: the menu
answer: la carte; le menu is like the pre-fixe for the day

question: For a starter I would like...and for drink I would like...
answer: Comme entrée je prends...et comme boisson je prends; Use PRENDRE (to take) is used instead 'to want' or 'to like' in this scenario.; To be even more idiomatic french - start with a prepositional phrase before making the request (e.g. Moi...je... OR Pour moi...je...)

question: I'll take (order) water.
answer: Je prends de l'eau. (feminine starting with vowel); The quantity is not specified at all so use partitive articles (du/d' + de la/de l' + des/d').; de la becomes de l' because the noun starts with a vowel.

question: I would like some juice. + One glass of juice please.
answer: Je voudrais DES jus. (Use DES because it is the plural article to indicate 'some' juice.) + Une verre DE jus s'il vous plaît. (use DE because you are giving a quantity OF something)

question: to grab a drink (like with a friend)
answer: prendre un verre; If we were using BOIRE then the verb must be followed by DE. But here we are using PRENDRE so DE is not required.

question: idiomatic way to say: Next round is on me!
answer: C'est ma tournée.; Literally: It's my turn.

question: the meal
answer: le repas ...s is silent

question: list five french meals

question: list the verbs for eating five french meals
answer: PRENDRE le petit déjeuner + DÉJEUNER ('day-juh-nay') + PRENDRE un brunch / ALLER bruncher + GOÛTER + DÎNER

question: a starter + a main dish + a dessert

question: a desert (area of land filled with sand)

question: What are two unique french desserts that can be given as gifts? (one is fancy/formal; one is more casual)
answer: 1) marron glacé (iced chestnuts) are an expensive delacy great for gifts; 2) des chouquettes are similar to doughnut holes covered in clumps of sugar - like bringing doughnuts to work... a treat but very common and not overly fancy

question: No dessert please.
answer: Pas de dessert S.V.P.; Alternative: Non merci.

question: How do you ask for something at a store/market? e.g. Ask for flour.
answer: First you always greet (e.g. bonjour!) and then ask for a general amount: Bonjour je voudrais de la farine.; Then - after they know what you are talking about - you specify the amount... 500 grammes de farine.; Never ever say 'je veux...' which is very rude. If the other person is in a rush then it is possible to say 'un baguette s.v.p.' but this is an exception.

question: When ordering something in a market/store/etc. how do you construct the opening phrase?
answer: Use the partitive articles (du/d' + de la/de l' + des/d') initially to indicate an unspecified quantity.; e.g. Bonjour je voudrais du café / de la farine / de l'huile / des pommes; NB: du = de + le and des = de + les because 'de le' and 'de les' are not used. D' occurs when du or des are followed by a noun that starts with a vowel.

question: When ordering something in a market/store/etc. how do you construct the second half of the phrase?
answer: After opening with a general statement of what you want in unspecified quanities... then specify the amount. Doing so will replaces partitive articles with DE or D' - only two options.; e.g. 500 grammes de café / un paquet de salade / une carafe d'eau / plus de pommes.; D' occurs when de is followed by a noun that starts with a vowel.

question: the delivery
answer: la livraison

question: Do you (formal) have pumpkin?
answer: Vous avez du potiron? (masculine); The quantity is not specified at all so use partitive articles (du/d' + de la/de l' + des/d').; de + le = du

question: Do you have pears?.
answer: Vous avez des poires? (plural); The quantity is not specified at all so use partitive articles (du/d' + de la/de l' + des/d').; de + les = des

question: I would like onion.
answer: Je voudrais d'oignon. (masculine starting with vowel); The quantity is not specified at all so use partitive articles (du/d' + de la/de l' + des/d').; de + le = du. du becomes d' because the noun starts with a vowel.

question: I would like salad.
answer: Je voudrais de la salade. (feminine); The quantity is not specified at all so use partitive articles (du/d' + de la/de l' + des/d').

question: I'll take (order) green beans.
answer: Je prends d'haricot verts (plural starting with vowel).; The quantity is not specified at all so use partitive articles (du/d' + de la/de l' + des/d').; de + les = des. des becomes d' because the noun starts with a vowel.

question: I want 500 grams of meat.
answer: Je veux 500 grammes de viande.; This is what you say after you requested 'some' (general amount) of meat.; Now you express yourself more directly (I want) and you give a specific amount.; Because there is a specified amount we use a more generalized preposition that doesn't care about gender or number - there are only two options: DE (if the noun starts with a consonant) or D' (if the noun starts with a vowel) - both regardless of gender and number

question: a bottle of oil
answer: une bouteille d'huile; Use DE (or D' if noun starts with vowel) when you are talking about a specific amount OR a lack of something

question: a karafe of water
answer: une karafe d'eau ('doh'); This is how you order a bottle of tap water in a restaurant.; Use DE because karafe is a quantity.

question: a head of garlic
answer: une tête d'ail ('dile'); same sound as taille (size); Use DE (or D' if noun starts with vowel) when you are talking about a specific amount OR a lack of something

question: a clove of garlic
answer: une gousse d'ail ('goos' 'dile'); Use DE (or D' if noun starts with vowel) when you are talking about a specific amount OR a lack of something

question: a piece of cheese
answer: un morceau de fromage; Use DE (or D' if noun starts with vowel) when you are talking about a specific amount OR a lack of something

question: 200 grams salt
answer: 200 grammes de sel; Use DE (or D' if noun starts with vowel) when you are talking about a specific amount OR a lack of something

question: a little pepper
answer: un peu de poirve; 'a little' is actually a specified amount; Use DE (or D' if noun starts with vowel) when you are talking about a specific amount OR a lack of something

question: a lot of oil
answer: beaucoup d'huile ('dweel') - it all runs together; 'a lot' is actually a specified amount; Use DE (or D' if noun starts with vowel) when you are talking about a specific amount OR a lack of something

question: a pinch of salt
answer: une pincée de sel; 'a pinch' is actually a specified amount; Use DE (or D' if noun starts with vowel) when you are talking about a specific amount OR a lack of something

question: I have a cat. I do not have a cat.
answer: J'ai UN chat. Je n'ai pas DE chat.; Add DE because ne pas (none) is a treated like a quantity so you have to add DE before a noun that follows.; NB: If what follows (after PAS) is verb then DE is not required.

question: No zuchini. / No onion.
answer: pas de courgette; A negative amount is considered a specific amount. So we use the non-specific prepositions that don't care about gender or number: DE (if the noun starts with a consonant) or D' (if the noun starts with a vowel)

question: No onion.
answer: pas d'oignon; A negative amount is considered a specific amount. So we use the non-specific prepositions that don't care about gender or number: DE (if the noun starts with a consonant) or D' (if the noun starts with a vowel)

question: an amount (of something)
answer: There are two words depending on context. 1) un nombre 2) un montant (only used for financial amounts)

question: Is it correct? (like when a vendor cuts something and asks for confirmation on the size)
answer: ça va ça?

question: Who is next? Me - it's my turn.
answer: C'est à qui? C'est à moi.

question: fake news
answer: l'infox

question: the news + in the news
answer: les actualités OR les informations + DANS l'actualité; Do NOT use les nouvelles. This does not work in the plural form to describe news.; But you can use in the singular form: une bonne nouvelle = a good thing that happened that you want to share with someone

question: I learned about the news on the news.
answer: J'ai appris l'actualité aux informations.

question: I have big news to share.

question: good news + bad news + no news

question: a novelty

question: a news report/show

question: It was published in 2020.

question: the newspaper + the newspapers

question: What are the three major newspapers in France and their place on the political spectrum?
answer: Libération (left) + Le Monde (center-left) + Figaro (right)

question: the front page of a newspaper

question: What are the four major forms of the word for 'all' in french (masc sing + fem sing + masc pl + fem pl)?; Specify the pronunciation of each.
answer: masc sing: tout ('too') + fem sing: toute ('toot') + masc pl: tous ('too') + fem pl: toutes ('toot'); The best way to remember the pronuncation is that it is generally 'too' when masculine and 'toot' when feminine.

question: all type of dance
answer: toutes les danses

question: ballet (the dance form - not the location/performance)
answer: la danse classique

question: I like to go to the ballet.
answer: J'aime le ballet.; Do not use ALLER + À in this case.

question: I like to go to the opera.
answer: J'aime al opera.; Do not use ALLER + À in this case.

question: I like to ski.
answer: J'aime faire du ski.; When it is appropriate to use a verb directly following AIMER then you do not need any preposition between AIMER and the infinitive of the thing that you like doing.

question: gardening + to garden
answer: le jardinage +  jardiner / faire du jardinage

question: leisure activities / places to go out
answer: des sorties / des lieux pour faire des sorties

question: the park or the garden
answer: le jardin ('shar-don'); This is how you refer to both a garden in a home and a public park.

question: the community garden

question: the vegetable garden
answer: le potager; Watch the pronunciation so it does not get confused with: le potage = the soup

question: the map of Paris
answer: le plan de Paris; la carte can also be used for map

question: I walked to the museum.
answer: J'ai marché jusqu'au musée.; Use MARCHER when you are walking purposefully but you cannot use MARCHER + À. (J'ai marché au musée is impossible.); Use JUSQUE when you there is some distance and you are walking until the end.; Alternative: If you want to use À then you could say: Je suis allé(e) au musée. OR Je suis allé(e) à pied au musée.

question: I walked toward the school.
answer: J'ai marché vers l'ecole.; Use MARCHER when you are walking purposefully but you cannot use MARCHER + À.; Use VERS to mean 'towards'.

question: I walked around Paris.

question: When do the standard rules for possessive adjectives not apply? ...what are the exceptions?

question: What is an independent possessive pronoun?
answer: An independent possessive pronoun is a shortcut for showing ownership where the pronoun stands on its own instead of being an adjective to the noun that is possessed. For example: This is my cat. 'my' is a possessive pronoun. 'cat' is the noun being possessed (by me). BUT... This cat is mine. 'mine' is the independent possessive pronoun - you could eliminate the cat entirely: It is mine.

question: How do you construct the independent possessive pronouns in french? (e.g. mine)
answer: There are two ways to express these in french. In both cases you need a second word. 1) DEFINITE ARTICLE + non-generic posessive pronoun: e.g. C'est mien. = It's mine. ...if the noun (that is owned) is singular/masculine. Both the article and the possessive pronoun change to adapt to the gender and number of the noun being owned. 2) À + generic tonique pronoun: e.g. La chat est à moi. = The cat is mine. These pronouns do not adapt to the number and gender of the possessed noun.

question: What are all the forms (masc sing + fem sing + masc pl + masc pl) of the possessive pronouns that mean 'mine'?

question: How are these words pronounced differently? toy + player + day + toy

The word is one syllable but you actually hear two vowel sounds. question: a photograph + a picture (in a book)
answer: un photo + une image

answer: une illustration OR un dessin; un tableau could also be used if the drawing is mounted - like a work of art

question: a painting

question: a collage + graffiti
answer: un collage + un graffiti

question: an artifact
answer: un artefact

question: a material + a component
answer: un matériau + un composant; electrical parts (of a machine) = des composants électroniques

question: a detail

answer: un trasformateur OR un transfo (for short)

question: the voltage
answer: le voltage; Le voltage au USA est la moitié de le voltage en Europe. = The voltage in the US is half the voltage in Europe.; moitié moins is a more familiar way to express 'half of'

question: the heating
answer: le chauffage (could mean a boiler but could be any heating system); le style de chauffage = the type of heating

question: a radiator + a boiler

question: a clothes pin

question: the clothes hamper (for dirty clothes)

question: the laundry (the clothes to being washed or dried)

question: the laundry detergent (dry)

question: the fabric softener
answer: l'adoucissant or l'assouplissant; both are masculine

question: the iron (for ironing clothes)
answer: le fer à repasser ('fe-ra-ra-pa-say')

question: the ironing board

question: a vacuum cleaner

question: the mop

question: the broom
answer: le balai-brosse

question: the bleach

question: garbage/rubbish in general
answer: Two options: 1) les ordures: refers to household garbage 2) les déchets: refers to anything that is not useful ('trash') e.g. les déchets radioactifs = radioactive waste  3) le gaspillage = the waste e.g. le gaspillage alimentaire = food waste

question: a piece of trash
answer: une ordure OR un déchet; une ordure can also mean 'an insult'

question: a ladder
answer: une échelle; This can also refer to the scale on a map or the scale of a house etc. But it does NOT refer to scales for weights(la balance).

answer: un tableau; NB: tableau can also mean painting

question: a pen + a pencil
answer: un stylo + un crayon; In figurative writing one might refer to the writing instrument as la plume (the writing plume).

question: tissues

answer: un évier + un lavabo

question: a dishwasher
answer: un lave-vaisselle ('lav-veh-sell'); One syllable is dropped completely.

question: the dishwashing detergent
answer: le liquide vaisselle

question: a refrigerator
answer: un réfrigérateur / un frigidaire / un frigo

question: a freezer
answer: un congélateur

question: a countertop
answer: un plan de travail

question: a stove(top)

question: a microwave
answer: un micro-onde

question: a toaster
answer: un gille-pain

question: an electric mixer (for cooking)

question: a shredder (for shredding cheese)
answer: une râpe

question: a citrus press
answer: un press-agrume

question: a kettle + a coffeemaker
answer: une bouilloire + une cafetière

question: a crock / a large pot for cooking

answer: une casserole; Do not use the word 'pot' because this means jar in french.

question: a skillet
answer: une poêle ('pwal'); The same word is used for a stove so you need context to understand the meaning.

answer: une assiette + un plat

question: the dishes (may include cups and plates)

question: a bowl

question: the jar
answer: le pot; Also use this word for a potted plant and for a cup of gelato.

question: a cup
answer: une tasse; This is probably the word for mug too.

question: a goblet (a glass with a stem)
answer: un verre à pied

question: a measuring cup
answer: un verre doseur

question: a bottle
answer: une bouteille ('boot-aye')

question: the cutlery
answer: les couverts; masculine when singular

question: a fork

question: a spoon
answer: une cuillére ('kee-yer')

question: a knife
answer: un couteau ('koo-tow'); un couteau á pain = a bread knife

question: a pocket knife
answer: un couteaux de poche; une arme blanche = the name for any weapon with a blade

question: a cutting board

answer: une spatule + une louche

answer: un tire-bouchon

answer: un cendrier; les cendres = ashes

question: a stamp

question: a tablecloth

answer: un bain

question: a shower
answer: une douche

question: a shower head + a shower cap
answer: les pommeaux de douche + un bonnet de douche

question: a drain
answer: une bonde

question: a faucet
answer: un robinet

question: a towel rack (mounted on the wall)

question: a sanitary napkin
answer: une serviette hygiénique

question: the toilet paper
answer: le papier toilette

question: the tiling

question: a material
answer: une matière

answer: le bois + en bois; NB: en chêne = made of oak

question: the cotton + made of cotton
answer: le coton + en coton

question: the wool + made of wool
answer: la laine + en laine ('len')

question: the leather + made of leather
answer: le cuir + en cuir

question: the clay + made of clay
answer: l'argile + en argile

question: the metal + made of metal
answer: le métal + en métal

question: a medal
answer: une médaille

question: the cardboard + made of cardboard

answer: en plastique + en caoutchouc ('cow-ooch')

question: the wax + made of wax
answer: le cire + en cire

question: the straw + made of straw (like a woven hat)
answer: la paille + en paille

question: I like fluffy things.
answer: J'aime les choses mouelleuses.; touffu translates to 'bushy' and can be used to describe fluffy animals

question: comfortable
answer: comfortable (to describe a piece of furniture) OR à l'aise (to describe a person 'at ease'); Do NOT use comfortable to describe a person.

question: Do you feel more at ease?
answer: Est-ce que tu te sens plus à l'aise?; Sens if pronounced 'sohnS'. The S is pronounced.

answer: J'étais MAL à l'aise.

answer: Il aime mettre ses amis mal à l'aise.; mal à l'aise = uncomfortable

answer: Le loyer est de combien?

answer: De combien sont les charges?

answer: Quelle est votre/ton addresse?; addresse is feminine singular so Quelle and ta must agree with it - but we cannot say 'ta ad..' because that is two vowels next to eachother so we change the possessive adjective from ta to ton!

question: my mailing address
answer: mon adresse postale; adresse is feminine BUT we cannot write/say ma adresse (two vowels) so we change it to mon addresse; remember to link the words together ('mo-na-dres')

answer: une lettre + une carte postale

question: How do you say a postal code? e.g. 33200
answer: trente-trois-mil-deuxcents ('33 mil 200'); you speak it as if it is a full number

answer: pour trois nuits

question: country code (for phone numbers)
answer: code pays

question: the number of rooms (in an apartment)
answer: le nombre de pièce; Do not use numèro in this case. Nombre is the quantity. Numèro is a specific number like an address or phone number.

question: the number of pages
answer: le nombre de pages; Do not use numèro in this case. Nombre is the quantity. Numèro is a specific number like an address or phone number.

question: to dial a phone number
answer: faire le numéro (less formal) / composer le numéro (more formal)

question: to ring (to make the sound of ringing)

question: a phone/video call
answer: un appel

answer: passer un coup de fil (more idiomatic) OR téléphoner

answer: recevoir un coup de fil DE quelqu'un

answer: décrocher OR rèpondre au téléphone

answer: raccrocher; idiomatic phrase: raccrocher au nez de quelqu'un = to hang up on someone

answer: être au téléphone

answer: teléphoner à Tom

question: to leave a message
answer: laisser un message; tomber sur le téléphone = to hit the answering machine

question: to be addicted to being on the telephone
answer: être pendu au téléphone OR passer sa vie au téléphone

answer: Vous êtes (bien) madame? monsieur? (casual) / C'est de la part de qoi? means Who is it? (formal)

question: What do you say when someone first picks up the phone to introduce yourself when you are calling?
answer: Bonjour c'est X. (informal) / Mme Sarah Jones à l'appareil. (formal)

answer: Je suis bien chez X? or Je suis bien ___the phone number___?

answer: Je vous/toi le passe.

answer: Voulez-vous rappeler? Voulez-vous laisser un message?

question: a cell phone + a land-line telephone + old-fashioned telephone
answer: un portable + un teléphone fixe + le combiné; The generic word for a phone is un téléphone.

question: a charger (for a telephone)
answer: le chargeur

question: to hold up a phone to take a picture
answer: SORTIR un portable pour prendre un photo; Use SORTIR (instead of tirer).

question: a battery of a device (like a flashlight) + a battery of a large machine (like a car)
answer: une pile (not rechargeable) + une batterie (rechargeable); à usage unique = for one-time use

question: to charge a battery
answer: RECHARGER une batterie

question: I forgot to charge my telephone. + I forgot my telephone charger.
answer: J'ai oublié DE rechargeur mon portable. + J'ai oublié mon chargeur de portable.

question: I don't have any battery (remaining) for phone or laptop.
answer: Je n'ai pas de batterie.

question: a text message + messaging
answer: un SMS + le messagerie (instantanée)

question: an email address
answer: une adresse mail; un courriel is a new word for email - it is the combination of courrier (old way to send physical mail) + the word for mail; courrier_mail is also used

question: an email
answer: un email ('ee-mail'; Do not pronounce the E like a french E.)

question: www.gmail.com + ".fr"
answer: trois W ('twa-doo-bluh-vay') gmail point ('pwa') com + point F R ('pwa-eff-ehr')

question: to attach + an attachment
answer: (se) joindre + une pièce jointe

question: The document is attached.; Give the formal and the informal versions.
answer: Formal: Je vous prie de trouver ci-joint le document. (Replace 'je vous prie' with 'nous vous prions' if writing on behalf of a company or couple.); Informal: Voici le documente en pièce jointe.

question: encrypted
answer: crypté(e)

question: a computer + a laptop
answer: un ordinateur + un ordinateur portable; NB: The noun starts with a vowel so you link the sounds ('uhnnnor-dee-na-toor).; une unité centrale = a mainframe computer

question: a screen + an iPad
answer: un écran + une tablette

question: a keyboard + a key (on the keyboard)
answer: un clavier + une touche; le piano = the entire piano; le clavier = the keyboard of a piano

question: a computer mouse
answer: la souris ('soo-ree'); Same word as the animal and when 'to smile' is conjugated.; Same pronounciation as the conjugated forms of SOURIRE (to smile): Je souris. ('soo-ree') = I smile.

question: a USB thumbnail
answer: une clé USB

question: a floppy disk
answer: une diskette

question: an external/internal hard drive
answer: un disque dur externe/interne

question: a CD player
answer: un lecteur de CD

question: a printer + a scanner
answer: une imprimante + un scanner

question: a sensor + a detector
answer: un capteur + un détecteur

question: VR (virtual reality) headset
answer: les lunettes de realité virtual

question: headphones
answer: les écouteurs (liaison z between; masculine); another older word for headphones is: un casque audio

question: a speaker
answer: There are two options: 1) un haut-parleur = the actual speaker. This is the word to use when you reference the speakers of a computer.  2) une enciente = a loud-speaker or amp (amplifier). It may contain multiple individual speakers (haut-parleurs).

question: What is the idiomatic way to express: In programming... (when you want to speak about the computer science domain)
answer: En informatique...

question: a programming language
answer: un langage de programmation; NB: le langue refers to natual languages like English and French. le langage refers to language as a general phenomenon or ability.

question: a programming library (targeting specific functionality)
answer: une bibliothèque logicielle

question: a programming framework (providing a broad functionality for an application) + a web framework
answer: un framework informatique + un framework web

question: How do you describe a programming framework?
answer: une boîte à outils; This translates to 'toolbox' and it is an idiomatic way to explain a framework or library to non-technical people.

question: a function / functionality (of a program or app)
answer: la fonction

question: the speed + the memory (related to computers)
answer: la vitesse + le mémoire (not souvenir which is used to describe a remembered experience)

question: to save or backup a digital document
answer: sauvegarder

question: the internet + the internet provider
answer: l'internet (feminine) + le fournisseur d'acces

question: the wifi + the fiber
answer: le wifi ('wee-fee') + le fibre

question: to be online (on the internet)
answer: être en ligne

question: the bandwidth (potential) + the data transfer rate (actual)
answer: la bande passante + le débit (also used in physics to mean the flow rate)

question: There is no signal (for wifi). + There is no signal (for mobile phone).

question: a tech company (like Google)

question: a webpage + a website + my website
answer: un page internet + un site ('seet') internet/web + mon site internet/web

question: the domain name (of a website; e.g. www.nike.com)
answer: le domaine

question: a computer application
answer: une application informatique

question: a social network/platform (online)
answer: un réseau social ('rue-so-so-see-ehl'); When a french word ends in -CIAL pronounce it the same as the word for sky: ciel.; un réseau = a network

question: a strong network (of people for getting a job etc.)
answer: un réseau social solide

question: a dating app/site

question: Do adjectives come before or after the noun they describe?
answer: Generally adjectives follow the noun that they describe. But there are many exceptions. Some categories of adjectives are always placed before the noun. For example: Salutations like Bonne week-end! Bonne nuit. For example: Adjectives that indicate order/class (premier/première + dernier/dernière + etc) are placed before the noun they describe.; It is also true that some adjectives can be used on either side of the noun and the placement changes the meaning.

question: Which adjectives almost always come before the noun they are describing (instead of after it as expected)?
answer: autre + long + court + jeune + nouveau + vieux/vielle + petit(e) + grand(e) + gros(se) + joli(e) + mal/mauvais + beau/belle/beaux (beautiful; m/f/pl) + bon/bonne/bons/bonnes (good) + meilleur/meilleure/meilleurs/meilleures (better) + le meilleur/ la meilleure/ les meilleurs/ les meilleures (best); NB: When adjectives are used to indicate order/class (premier/première + dernier/dernière + etc) then they are also placed before the noun they describe.; NB: The masculine singular versions of these adjectives may change spelling if the noun begins with a vowel or silent H.

question: What changes when an adjective is placed before a noun instead of after it (as is the general case)?
answer: When an adjective is placed before a noun then the spelling of that noun becomes important. If the noun starts with a vowel then it may change the spelling of the adjective. This is most common for adjectives that end in -eau and -eux. For example: The masculine singular version of 'old' is vieux. But an old man = un vieil (not vieux) homme because H is treated as a vowel.

question: When an adjective can be placed either before a noun or after a noun - what does the placement indicate?
answer: There are many adjectives that change meaning completely depending on whether they are placed before or after the noun. But for the other adjectives that are generally always placed after a noun (e.g. magnifique) then the placement before the noun indicates a more emphathetic or subjective value. e.g. un paysage magnifique vs un magnifique paysage. The second example is more empathetic/subjective.

question: What is the general rule for adapting adjectives to gender and number?
answer: Add E to form feminine singular - this will force the pronunciation of the final consonant (that was silent in the masculine singular form) but it's a light touch on the consonant...it's not hard or heavy; Add S to form masculine plural; Add ES to form feminine plural; No change in pronunciation from the singular to plural forms of the same gender because the S and ES are generally silent.; There are many different variations of adjectives but this is the most basic transformation.

question: When do adjectives have the same spelling and pronunciation for masculine and feminine and plural?
answer: Generally any adjective that ends in an E or S or X in the masculine form is spelled the same in the feminine form.

question: What is the difference in pronunciation between bon (good/masc) + bonne (good/fem) + beau (beautiful/masc)?
answer: The first two have an extreme nasal quality: 'boh' and 'bohn'. Shoot the sound up at the roof of the mouth and out the nose. The third (beau - like beaucoup) is not nasal and sounds exactly like the word 'bow' in English.

question: What is the difference in pronunciation between beau (beautiful/masc) + beaucoup?

question: What are the two major rules (not exhaustive) for transforming an adjective to an adverb (e.g. blind to blindly)?
answer: 1) If the masculine adjective ends in vowel (e.g. vrai + absolu + probable): Add -MENT (e.g. vraiment).; 2) If masculine adjectives ends in consonant (e.g. amical + heureux + long): Select the feminine adjective and add -MENT (e.g. amicalement + heureusement + longuement).; These 2 rules ensure that adverbs have a vowel immediately preceding the -MENT ending. Sometimes (no rule of thumb) we add an accent to that E (e.g. obscur = obscure; obscurÉment = obscurely).; NB: Adverbs do not change form to agree with gender/number because they modify verbs - not nouns.

question: How do you transform an adjective that ends in -ANT or -ENT to an adverb?
answer: Replace -ant with -AMMENT. Replace -ent with -EMMENT.; e.g. apparENT becomes apparEMMENT; NB: This is a group of exceptions from the general two rules for transforming adjectives to adverbs.

question: pleasant vs unpleasant
answer: agréable vs désagréable; adjectives that end in E are the same in masculine and feminine form

question: He is in a good mood. + He is in a bad mood.
answer: Il est DE bonne humeur. + Il est DE muavais humeur.; ÊTRE + DE + bonne/muavais humeur; a mood = une humeur

question: optimistic + pessimistic
answer: optimiste + pessimiste OR défaitiste; Adjectives that end in E in the masculine form are spelled the same in the feminine form.

question: dynamic
answer: dynamique; This means that someone is moving around a lot / doing a lot of things / involved in lots of activities. It is not the correct word to use for someone that has a lot of dimensions to their personality.

question: cultured + informed
answer: cultivé(e) + informé(e)

question: punctual
answer: ponctuel(le)

question: modest
answer: modeste; adjectives that end in E are the same in masculine and feminine form

question: He is modest. 3 ways to express this.
answer: Il est modeste. Il est un homme modeste. C'est un homme modeste.

question: poor
answer: pauvre (same m/f); Pauvre means poor when it is placed after the noun (in the normal location). Otherwise it means 'in a bad mood'.

question: a poor man + a man in a bad situation
answer: un homme pauvre + un pauvre homme; The meaning of pauvre changes based on the location of the adjective.

question: to live in poverty
answer: vivre dans une situation de pauvreté; le niveau de pauvreté = the poverty line

question: rich
answer: riche (same m/f); This is a general adjective. It can mean super-rich or moderately-rich.

question: funny/silly
answer: rigolo(te) OR drôle; This generally has a positive connotation.

question: fun (as an adjective)
answer: marrant(e) / amusant(e); Both can be used to express fun. Ils n'est pas marrant. = He's not much fun. C'est amusant. = It's fun.

question: for fun
answer: pour me divertir

question: entertaining
answer: divertissant(e); Only use this to describe something that is actively entertaining - not just fun or nice.; le divertissement = the entertainment

question: ways to describe a place that mean fun or nice
answer: 1) avec un environnement agréable 2) où on peut passer un bon moment; Divertissant (= entertaining) is used to describe something that is more actively entertaining. Do not use it just to mean 'fun' or 'nice'.

question: spontaneous
answer: spontané(e)

question: energetic + energizing
answer: + énergique + énergisant(e); Same meanings as in english.

question: She has a lot of energy.
answer: Elle est EN plein énergie. (literally: She is full of energy.); Alternative: Elle a beaucoup d'énergie. But this is less idiomatic than 'en plein énergie'.

question: I have too much energy.
answer: J'ai trop d'énergie.; trop (too much) is a quantity so you follow it with DE.

question: gratifying
answer: gratifiant(e)

question: pretty
answer: joli(e) (m/f)

question: ugly
answer: moche / laid(e); laid is pronounced 'lay'. laide is pronouced 'layd'.

question: mean
answer: méchant(e); a casual way to express this is bête bête which contracts when you pronounce it to ('buh-bet')

question: malicious / back-stabbing
answer: médisant(e)

question: suspicious (not trustworthy)
answer: suspect(e) OR méfiant(e)

question: questionable
answer: critiqable; literally: able to be critiqued or open to critique

question: foodie / really loves the food
answer: gourmand / gourmande (m/f); e.g. Il est gourmand.; idiomatic french

question: A common french expression when you love some food to an extreme; In English it's similar to... I'd kill for it.
answer: C'est une tuerie. The literal translation is: It is a killer.; tuer = to kill

question: the ambiance of the café
answer: l'ambiance DU café (de + le = du)

question: How do you talk about the energy of a big city?
answer: l'ambiance animé; literaly: the lively atmosphere

question: to smoke (cigarettes) + to smoke marijuana
answer: fumer + fumer de l'herbe/juane; juane is a shortened form of marijuana

question: an ashtray + the ashes
answer: le cendrier + les cendres

question: to be hungover
answer: avoir la gueule de bois

question: drunk + totally drunk
answer: ivre (same m/f pronounced 'eehvr') is the best word to use + ivre mort ('eevrehmor') = totally drunk; Alternatives: bourré(e) is slang. saoûlt ('soo') is another option. Tipsy is the same in english/french.

question: the noun for drunkeness / inebriation
answer: la ivresse ('eeh-vres')

question: to take drugs
answer: se doper

question: the drugs (street drugs) + edibles (e.g. marijuana)
answer: les drogues + comestible

question: Edibles are better than smoking weed.
answer: Les comestibles sont meilleurs que de fumer de l'herbe.

question: an addiction
answer: une dépendance

question: unregulated + illegal
answer: pas régulé + pas légal; illegally = illégalement

question: controversial
answer: controversable OR controversé(e)

question: cooked
answer: cuit ('quee') / cuite ('queet')

question: raw + the raw vegetables
answer: cru / crue (m/f) + les légumes crus

question: chopped
answer: X en morceaux ('moor-soh'); e.g. oignon en morceaux

question: soft
answer: doux/douce (m/f); This word means both soft and sweet in french. It is used to describe something that is physically soft. It is used to mean the opposite of strong. e.g. The odor of this cheese is muted. = L'odeur de ce fromage est douce.

question: sweet
answer: sucré(e); Alternative: doux/douce (m/f) means both soft and sweet. e.g. le cidre sec / le cidre doux = the dry cider / the sweet cider

question: salty or salted
answer: salé / salée (m/f); NB: This can be used to express a high bill. e.g. Ma facture est salée. = My invoice/bill is high.; NB: This is different from the word for dirty: sale (without accent).

question: sour
answer: aigre; aigre-doux = sweet-sour

question: spicy
answer: épicé / épicée (m/f)

question: hot
answer: chaud(e) (m/f); The D is silent ('show') unless the final E is present.

question: cold (in terms of temperature) + cold (like a person / aloof)
answer: same adjective for both meanings: froid(e) (m/f); Make sure to pronounce the R. Otherwise it sounds like fois or foie gras.

question: to heat/warm + to cool
answer: chauffer + refroidir

question: I am heating the towels.
answer: Je réchauffe les serviettes.; CHAUFFER = to heat. Use RÉCHOUFFER to emphasize that it is a repetitive or non-permanent activity.

question: emotional + lacking emotion
answer: émotif/émotive (m/f) + impassible

question: emotionally speaking.... + physically speaking...
answer: émotionnellement parlant... + physiquement parlant...; These are great phrases that you can place anywhere in a sentence when you need to indicate that the words you are using are intended to reference either emotions or something physical. e.g. Je me sens - émotionnellement parlant - que...

question: warm (in terms of a person/welcoming) + open-minded
answer: chaleureux / chaleureuse (m/f) + ouvert(e) d'esprit

question: full + empty
answer: plein(e) / vide (same m/f)

question: filled
answer: remplé(e); To express this adjective use the verb REMPLIR (to fill). To turn it into an adjective add é(e).

question: open + closed
answer: ouvert ('ooh-ver') + fermé ('fer-meh')

question: daily (e.g. daily routine) + on a daily basis; Specify pronunciation.
answer: quotidien/quotidienne (m/f) + au quotidien ("koh-tee-dyohn"; Strong O sound to start and then finish with a very nasal E.); e.g. the daily routine = la routine quotidienne

question: dirty
answer: sale (same m/f); NB: This is different from salé(e) which means salty.

question: clean + the cleanliness
answer: propre (same m/f) + la propreté; propre: It connotes ownership when placed before the noun. It means clean when placed after the noun.

question: her clean apartment + her own apartment
answer: son appartement propre + son propre appartement; propre: It connotes ownership when placed before the noun. It means clean when placed after the noun.

question: luxurious
answer: luxueux/luxueuse (m/f); luxury goods = des produits de luxe

question: blurry / fuzzy (like a vision or memory)
answer: flou(e)

question: My memory is blurry.
answer: Mon souvenir est flou.; flou(e) = blurry

question: true + false
answer: vrai(e) and faux/fousse (m/f); NB: vrai (true) is the adjective base for the adverb vraiment ('vray-mohn') which is a super common word (same as english... really?! = vraiment?!); NB: Transform an adjective that ends in a vowel (vrai) by adding -MENT.

question: the truth
answer: la vérité

question: official + fake
answer: officiel(le) + faux/fousse; faux/fousse means both 'false' and 'fake'

question: quiet + muted + silent
answer: calme (also means calm) + muet/muette (m/f) + silencieux/silencieuse (m/f)

question: calm + not calm
answer: calme/tranquille/zen (all same m/f) + inquiet/inquiète (m/f); Alternative for calm: résistant au stress

question: to worry + the concerns
answer: S'INQUIÉTER + les inquiétudes; Alternative word for a concern: une préoccupation

question: loud/noisy + loudly
answer: bruyant(e) + bruyamment; This follows a rule for transforming adjectives to adverbs: If adjective ends in -ANT or -ENT then remove -NT and add -AMMENT or -EMMENT respectively.

question: the noise
answer: le bruit

question: out loud
answer: à voix haute; e.g. She read out loud. = Elle a lu à voix haute.

question: fast + quickly
answer: rapid(e) OR vite ('veet') + rapidement OR vite (same as the adjective); Use rapid(e)/rapidement when something IS fast. (e.g. Le train est rapid.) Use vite/vite when someone or something does something quickly. (e.g. Il parle trop vite.)

question: the speed
answer: la vitesse

question: slow + slowly
answer: lent ('lon') + lentement; This is an exception in how to form an adverb because normally if an adjective ends in -ENT then the adverb ends in -EMMENT with double M.

question: quicker / with more ease
answer: avec plus de facilité; This is a good alternative to plus rapid(e) and plus vite.

question: efficient
answer: efficace

question: spacious
answer: spacieux / spacieuse ...is an exception - doesn't follow the 'rules' for gender

question: cramped / too small
answer: exigu/exiguë

question: crowded
answer: bondé(e); Alternative ways to say this: très peuplé / il y a trop de monde

question: the crowd
answer: la foule / trop de monde / l'affluence

question: Explain the difference between affluence and influence in French.
answer: une affluence = an influx / the number of people attending; une influence = an influence / same in English

question: luminous
answer: lumineux

question: fluid + stacato (when describing the sound of a language)
answer: fluide (same m/f) + saccadé(e); saccadé(e) means abrubt or irregular in movement

question: practical + impractical
answer: pratique + incommode

question: I did it for practical reasons.
answer: Je l'ai fait pour l'aspect pratique.; "raisons pratiques" does not work in french.

question: expensive
answer: cher / chère (m/f); It means beloved if placed before the noun. It means expensive if placed after the noun.

question: an beloved book + an expensive book
answer: un cher livre + un livre cher

question: cheap
answer: pas cher / pas chère (m/f); There is no word for cheap. It is just the opposite of expensive. Or you can use 'bon marché' to mean a good deal.

question: affordable
answer: abordable; Take care when pronouncing this to differentiate it from portable.

question: economical + a good deal
answer: économique + bon marché; Bon marché means good value for money. It is not really a noun or adjective. e.g. C'est bon marché!

question: the opposite of a good deal
answer: un fric fou; This means a waste of money / crazy money.; You can also translate a waste of money literally = une perte d'argent

question: to optimize space (in a room)
answer: maximum de rangement / optimizer le petite espace

question: creative + artistic + strategic
answer: créatif/créative + artistique + calculateur/calculatrice; calculer = to calculate

question: a designer (m/f)
answer: un créateur + une créatrice; Watch out because the word créateur must sound different from créature (pronounced with deep U; means creature).

question: innovative + entrepreneurial
answer: innovant(e) + entreprenant(e)

question: formidable + splendid
answer: formidable + splendid

question: old-fashioned + modern
answer: ancien(ienne) + moderne; NB: ancien(ne): It means the previous version when placed before the noun. It means ancient / very old when placed after the noun.

question: It's a treasure!
answer: C'est un bijeoux!

question: easy + rudimentary + simple
answer: facile (same m/f) + rudimentaire (same m/f) + simple (same m/f); Simply... + Simplement...

question: clear (as in explicit or uncomplicated) + clearly
answer: clair(e) + clairement; NB: explicit/implicit (french: explicite / implicite) are the same meaning and almost same spelling in french.

question: intuitive
answer: intuitif/intuitive (m/f)

question: difficult + hard
answer: difficile (same m/f) + dur(e); durer is the verb that means 'to last/to endure'; dur(e) means 'hard' both figuratively and literally. e.g. Le bois est dur. = The wood is hard.

question: confusing
answer: déroutant(e); If you want to express that someone is confused then use: dérouté(e).; NB: There is no such word as confussant(e) in french! You could use the adjective confus(e) to describe someone who is totally lost. But you cannot use the same root to express that something is confusing.

question: I am confused.
answer: Je suis dérouté(e).; This is the best option because it is the closest translation and because you can use the same base to express that something is confusing: déroutant(e).; Alternatives: confus(e) and perplexe (same m/f). Watch out because you can only use these adjectives to describe someone who is confused. You cannot use these roots to describe something that is confusing.; NB: Confus(e) is very old-fashioned and connotes 'totally lost' instead of just confused.

question: strange
answer: étranger / étrangère (m/f); This is the same word used to say that someone is a foreigner.

question: foreign (as in a foreigner)
answer: étranger ('ay-trohn-jay')/ étrangère ('ay-trohn-jer'); Adjectives that end in IER or ER in the masculine form change to (I)ÉRE to make the feminine form.

question: bilingual
answer: bilingue; Adjectives that end in E in the masculine form are spelled the same in the feminine form.

question: a foreign language
answer: une langue étrangère; NB: The name of a language is generally the masculine form of a country's name. The only times this is not the case is when the name of a country and the name of the language are different (e.g. USA and English).

question: Italian (m/f)
answer: italien/italienne (m/f); Adjectives that end in EN or IEN in the masculine form add NE to make the feminine form.

question: Korean (m/f)
answer: coréen/coréenne; Adjectives that end in EN or IEN in the masculine form add NE to make the feminine form.

question: Spanish (m/f)
answer: espagnol/espagnole (m/f)

question: German (m/f)
answer: allemand/allemande (m/f)

question: Argentinian (m/f)
answer: argentin ('ahr-zhan-tuhn'; IN like INgénieur; masculine) + argentine ('ahr-zhan-teen'; feminine); the country Argentina = l'Argentine (feminine)

question: Greek (m/f) Specify pronunciation.
answer: grec / grecque; Both are pronounced 'grek'. But this is different than the country Greece ('gres').

question: Dutch (m/f)
answer: néerlandais(e); The adjective hollandais(e) exists but it only refers to a part of the Netherlands so avoid it.

question: Chinese (m/f)
answer: chinois/chinoise (m/f)

question: English (m/f) + Brittish (m/f)
answer: anglais(e) + britannique (same m/f); Britain/Brittish refers to the UK (larger than England).

question: England + UK
answer: L'Angleterre (feminine) + Le Royaume-Uni (masculine)

question: North America + South America + Antarctica
answer: l'amérique du nord + l'amérique du sud + l'antarctique

question: Africa + Asia + Europe
answer: l'afrique + l'asia + l'europe

question: African + American + European +
answer: africain(e) + américain(e) + européen(ne); The masculine version: européen ('oo-roh-pay-uh') ends with a sound exactly like the number 1 in french. The feminine version: européenne ('oo-roh-pay-ehN') ends like the feminine endings for the other continents.

question: North American football + South American football (meaning soccer)
answer: football nord-américain + football sud-américain

question: eastern Europe
answer: l'europe de l'Est

question: the European Union
answer: l'Union Européenne; union is feminine; l'U.E is the acronym but say the entire word as a beginner - it's unlikely people will understand someone with a heavy accent if you use the acronym.

question: with locals (like when travelling)
answer: avec des locaux

question: local; Give all the variations: masculine singular + feminine singular + etc.
answer: local (masc sing) / locale (fem sing) / locaux (masc pl) / locales (fem pl); This adjective can mean sourced locally or a person who lives in a location.

question: I prefer local food. + I prefer local produce.
answer: Je préfère la nourriture locale (fem sing). + Je privilégie les produits locaux (masc pl).

question: Those women are locals.
answer: Ces femmes sont des locales.; local/locale/locaux/locales

question: a native American
answer: un natif américain / une native amémicaine; This is the word for a person. There is not a great adjective that means 'native american'. amérindien(e) is an out-dated adjective meaning 'american indian'.

question: a dash
answer: un tiret

question: a slash
answer: slash (same) OR barre de fraction (for division)

question: a comma
answer: une virgule ('veer-gool')

question: a colon (:) + a semi colon
answer: deux points + le point virgule

question: an ellipsis (...)
answer: les points de suspension

question: an apostrophe (')
answer: une apostrophe ('a-po-strof')

question: quotation marks
answer: des guillemets; entre guillemets

question: the parenthesis
answer: la parenthèse

question: a question mark
answer: le point d'interrogation

question: an exclamation point
answer: le point d'exclamation

question: a period (punctuation mark)
answer: le point ('pwoh') ...just say 'pwoh' when spelling an email address

question: In written french which punctuation marks require a space before them?
answer: exclamation marks + questions marks + colons; There is no space between a word and a period.

question: ampersand (@; aka 'at')
answer: une arobase ('ar-row-baz')

question: percent (%)
answer: pour cent (two words)

question: a high percentage
answer: un pourcentage élevé; élevée means raised in the sense of heightened and also in terms of a person being raised by their parents

question: a minority + a majority + an overwhelming majority
answer: une minorité + une majorité + une grande majorité

question: a contraction (of words or syllables)
answer: la contraction: This is the word commonly used in conversation which means a contraction of muscles or sound (like in English).; alternative: 'la forme contractée' is a grammatical term but this may refer to formal contractions found in English (e.g. I'm)

question: uppercase / lowercase
answer: majuscule / minuscule; les majuscules = the upper case letters

question: half
answer: la moitié OR la demi

question: the speed
answer: la vitesse

question: fluently
answer: couramment

question: They buy a boat because they like the see.
answer: Ils achètent un bateau pace qu'ils aiment le mer.; Note how we must us a contraction with apostrophe because PARCE QUE ends in a vowel and ILS begins with a vowel.

question: degrees celsius
answer: degré Celsius

question: degrees fahrenheit
answer: degré Fahrenheit

question: the weather
answer: la météo (technical word) OR le temps (conversational)

question: nice weather
answer: le beau temps; Use temps instead of méteo to express this.

question: The wheather is terrible.
answer: Le temps est horrible.; Use temps instead of méteo to express this.

question: What is the weather like?
answer: Quel temps fait-il ?; idiomatic way to ask the question

question: It's nice (outside - regarding the weather).
answer: There are two ways to express this. The most common: Il fait beau. This generally means it is sunny outside.; The other: Il fait bon. This generally means the weather is agreeable. It's probably the best way to express that it is warm (not hot) outside.; These are both different from how you express that people are nice (e.g. gentil(le) or sympa) or how you express that things are nice (e.g. sympa - not gentil(le).

question: It's six degrees (outside).
answer: Il fait six degrés.; say it as if one word ('eel-fay-ses-deg-ray'); talking about weather uses faire

question: It's hot.
answer: Il fait chaud ('show').

question: I'm hot (in temperature).
answer: J'ai chaud.; Use AVOIR for temperatures.; If you use ÊTRE and if the subject is a person it either does not make sense or means something completely different. e.g. Je suis chaud(e). = I'm on fire.; However it is appropriate to use ÊTRE with temperature for inanimate objects. e.g. The water is hot. = L'eau est chaude. (eau is feminine)

question: The water is too cold.
answer: L'eau est trop froide.; eau is feminine.; It is appropriate to use ÊTRE with temperature for inanimate objects.

question: ...because I'm cold / ...because it's cold
answer: parce que j'ai froid. / parce qu'il fait froid ('fwa').; parce que becomes parce qu'il and it's one word - no pause for the apostrophe

question: a bit chilly
answer: un peu frais; cold = froid ('fwa') but a little cold = frais ('fray'); Alternative: Il fait frisquet. = It's chilly out.

question: It is below freezing. (the weather)
answer: Il fait en dessous de zéro. OR Il fait sous zéro degrées.

question: I have a lot of layers (of clothing).
answer: J'ai beaucoup de couches.; Couche is also the word or diaper.

question: The weather in that region is not good/warm.
answer: La météo dans cette région n'est pas bonne.; Use BONNE because la météo is feminine.

question: idiomatic way to express: the weather is ok but not great
answer: C'est supportable.; Literally: It's tolerable.

question: idiomatic way to express: I can't stand the cold + the heat + ...or anything.
answer: Je ne supporte pas le chaleur + le froid...; SUPPORTER = to be able to withstand

question: I hate being cold.
answer: Je déteste avoir froid.

question: I am always cold.
answer: J'ai tout le temps froid.; Use AVOIR - not ÊTRE - to talk about body temperature.

question: to encourage
answer: encourager; e.g. Je ne voudrais pas encourager ma famille à acheter des cadeaux.

question: It's sunny.
answer: Il fait soleil. OR Il y a du soleil.; The literal translation of the adjective sunny is ensoleillé(e).

question: The sun shines.
answer: Le soleil brille.

question: the rain
answer: la pluie ('ploo-ee')

question: It's raining. + It will rain (futur proche)
answer: Il pleut. / Il fait pleut. ('ploo') + Il va PLEUVOIR; The pronunciation of pleut is the same as peux ('poo') but add an L ('ploo'). It is not 'ploo-ee'.

question: When it is raining...
answer: S'il pleut...

question: to cry/weep + to rain
answer: pleuRER + pleuVOIR

question: He was crying. + It was raining.
answer: Il pleurait (infinitive: pleurer). + Il pleuvait (infinitive: pleuvoir).

question: to yell/scream/shout
answer: crier; NB: Unless other context is given this noun connotes that the yelling is happening because the person being yelled at did something wrong.; CRIER is a faux ami. pleurer = to cry

question: I yell at my mother.
answer: Je crie sur ma mère.; CRIER assumes that you person being yelled at is at fault.

question: I yell to the pompier...Help me!
answer: Je crie au pompier..."aidez-moi".; CRIER assumes that the person being yelled at did something wrong. Je crie sur les pompier. = I yelled at the firemen (because they did something wrong).; If you want to express that you were yelling something to get attention then you have to explain what it is that you yelled.

question: It's snowing. + Is it snowing?
answer: Il neige. + Il va neiger?

question: It's cloudy.
answer: Il y a des nuages (gris).

question: It's windy.
answer: Il y a du vent. (pronounced 'von' ...that nasal ohn sound where lips make o-shape; very different from the word vin which is like 'vehn' with wide mouth like INgénénieur)

question: the title + the film titled X
answer: la titre + le film intitulé(e) X

question: a chapter
answer: un chapitre

question: How do you describe the date that something was made? + This painting was made in 1890.
answer: être réalisé(e) en XXXX + Cette peinture a été réalisée en 1890.

question: How do you describe a bottle of wine (or other fine product) in terms of its age - if it is 25 years old?
answer: Cette bordeaux a 25 ans d'âge.

question: The bottle of wine went bad (or turned).
answer: The best option: La bouteille de vin a tourné.; Alternatives: La bouteille de vin est devenu mauvais. OR La bouteille de vin s'est périmée (infinitive: se périmer)

question: The food is expired. + the expiration date
answer: La nourriture est périmé(e). + la date de péremption

question: spell and pronounce: Burgundy + Bordeaux
answer: Bourgogne ("Bore-goi-ng") + Bordeaux ("Boor-doh")

question: This belongs to the impressionnist movement.
answer: Cela appartient (appartenir) au courant impressioniste.

question: It is a figurative + abstract painting.
answer: C'est une peinture figurative + abstraite.

question: It is an acrylic painting. It is an oil painting.
answer: C'est une peinture acrylique. + C'est une huile sur toile. (literally: oil on canvas)

question: a loyalty
answer: une fidélité; NB: Nouns that end in Y in english often are the same word ending in É in french. And they are feminine in french.

question: the french motto
answer: la devise de la Republique: la liberté l'égalité et la fraternité; une devise = a motto

question: a law + a regulation
answer: une loi + une régle (more like a rule)

question: idiomatic way to express: in the eyes of the law/government
answer: devant la loi

question: idiomatic way to express: Open your eyes! (as in - be aware!)
answer: Ouvre les yeux!

question: compliant (adjective) + in accordance (adverb)
answer: conforme + conformÉment; This is a slightly irregular adverb because we add accent É.

question: a fact; Specify pronunciation.
answer: le fait ('fay'; T is silent); Make sure to differentiate the sound and gender from la fête ('fehT') = the party.

question: stuff
answer: faits divers (= miscellanous facts) is the idiomatic way to express this.

question: the fact that there was a change
answer: le fait qu'il y AIT eu un changement; This phrasing triggers subjonctif passé (être/avoir au subjontif + past participle)

question: a loophole
answer: une faille dans le système is the best contextual translation.; une échappatoire is similar but I think it refers more to the action of escaping or evading in a clever way.

question: a step (in a process) + the steps to follow
answer: une étape ('ay-tap') + les étapes à suivre; e.g. la première étape + la deuxième étape...; NB: un pas = a physical step with a foot

question: to take a step a forward
answer: faire un pas en avant; une étape is a step in the process; un pas is a physical step forward with a foot. It can be used for walking and dancing.

question: a procedure
answer: une procédure

question: Merry Christmas! Happy Holidays!
answer: Joyeux noël! Bonnes fêtes!; NB: Be careful with fêtes. It cannot always be used to translate from holiday and fêtes often means party instead.

question: Happy New Year!
answer: This depends on the date because it is bad luck to wish anyone 'Happy New Year' before it is actually the new year. 1) Before midnight 31 December:Bonnes fêtes ...et une bonne fin d’année!  2) After midnight 31 December: Bonne année! = Happy New Year!

question: during the holidays
answer: pendent les jours fêtes/fériés

question: It was a holiday (like a long weekend linked to a public holiday)
answer: C'était férié.

question: How were your holidays / vacation?
answer: Comment étaient tes vacances?; The subject is your vacation (tes vacances).; The verb (pronounced same as summer - 'eh-tay') is être conjugated in l’imparfait de l’indicatif temps (the imperfect tense within the indicative group; 'imparfait' for short).; Indicative is an umbrella group of verb conjugations - a mood of the verb where a fact / something certain (from the perspective of the speaker) is being communicated.

question: How was your Christmas (holiday)?
answer: Comment étaient tes fêtes de Noël?; The subject is your Christmas holiday.; The verb (pronounced same as summer - 'eh-tay') is être conjugated in the 'imparfait' tense.

question: How was your New Year's Eve?
answer: Comment étaient ton Réveillon?; The subject is your New Year's Eve.; The verb (pronounced same as summer - 'eh-tay') is être conjugated in the 'imparfait' tense.
