question: I am going to take vacation. + I will be on holiday
answer: Je vais prendre des vacances. + Je serai en vacances.

question: the vacation + the sabbatical
answer: les vacances + le congé sabbatique OR une année sabbatique; NB: There is only one word for holidays/vacation in French (les vacances). And it is always plural.; Les vacances is used for any time off throughout the year EXCEPT Christmas/New Years which use different and specific terms.

question: idiomatic saying for when you take a day of vacation between a holiday and a weekend to make an extra long weekend
answer: faire le pont (de vacances)

question: a day off of work/school (for a holiday) + a day off of work/school (for other reasons)
answer: un jour férié + un jour de congés

question: back to school
answer: la rentrée scolaire; but the word for school is une école

question: the school holidays
answer: les vacances scolaires; This can refer to any school holiday (singular) including summer vacation.

question: on Christmas + the Christmas holiday
answer: à Noël + les fêtes de Noël

question: New Year's Eve (31 December)
answer: le Réveillon OR le Nouvel An; NB: The adjective nouveau (masc sing) changes to nouvel when the noun starts with a vowel. This avoids two vowels against eachother. This behavior only happens to some adjectives that are placed before a noun.

question: New Year's Day (1 January)
answer: le jour de l'an OR la nouvelle année

question: Easter + Valentine's Day
answer: Pâques + la saint valentin

question: Mother's/Father's Day
answer: la fête des mères/pères

question: a calendar
answer: un calendrier; le calendrier lunaire = the lunar calendar; agenda = personal calendar / schedule

question: an agenda (for a meeting)
answer: l’ordre du jour; Agenda is a faux ami - it means personal calendar / schedule in french.

question: an equinox
answer: un équinoxe; la fête de la musique = 21 June (equinox) with live music in every corner of Paris

question: the national holiday of France
answer: la fête nationale (14 July) is the same day as Le bal de pompiers.

question: an animal / the animals
answer: un animal / des animaux

question: How do you form the plural of nouns that end in -al? e.g. carnival
answer: The ending -al in a singular noun changes to -aux in the plural. e.g. animal/animaux + carnival/carnivaux + festival/festivaux + récital/récitaux

question: How do you form the plural of nouns that end in -eau? e.g. bateau
answer: The ending -eau in a singular noun changes to -eaux in the plural. e.g. bateau/bateaux + oiseau/oiseaux

question: I have one dog and one cat.
answer: J'ai un chien et un chat. ('shat'); male cat: le chat; female cat: la chatte

question: a squirrel
answer: un écureuil

question: a bird + a peacock
answer: un oiseau + un paon

question: an eagle + a hawk
answer: un aigle + un faucon

question: a swan + a stork
answer: un cygne + une cigogne

question: a fish
answer: un poisson; un poison (one S) = a poison

question: a lion + a tiger
answer: un lion + un tigre; NB: The pronunciation of lion is 'lyohn'. Though 'io' sounds like 'wah'... 'ion' takes precedent to sound like 'yohn'.

question: a cow + a wolf
answer: une vache + un loup

question: a horse / horses; Specify the pronunciation.
answer: un cheval ('sheh-vaL'; the L is not silent because LCFR); les chevaux ('sheh-voh'; There is no L in the plural. AU makes the 'oh' sound.)

question: a pig
answer: un cochon; une cochonne = a woman who is untidy or sexually permiscous (depending on context); It's a double standard because it doesn't really work in the male form.

question: a sheep
answer: un mouton; an ewe (female sheep) is called une brebis and that is the word used for sheep cheese

question: a goat
answer: une chèvre; a horn = une corne

question: a deer
answer: une cerf

question: a bear
answer: un our; Pronounced the same as course and four. It is not the very deep like (as in bus). The sound is higher in the mouth.

question: a monkey + an elephant
answer: un singe + un éléphant

question: a turtle + a whale
answer: une tortue + une baleine

question: a coral (the animal)
answer: un corail

question: an insect+ a spider
answer: un insecte + une araignée

question: a worm + a caterpiller
answer: un ver + une chenille

question: an ant
answer: une fourmi

question: crustaceons + shellfish
answer: des crustacés + des coquillages / des fruits de mer

question: an oyster
answer: une huître ('lay-zwee-tr')

question: a clam + a muscle (the animal)
answer: une palourde + une moule; une moule = a bivalve animal; un moule = a mold (for a sculpture or pastry)

question: a lobster + a crab + a shrimp
answer: un homard + un crabe + une crevette

question: a circus
answer: un cirque

question: grammar
answer: les règles de grammaire

question: an emergency
answer: une urgence

question: a view of the neighborhood + a view of the forest
answer: une vue du quartier (de + le = du) + une vue de la forêt

question: a view of the rooftops of Paris + a view of the boulevard
answer: une vue sur les toites de Paris + une vue sur le boulevard; Use SUR when you are looking out onto something.

question: from the perspective of...
answer: d'un point de vue de

question: from my perspective...
answer: À mon avis...; Alternative: Pour moi... = For me...

question: According to me...
answer: selon que moi OR d'après moi; selon que is the more idiomatic translation of 'according to'.

question: According to the article...
answer: Selon l'article...

question: To me... / For me... (before expressing a view)
answer: selon moi...

question: In my opinion...
answer: De mon point de vue...

question: To my knowledge...
answer: À ma connaissance...; la connaissance = the knowledge AND the acquaintance

question: It seems to me...
answer: À ce qu'il me semble...; Soutenu alternative: Il me semble que...; Informal alternative: Me semble... ; The verb is SE SEMBLER ('to seem' used reflexively).; NB: Il me semble que... does not trigger the subjonctif because it is an opinion. But Il semble que... does trigger the subjonctif because it indicates possiblity (vs certainty).

question: In my experience...
answer: D'après mon expérience...

question: As for me... + As far as I'm concerned...
answer: Quant à moi... + En ce qui me concerne...; NB: ce qui is pronounced "ski" in conversation.

question: As far as I know...
answer: Autant que je sache... OR Pour autant que je sache...

question: Unless I'm mistaken...
answer: Sauf erreur de ma part...; Alternative: Si je ne me trompe pas...

question: I'm not an expert but...
answer: Je ne suis spécialiste mai...; Spécialiste (same m/f) is the word to use for 'expert'.

question: I wouldn't surprise me...
answer: Cela ne m'étonnerait pas que...

question: It's a good point but...
answer: C'est une bonne remarque mais...; une remarque is better than un point in this case.

question: It's an important point.
answer: C'est un point important.; NB: There is no liaison between point and important. The T in point remains silent.

question: I have an announcement to make.
answer: J'ai une annonce à faire.

question: idiomatic way to bring up a new subject / Let's chat about...
answer: On (se) fait un petit point...

question: If I may...
answer: Si je peux me permettre...

question: I am for... + I am against...
answer: Je suis pour... + Je suis contre...

question: I agree. + I disagree.
answer: Je suis (entièrement) d'accord. + Je ne suis pas d'accord.

question: I approve (completely). + I do not approve at all.
answer: J'approuve totalement. + Je n'approuve pas du tout.

question: I have complete confidence/trust.
answer: J'ai totale confiance.

question: I share your perspective. + I do not share your perspective.
answer: Je partage (complètement) ton/votre avis. + Je ne partage pas (du tout) ton/votre avis.; Alternative: Je ne suis pas du même avis.

question: I am in favor of the project. + I am not in favor of the project.
answer: Je suis favorable à ce projet. + Je ne suis pas favorable à ce projet.

question: You are absolutely right.
answer: Vous avez tout à fait raison.

question: I changed my mind. + I did not change my mind.
answer: J'ai changé d'avis / d'idée. + Je ne changerai pas d'avis.

question: It was on my mind.
answer: Two options: 1) C'était dans mon ésprit. 2) C'était dans ma tête.; Do NOT use cerveaux in this case.

question: idiomatic way to express: I will keep it in mind.
answer: Je le garde à l'esprit.

question: idiomatic way to express: How beautiful! So beautiful! (or any adjective)
answer: Comme tu est belle!; The formula: Comme + phrase. So you cannot just say Comme belle.

question: Exactly! + Perfectly!
answer: Exactement! + Parfaitement!

question: Effectively! + Indeed!
answer: Effectivement! + En Effet!

question: Obviously!
answer: Évidemment! or Clairement!

question: Without a doubt.
answer: Sans aucun doute.

question: a certainty + an uncertainty + a doubt
answer: une certitude + une incertitude + un doute

question: sceptical
answer: sceptique ('sep-tik'); same spelling for m/f; Watch out because the pronunciation is exactly the same as une fosse septique = a septic tank

question: idiomatic way to say: Yes of course.
answer: Bien súr que oui.

question: idiomatic way to say: You must be joking!
answer: Vous plaisantez OR Vous rigolez!; Alternative: Tu veux rire! This is literally 'You want to laugh!' but it translates to 'You must be joking!'; Colloquial alternative: Te te fiches de moi!

question: idiomatic way to say: You must be kidding!
answer: Tue te fiches de moi!

question: idiomatic way to say: Get out! / Never in my life!
answer: Jamais de la vie!

question: idiomatic way to say: I don't believe it!
answer: Je n'en reviens pas! or Incrédulité!

question: idiomatic way to say: I must be dreaming!
answer: On croit rêver!

question: idiomatic way to say: What next?! (in disbelief/outrage)
answer: Et puis quoi encore?

question: idiomatic way to say: It's unaceptable!
answer: C'est inadmissible!

question: It's dumb.
answer: C'est bête.; Alternative: C'est idiot. ...if you are talking about a person.

question: idiomatic way to say: shut up
answer: tais-toi

question: idiomatic ways to say: Calm down!
answer: Calme-toi! (= calm yourself) + C'est bon la. (= that's enough); NB: Only use these when the person is acting irrationally. Otherwise you will be escalating the situation.

question: idiomatic way to say: The fact remains that...
answer: Il n'en reste pas moins que...

question: idiomatic way to say: We would say...
answer: Dirons nous...; Another way to translate this: Shall we say...

question: idiomatic way to say: I struggle with X.
answer: J'ai du mal avec X.: Alternative: J'ai des difficultés avec X.

question: idiomatic way to say: I struggle using X.
answer: J'ai du mal À utliser X.; If you need to use a verb following 'J'ai du mal' then you must connect the two with À.

question: I don't see myself (doing something).
answer: J'ai du mal (I struggle) À me projeter.; se projeter = to project; se projeter can mean literally to project (like in a movie theater) or to forecast something.

question: idiomatic phrase meaning to have great difficulties
answer: manger son pain noir; This is a reference to the bread (pain noir) that the poor ate prior to the french revolution when only the wealthy could afford white bread. Since the revolution baguettes are regulated to avoid this disparity.

question: idiomatic way to say: It was hard to do that.
answer: J'ai galéré à le faire.; galérer (to struggle) is the verb

question: idiomatic way to say: It was a pain in the ass.
answer: C'était une galére.; galérer (to struggle) is the verb

question: idiomatic way to say: I will work very hard.
answer: Je ferai de mon mieux.; Literally it translates to: I will do my best.; There is not a good direct translation for working hard.

question: idiomatic way to say: I'm discombobulated. (e.g. after just waking up)
answer: 1) Je suis dans le brouillard. = literally I'm in the clouds. 2) Very casual: J'ai la tête dans le cul. = My head is in the ass.

question: damn (the curse word)
answer: zut or mince

question: a conspiracy theory
answer: une théorie du complot

question: I have culture shock.
answer: Je suis dépaysé(e). = I am in culture shock.; Dépaysant is the adjective of some noun that is causing the culture shock.; the culture shock = le choc culturel

question: a life + a death
answer: une vie + un décès

question: idiomatic way to express: in real life / in the real world
answer: dans la vrai vie

question: privacy
answer: la vie privée; literally: the private life; This is an idiomatic way to express privacy. Confidentiality is slightly different.

question: the government
answer: le gouvernement ('gov-er-NUH-moh'); Do not forget to pronounce all 4 syllables. It sounds different than in English.

question: a government organization
answer: le ministère; ministre (same m/f) is the name of a person who is the head of a government organization)

question: the democracy
answer: la démocratie

question: the heritage (of a person or country)
answer: le patrimoine

question: the patriarchy
answer: le patriarcat

question: authoritarian
answer: autoritaire (same m/f); l'autorité = the authority

question: a king + a queen
answer: un roi ('rhwa' not 'roy') + une reine ('rhen'); OI is always pronounced the same: 'wa' like choisir and toi

question: a reign (e.g. of a monarch)
answer: le règne

question: to nationalize
answer: nationaliser

question: the fall of the Berlin Wall / iron curtain
answer: la chute du mur de Berlin

question: a goal
answer: un but / un objectif; 'boot' the T is pronounced - likely because the origin of the word is foreign

question: a challenge
answer: un défi; challenge (pronounced with the anglo/czech CH) is often used by the French instead of the more idiomatic défi.

question: a test
answer: un examen OR un contrôle; e.g. J'ai un contrôle de maths. = I have a math test.

question: a multiple-choice (scan-tron) test
answer: QCM

question: an effort / You make the effort to speak french.
answer: un effort / Tu fais l'effort de parler français.

question: to achieve
answer: achever; But you can say: réaliser un rêve to mean 'to realize a dream'

question: to realize
answer: + prendre conscience (most idiomatic); Alternative ways to express 'to realize': accomplir + réaliser

question: a conflict + a contest/competition
answer: un conflit + un concours

question: the competition (e.g. among players or companies or countries)
answer: la concurrence

question: a list of the winner's of some competition
answer: un palmarès; It is a reference to a podium.

question: a crime + a crisis
answer: une délinquance/un crime + une crise

question: an ally + an alliance
answer: un(e) allié(e) + une alliance

question: a civilian + a fighter (not a civilian)
answer: un(e) civil(e) + un(e) belligérant(e)

question: a weapon
answer: une arme

question: ammunition
answer: des munitions; singular version: une munition

question: a handgun + a rifle
answer: un pistolet + un fusil

question: a missile + a bomb
answer: un missile + une bombe; a missile strike = une frappe de missiles

question: a canon + a landmine
answer: un canon + un mine

question: a tank
answer: un char d'assaut; un char = a cart; The french do use un tank but this is anglaicism.

question: a drone
answer: un drone

question: to hit / to strike
answer: frapper; This can mean to hit/slap a person or to hit a target with some object.; gifler quelqu'un = to slap someone

question: a disagreement
answer: une dispute; se disputer = to have a dispute

question: a fight + a struggle
answer: un combat + une lutte

question: to fight/struggle against (some force X) + to fight/struggle for (some goal)
answer: lutter contre X + lutter pour X

question: to fight (in a battle)
answer: se battre (past participle: battus) OR combattre (to physically fight; 3rd verb group); la bataille = the battle

question: They fought.
answer: Ils se sont battus.;SE BATTRE is a reflexive verb so the literal translation is: They fought eachother.; The reflexive pronoun (SE) comes before both verbs in passé composé.

question: I beat the eggs.
answer: Je battre les œufs.; BATTRE uses non-reflexively means to beat (like an egg). Used reflexively (se battre) it means to fight.

question: to beat someone up
answer: tabasser; This is an informal verb.

question: to confront + to attack + to block
answer: (s')affronter + attaquer + bloquer

question: a confrontation + an assault
answer: un affrontement + un assaut; (s')affronter = to confront

question: an attack + a bombing
answer: une attaque + un bombardement; bombarder = to bomb

question: a terrorist attack
answer: un attentat OR une attaque terroriste

question: to target something + a target
answer: cibler + une cible

question: to kill + to execute
answer: tuer + exécuter; gorger = to slaughter; massacrer = to massacre

question: a cease fire + a curfew
answer: un cessez-le-feu + un couvre-feu

question: to threaten + a threat
answer: menacer + une menace

question: threatened + threatened by something
answer: menacé(e) + menacé(e) PAR quelque chose

question: to flee + to betray
answer: fuir + trahir

question: the violence towards/against women
answer: la violence (or la brutalité) ENVERS les femmes

question: an embassy
answer: une ambassade

question: an ambassador (masc + fem)
answer: un ambassadeur / une ambassadrice

question: an immigrant (a person moving to a different country)
answer: un immigré / une immigrante

question: an emigrant (a person moving away from a country)
answer: un(e) émigré(e)

question: an expat (a foreigner who works for a company that is based in their country of origin)
answer: un(e) expatrié(e)

question: a refugee + an asylum-seeker
answer: un(e) réfugié(e) + un(e) demandeur/demandeuse d'asile

question: a victim
answer: une victime

question: a civilian (masc + fem)
answer: un(e) civil(e); un(e) belligérant(e) = a person who takes place in war aka fighter

question: a soldier + a spy
answer: un(e) soldat(e) + un(e) espion(ne)

question: a war + World War 2
answer: une guerre ('gehr' ryhmes with air) + la deuxième guerre mondiale

question: a war crime
answer: un crime de guerre

question: a strategy + a tactic
answer: une stratégie + une tactique

question: the military + the army
answer: les militaires + la armée

question: a rank (like in the military)
answer: un rang; a high rank = un haut rang

question: the marines (U.S.)
answer: les marines; This division does not necessarily exist in the french military. 'Les marines' is how the french refer to U.S. marines from WW2 + films + etc.

question: the police
answer: In France there are two groups: 1) La Police - the national group that is similar to police in the US. 2) gendarme - a part of the military that can also function as local/rural police; The gendarme tend to carry a better reputation than la police. They are literally part of the army.

question: the police station
answer: le commissarait

question: the barracks (where the army and firefighters stay)
answer: la caserne

question: the peace
answer: la paix ('pay') is pronounced differently than le pays ('pay-ee'; means country); to appease = APAISER; appeased = apaisé(e)

question: to pacify
answer: pacifier

question: pacism + militarism
answer: un pacifisme + un militarisme (= a warmongering approach)

question: Explain the suffixes -isme and -iste.
answer: These come from latin: -isme indicates an ideology. -iste indicates a person who practices that ideology.; For example: le capitalisme + capitaliste (same for masculine and feminine)

question: complicit
answer: complice

question: stable
answer: stable

question: sustainable
answer: This depends on context. 1) viable: able to sustain in a very real sense (e.g. like a fetus) 2) durable: able to maintain or last (e.g. like a business)  3) écoresponsable: sustainable as it relates to environmental concerns

question: an economy + a society
answer: une économie + une société

question: the western/developed world
answer: les pays occidentaux

question: the globalisation
answer: la modialisation

question: a loss of jobs
answer: une perte d'emplois

question: What is the french equivalent of GDP (gross domestic product)?
answer: PIB = le Produit Intérieur Brut

question: a commodity product
answer: There is no direct translation. The best option is un bien which means something like 'a good' or 'raw material' - something that is owned and could be sold.; une commodité is a faux ami. It means ammenity - not commodity.

question: an ammenity (in an apartment)
answer: une commodité; This is a type of convenience or utility. Typically it is used when describing housing.; This is a faux ami! It does not refer to a raw material.

question: What is the specific work that means: the request/demand (when a collection of people strike or protest)
answer: la revendication

question: a strike (of workers) + the strikers (in France)
answer: une grève + les grévistes; This is different than 'les gilets jaunes' which was a specific social movement that began in 2018.

question: a protest
answer: une manifestation; e.g. une manifestation du peuple = a people's protest

question: a revolt + a revolution
answer: une révolte + une révolution

question: the reinforcements (on buildings to prepare for a strike)
answer: le renforcement

question: a riot + riot-gear
answer: une émeute + une tenue d'intervention

question: the separation of powers (in government)
answer: la séparation des pouvoirs

question: the power
answer: Word choice depends on context. 1) la puissance: a physical power or force - e.g. the power of a machine or microscope or muscles;  2) le pouvoir: the power of authority/control or the possession of some ability - e.g. the powers that be and the power to accomplish something

question: powerful
answer: puissant(e); There is only one adjective that means powerful even though you must choose between le pouvoir and la puissance to mean 'the power'.

question: the right to property + the right to live free
answer: le droit À propriété + le droit DE vivre libre; Use À when the descriptor is a noun (e.g. propriété). Use DE when the descriptor is a verb (e.g. vivre).

question: the right to abortion
answer: le droit ('dwa') à l'avortement; Do not pronounce the T when you mean a right backed by law.

question: a human being + a living thing
answer: un être humain + un être vivant; Vivant is the adjective that means alive.

question: a lively atmosphere
answer: une ambiance vivante OR animée; vivant is the common word to use to describe a place with lots of energy (e.g. un quartier vivant)

question: a human right + humane
answer: un droit humain + humain(e)

question: How do you specify the difference between the right (like a law) vs the right (the direction or the political orientation)?
answer: LE droit (masculine + sans E) = the right that a person has; LA droitE (feminine + avec E) = the direction or political persuasion)

question: human nature
answer: la vrai nature

question: the United Nations
answer: les Nations Unies; NB: Acronyms are often reversed in english/french. e.g. DNA in english = ADN in french; AI = IA; IUD = DUI; HIV = VIH; AIDS = SIDA

question: a person who loves France (and the French) + a person who detests France (and the French)
answer: francophile + francophobe

question: What is a francophone country?
answer: A country that designates French an official language or whose people primarily speak French

question: What is Overseas France and what is it called in french?
answer: The 13 overseas territories of France. Some but not all are part of the EU.; In French: France d'outre-mer.; Alternatives: France ultramarine + les outre-mers + les départements d'outre-mer + les territoires d'outre-mer + les DOM-TOM ("duhm-tuhm"; départements d'outre-mer et territoires d'outre-mer) + les DROM-COM (départements et régions d'outre-mer et collectivités d'outre-mer)

question: to vote + to elect
answer: voter + élire; ÉLIRE is conjugated similar to LIRE.

question: She was elected.
answer: Elle était élu(e).

question: to suffer
answer: souffrir; the suffering: la souffrance

question: a prejudice/bias + a stereotype
answer: un préjuge + un stéréotype / un cliché; NB: This is a faux ami. un préjuge = a bias BUT un préjudice = an injury/harm.

question: xenophobic
answer: xénophobe

question: an ethnicity
answer: une ethnie

question: secular
answer: laïque; la laïcité = secularism

question: an atheist
answer: un(e) athée; Same spelling for masculine and feminine.

question: a pagan + the pagans
answer: un(e) païen(ne) + les païen(ne)s

question: a jewish person + a muslim person + a christian person
answer: juif/juive + musulman(e) + chrétien(ne)

question: the nazis; Specify pronunciation.
answer: les nazis ('nah-zee'); The Z is not pronounced with a T sound (as in English). It's like the Z in magazine.

question: religious + persecution
answer: religieux/religieuse + la persécution religieuse; Ils étaient persécutés. = They were persecuted.

question: the Zionism
answer: le sionisme ('see-oh-neesm'; the first two syllables are pronounced very quickly)

question: sacred
answer: sacré(e): It means extroadinary when placed before the noun. It means sacred when placed after the noun.

question: a sacred building + a damned liar
answer: un édifice sacré + un sacré menteur; sacré(e): It means extraordinary when placed before the noun. It means sacred when placed after the noun.

question: a promised land
answer: une terre promise

question: a secret + a promise
answer: un secret + une promesse

question: on average
answer: en moyenne; The noun is la moyenne.; NB: The masculine form (le moyen) means something different - more like a way or a means of doing something

question: an average-sized room
answer: une pièce moyenne

question: the humor
answer: l'humour (masculine)

question: the devil + an angle
answer: le diable + un ange

question: a phenomenon + a paradigm
answer: un phénomène + un paradigme ('pa-ra-deem'; the g is silent in french)

question: As a... / Speaking as a...
answer: en tant que; This is a common french expression that is used for times when you want to describe a person fully embodying a role. e.g. He is working as an X.; This is not the correct phrase when you are comparing people/things. e.g. He eats like a bird.

question: She is working as an engineer. + She works on a book.
answer: Elle travaille EN TANT QUE ingénieur. + Elle travaille un livre.; NB: There is no preposition (de + sur + etc) after the verb travailler when you want to describe working 'on' something.

question: He moves like a danser.
answer: Il bouge COMME un danseur.; COMME is the correct word to use for this comparison - instead of EN TANT QUE or AUSSI - because you are not really saying that he is a danser and the quality is not quantified.

question: X is similar to Y
answer: X est similair à Y.; Use À after the adjective.

question: a similarity
answer: une ressemblance OR une similitude

question: They were not happy as a couple.
answer: Ils n'étaient pas heureux en tant que couple.

question: convinced
answer: convaincu; like an adjective - tu est convaincu.

question: step by step (idiomatic french)
answer: petit à petit; a very french expression

question: fingers crossed
answer: croisons les doigts

question: It works! + It might work. + It does not work.
answer: Ça marche! + Ça ne marche pas.; Using marcher (literally 'to walk') is the idiomatic way to express that something is working.

question: It might not work. + It cannot not work.
answer: This is really interesting because the difference in these two meanings occurs only by re-ording the words: Ça peut ne pas marcher. (I might not work. - 50/50 chance) + Ça ne peut pas marcher. (It cannot work. - 100% negative; This is the standard way to negate where NE comes directly after the subject.)

question: Perhaps her efforts will not work.
answer: Peut-être que ses efforts ne marcheront pas.; NB: Use que because it's like 'it's possible that...'. Use futur simple form of marcher.

question: at your disposal
answer: à disposition

question: the pronoun
answer: le pronom

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au présent?
answer: If there is only one word representing the verb in présent then pronouns come before that verb; NB: This is true for all tenses where a single word represents the entire verb.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au présent when using two verbs (e.g. I want to dance.)?
answer: in between the conjugated HELPER and the INFINITIVE; NB: For any tense... whenever you need two different verbs where one is a conjugated HELPER and the other is the INFINITIVE... then pronouns usually are placed before the infinitive - but not before the helper verb.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au passé composé?
answer: before both the AUXILLIARY conjugated form of avoir/être and the PAST PARTICIPLE; NB: This does not violate the general rule that pronouns come before an infinitive when using two verbs together (e.g. I want to dance) because there is no infinitive in passé composé - there are two words acting as verbs but they are viewed as a single verb (auxiliary + past participle). So the pronouns are placed before both the auxiliary and past participle.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au imparfait and conditionnel?
answer: If there is only one word representing the verb in imparfait then pronouns come before that verb; NB: This is true for all tenses where a single word represents the entire verb.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au futur proche?
answer: in between the conjugated form of ALLER and the INFINITIVE; NB: This follows the rule of dual verbs. Whenever you need two different verbs in french where one is a conjugated HELPER and the other is the INFINITIVE (e.g. I want to dance = Je veux danser)... then pronouns usually are placed before the infinitive - but not before the helper verb.

question: Where do you place pronouns (that are objects of the verb) au futur simple?
answer: If there is only one word representing the verb in futur simple then pronouns come before that verb; NB: This is true for all tenses where a single word represents the entire verb.

question: List the french pronoms sujets (aka subject pronouns) e.g. YOU went to the store.
answer: je + tu + il/elle/on + nous + vous + ils/elles

question: What is a COD (compléments d’objet direct) aka a direct object?
answer: An object that receives or experiences the action of the verb. e.g. I bought IT.; COD (direct objects) generally follow a verb when spelled out. If we use a COD pronoun then the pronoun moves in front of the verb.

question: List the french COD pronoms.
answer: me + te + le(m)/la(f) + nous + vous + les(m/f); me + te + le/la change to m’ + t’ + l’ in front of a vowel or mute H.; NB: The COD pronouns for he/she/they are the same as the definite articles (le/la/l'/les).

question: What is a COI (compléments d’objet indirect) aka an indirect object?
answer: An indirect object receives a direct object or is 'for whom' the action of the verb is done. e.g. I gave THEM the book.; Indirect objects follow a verb when spelled out.; NB: When a preposition is used in front of the object (for THEM) then it is technically NOT an indirect object (and is not receiving the direct object) in English. Instead we call it an 'object of a preposition'. e.g. I gave the book to THEM. The coffee is for HIM.; That noun 'him' is required to be present. The preposition 'for' doesn't make sense without 'him'.

question: List the french COI pronoms.
answer: me + te + lui(m/f) + nous + vous + leur(m/f); me + te change to m' and t' in front of a vowel of mute H.; NB: The COI pronouns for him/her/them are genderless. LUI is used for both masculine and feminine.; NB: LEUR does not have an S when used as a COI pronom. But leur can also be a possesive adjective (e.g. their cat = leur chat). When leur is used as a possesive adjective then it must agree with the number of the noun that it describes (e.g. their cats = leurs chats).

question: Sometimes we do not use a COI pronom to reference an indirect object or object of a preposition. When is that the case?
answer: Use COI unless it is one of the many special cases where pronoms toniques is used. This depends - among other things - on the preposition (or lack thereof) required by the verb - which is not consistent between English and French. You cannot translate directly from English.; NB: In English the treatment of pronouns for indirect objects and objects of a preposition are the same. The pronouns taking the objective case: him/her/them.

question: Which COD and COI pronouns are the same? Which are different?
answer: They are mostly the same: me + te + nous + vous. The only perspectives in which they differ are 3rd person singular (le/la vs lui) and 3rd person plural (les vs leur).

question: When we have both a COD pronom and a COI pronom in a sentence they are both placed before the verb. Which one is placed first?
answer: COI; General order: Subject + COI pronom + COD pronom + Verb.; Exception: When both pronouns are in the 3rd person then the order is reversed.; In spoken french it is very uncommon that both a COD and a COI pronoun are used. Typically a person will only use one pronoun and be explicit about the other object.

question: Do these verbs trigger a COD pronom or a COI pronom? aimer + appeler + écouter + lire + voir
answer: They trigger a COD pronom. e.g. Je vois Audrey. = I see Audrey. Je LA (not lui) vois. = I see her.; e.g. J'écoute Audrey = I listen to Audrey. Je l'écoute. = I listen to her.

question: Do these verts trigger a COD pronom or a COI pronom? parler + plaire + répondre + téléphoner
answer: They trigger a COI pronom. e.g. Je réponds Audrey = I respond to Audrey. Je LUI (not la) réponds. = I respond to her.

question: You want me to 'do something'.
answer: Tu veux que je... ; VOULOIR triggers the subjonctif to express this (You want that I...). We do not translate it directly with a direct or indirect object (me).

question: If some noun/pronoun is an indirect object in English then will it also be an indirect object in French? Why?
answer: No. Not necessarily.; French and English verbs differ in their use of prepositions. This means that a verb might use a preposition in English but not in French (and vice versa). The presence/absence of a preposition can often determine whether or not the object of the verb is direct or indirect. So you have to memorize whether how each french verbs us prepositions in order to know which pronouns to use for the objects following the verb.

question: We listen to our mothers. + We listen to THEM.; Explain the selection of the french pronoun for 'them' in this case.
answer: Nous écoutons nos mères. + Nous LES (COD) écoutons.; In English the verb that means 'to listen to something' requires a preposition TO and its object is indirect. But in french the verb ÉCOUTER does not use a preposition and its object is direct (not indirect). So when we replace the object (mothers) with a pronoun we use COD (les) instead of COI (leur).

question: We call our mothers. + We call THEM.; Explain the selection of the french pronoun for 'them' in this case.
answer: Nous téléphonons À nos mères. + Nous LEUR (COI) téléphonons.; In English the verb that means 'to call someone' does not require a preposition and its object is direct. But in french the verb TÉLÉPHONER requires the preposition À and its object is indirect (not direct). So when we replace the object (mothers) with a pronoun we use COI (leur) instead of COD (les).

question: Define transitive and intransitive verbs. Give examples.
answer: Transitive verbs can take a direct object. e.g. To put: He put the book on the table.; Intransitive verbs do not require a direct object. e.g. To die: John died.; NB: In English you cannot have an indirect object if there is no direct object.

question: Define linking verbs. Do they have direct/indirect objects?
answer: Linking verbs do not have action. They connect the subject of a sentence to some information. e.g. To be: Simone is a leader.; Linking verbs do not have direct objects. Therefore they also do not have indirect objects.

question: What are the requirements for when a verb must agree (in number/gender) with the object (instead of the subject) of a phrase?
answer: Requirements: 1) The verb is using avoir (not être) as its auxiliary. 2) The object is a direct (not indirect) object. 3) The direct object (could be a noun or a pronoun) precedes the verb. 4) The direct object is associated with a conjugated part of the verb (e.g. the past participle) so that the verb can be adapted - not a supplementary verb that is in the infinitive form (because we can not change an infinitive to agree in gender/number). 5) The verb is not related to perception (e.g. voir + entendre)

question: I am buying the car that you recommended.
answer: J'achete la voiture que tu as recommandéE (singular feminine agreement).; The past participle of the verb must adapt to the object (la voiture) because this example satisfies all of the requirements for when a verb must agree in gender/number with a direct object (instead of the subject).

question: I found them (my glasses) under the couch.
answer: Je les (plural feminine COD) ai trouvéES (plural feminine agreement) sous le canapé.; The past participle of the verb must adapt to the object (them - the glasses) because this example satisfies all of the requirements for when a verb must agree in gender/number with a direct object (instead of the subject).

question: He gave them (the books) to me.
answer: Il me les (plural masculine COD) a donnéS (plural masculine agreement).; The past participle of the verb must adapt to the object (them - the glasses) because this example satisfies all of the requirements for when a verb must agree in gender/number with a direct object (instead of the subject).

question: Here are the photos that I took during vacation.
answer: Voici les photos que j'ai prisES (feminine plural agreement) pendant les vacances.; The past participle of the verb must adapt to the object (the photos) because this example satisfies all of the requirements for when a verb must agree in gender/number with a direct object (instead of the subject).

question: The gifts were given by me. + I gave them (the gifts) to you.
answer: Les cadeaux étaient donnéS (masculine plural agreement) par moi. + Je te les ai donnéS (masculine plural agreement).; The first sentence uses passive form. It demonstrates how we sometimes adapt verbs (donner) to agree with an object (the gifts).; The second sentence is passé composé but the past participle must adapt to the object (the gifts) because this example satisfies all of the requirements for when a verb must agree in gender/number with a direct object (instead of the subject).

question: Here’s the dress that I thought about buying.
answer: Voici la robe que j’ai pensé (no agreement with direct object) acheter.; PENSER does not agree with the direct object (la robe) because PENSER is related more closely to the subject (je). The object (la robe) is more closely related to the verb in the infinitive form (acheter) in this case. We cannot change infinitives to agree with nouns.

question: A song that I heard... + A song that I played...
answer: Une chanson que j'ai entendu (no agreement with direct object)... + Une chanson que j'ai jouéE (singular feminine agreement with chanson).; ENTENDU does not agree with the direct object that comes before the noun because this is an edge case where the verb is a perception (e.g. voir + entendre)

question: The house that you saw... + The house that you bought...
answer: La maison que tu as vu (no agreement with direct object)... + La maison que tu as achetéE (singular feminine agreement with chanson).; VU does not agree with the direct object that comes before the noun because this is an edge case where the verb is a perception (e.g. voir + entendre)

question: She advised Marie to buy a house. + She advised her of it (to buy a house).
answer: Elle a conseillé à Marie d'acheter une maison. + Elle le lui a conseillé.; The COI is à Marie. The COD is d'acheter une maison. Those verb phrases can be represented by COD pronoms.

question: What are pronoms toniques?
answer: Pronouns that are used in french in some special circumstances (including for emphasis). Sometimes pronoms toniques replace COI when referring to indirect objects. Sometimes they are used to show possession. Pronoms toniques ALWAYS refer to a person (never a thing). Do not use a tonique pronom if you are referring to a thing.; Other names for these pronouns: stressed pronouns + disjunctive pronouns + pronoms disjunct.

question: List the pronoms toniques.
answer: moi + toi + lui(m)/elle(f) + nous + vous + eux(m)/elles(f); me + te change to m' and t' in front of a vowel of mute H.; NB: Pronoms toniques differ by gender in 3rd person singular AND plural. (This is not surprising considering that pronoms toniques are always used to refer to people - never to things.); For example... 'to him/her/them(m)/them(f)' does not adapt to gender because TO triggers COI: lui/lui/leur/leur. BUT 'with him/her/them(m)/them(f)' must adapt to gender because WITH triggers tonique (assuming that we are referencing people): avec lui/elle/eux/elles.

question: What are the special scenarios where we use pronoms toniques?
answer: Most importantly you can only use a tonique pronom when referencing a person (not a thing). Then the scenarios include (but are not limited to): 1) a short response to question (e.g. Who is there? I am! = Moi!); 2) a double subject - a very french structure (e.g. Me` I am... = Moi` je suis... ); 3) indirect objects when we are forced - in french - to place a preposition (like APRÈS AVEC DANS DEVANT POUR SANS CHEZ...) in front of the pronoun; 4) in comparisons after QUE - remember that QUE contracts to QU' when followed by a vowel (e.g. bigger than her = plus grand qu'elle; bigger than them masculine = plus grand qu'eux); 5) a shortcut for ownership called independent possessive pronouns (e.g. mine = à moi); 6) together with -même (e.g. moi-même = myself + elle-même = herself + lui-même = himself); 7) After C’est... and Ce sont... (e.g. Ce sont EUX qui sont venus ici = They(m) are the ones who came here.); 8) for emphasis: Moi` j'aime bien la table. Je l'envoie la lettre` lui (l' stands for lui. Then lui is repeated at the end for emphasis.).

question: for me + you + him/her + us + you guys + them(m/f)
answer: POUR triggers pronoms toniques (as long as the pronouns reference a person): pour moi + toi + lui/elle + nous + vous + eux/elles

question: with me + you + him/her + us + you guys + them(m/f)
answer: AVEC triggers pronoms toniques (as long as the pronoun references a person): avec moi + toi + lui/elle + nous + vous + eux/elles

question: his + hers + theirs(m) + theirs(f)
answer: à lui + elle + eux + elles; Use pronoms toniques to show ownership when the owner is a person. It also requires preposition À in french.

question: I walk the dog (gender not specified).
answer: Je promène le chein.; PROMENER does not use a preposition for its direct object (the dog).; Objects of the verb (direct and indirect) are placed after the verb (unless they are represented by pronouns).

question: I walk it (the male dog). + I walk it (the female dog).
answer: Je LE promène. + Je LA promène.; The dogs are direct objects of the verb. So we use the COD (le/la) pronouns.; All pronouns that represent objects of the verb are placed before the verb.

question: I help her/him. + I can help her/him.
answer: Je L'aide. + Je peux l'aider.; AIDER does not use a preposition for its direct object (him/her). So we use the COD (le/la) pronouns.; Use l' to avoid two vowels together.; All pronouns that represent objects of the verb are placed before the verb.

question: I bring you (informal). + I bring you (formal). + I bring us.
answer: Je T'amène. + Je VOUS amène. + Je nous amène.; AMENER does not use a preposition for its direct object (you/us). So we use the COD (te/vous/nous) pronouns - though the COI pronouns in these cases are exactly the same.; All pronouns that represent objects of the verb are placed before the verb.

question: I bring them (all masculine). + I bring them (all feminine).
answer: Je LES améne. (same for both); AMENER does not use a preposition for its direct object (them). So we use the COD (les) pronouns.; All pronouns that represent objects of the verb are placed before the verb.

question: She gives the hen to Anna. + She gives IT to ME.
answer: Elle donne la poule À Anna. + Elle ME LE donne.; DONNER does not use a preposition of its direct object (the cat). DONNER uses À for its indirect object (Anna).; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to you (informal).
answer: Elle TE LA donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'You' is a COI (te) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to him/her.
answer: Elle LA LUI donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'Him/her' is a COI (lui) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to us.
answer: Elle NOUS LA donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'Us' is a COI (nous) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to you (formal).
answer: Elle VOUS LA donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'You' is a COI (vous) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: She gives IT (feminine) to them (m/f).
answer: Elle LA LEUR ('leuhr' same as heures) donne.; 'It' is a COD (la). 'Them' is a COI (leur) because DONNER uses À before its indirect object.; All pronouns come before the verb. If a phrase includes both COD and COI pronouns then the COI pronoun comes first. UNLESS both pronouns are in the 3rd person - then the order is reversed.

question: We work for me. + We work for you (informal).
answer: Nous travaillons pour MOI. + Nous travaillons pour TOI.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques as long as the pronoun references a person.

question: We work for him. + We work for her.
answer: Nous travaillons pour LUI. + Nous travaillons pour ELLE.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques (which disambiguate between genders in 3rd person) as long as the pronoun references a person.

question: We work for us. + We work for you (formal).
answer: Nous travaillons pour NOUS. + Nous travaillons pour VOUS.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques as long as the pronoun references a person.

question: We work for them (masculine) + We work for them (feminine).
answer: Nous travaillons pour EUX ('oo'). + Nous travaillons pour ELLES.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques (which disambiguate between genders in 3rd person) as long as the pronoun references a person.

question: We go without them (unspecified gender).
answer: On va sans EUX.; The preposition sans triggers pronoms toniques so the object of the preposition (them without specified gender) translates to EUX (instead of les or leur). is the tonique pronoun for them (male).

question: It is difficult for them (all women) to travel.
answer: C'est difficile pour ELLES de voyager.; The preposition pour triggers pronoms toniques so the object of the preposition (them feminine) translates to ELLES (instead of les or leur).

question: Simone is stronger than her.
answer: Simone est plus forte qu'ELLE.; Using the comparator QUE triggers the pronoms tonique. So we use ELLE to represent 'her' (instead of la or lui).

question: Michael and I are playing tennis.
answer: Michel et MOI    jouons au tennis.; Use tonique pronouns (moi instead of je) whenever there are 2+ subjects of a sentence (and any of them are pronouns).; NB: One way to think of this: Michael WITH me. AVEC triggers the use of the pronoms toniques.

question: He and I are friends.
answer: LUI et MOI    sommes amis.; Use tonique pronouns (lui instead of il) whenever there are 2+ subjects of a sentence (and any of them are pronouns).; NB: When the subject is compound (lui et moi) you should pause between the subject and verb. Running them together is not idiomatic.

question: He and his friends are there.
answer: Lui et ses amis   sont là.; Use tonique pronouns (lui instead of il) whenever there are 2+ subjects of a sentence (and any of them are pronouns).; NB: When the subject is compound (lui et ses amis) you should pause between the subject and verb. Running them together is not idiomatic.

question: Them and their friends are there.
answer: Eux et leurs amis   sont là.; Use tonique pronouns (eux instead of ils) whenever there are 2+ subjects of a sentence (and any of them are pronouns).; NB: When the subject is compound (eux et leurs amis) you should pause between the subject and verb. Running them together is not idiomatic.

question: Who is going to the beach? He is! She is!
answer: Qui va à la plage? Lui! Elle!; When answering a question quickly in french like this it triggers the pronoms toniques which disambiguate between gender in the 3rd person. So use lui/elle (disambiguated) instead of le/la or lui (ambiguous).

question: They (unspecified gender) want to come too.
answer: EUX aussi veulent venir.; When using emphatic phrases (words like aussi + non plus + seul) it triggers the pronoms toniques (eux - or elle - instead of les or leur).

question: She is taller than you (are).
answer: Elle est plus grande que toi.; The S in plus is not pronounced in this case because it precedes a word that starts with a consonant.; When making a comparison in french (e.g. following 'que') it triggers the pronom tonique (m'/moi + t'/toi + lui (m) + elle (f) + nous + vous + eux (m) + elles (f))

question: He is going to do it himself.
answer: Il va le faire lui-méme.; This is a special case that triggers the tonique pronoms.

question: Everyone has to do it himself/herself.
answer: Tout le monde doit le faire soi-méme.; Soi is used as a tonique pronom for unspecified persons. It is equivalent to 'one' or 'oneself' in English.

question: Everyone is going home.
answer: On va chez soi.; Soi is used as a tonique pronom for unspecified persons. It is equivalent to 'one' or 'oneself' in English.

question: I (emphasized; meaning not others) did it.; Use a tonique pronoun to show emphasis.
answer: Je l’ai fait` moi.; Tonique pronouns are used in repetition to show emphasis. In this case JE is already stated. Adding MOI at the end gives the impression of: I - and no one else - did it. It's aggressive.

question: I like him (emphasized; meaning not others).; Use a tonique pronoun to show emphasis.
answer: Je l'aime` lui.; Tonique pronouns are used in repetition to show emphasis. In this case L' (representing lui) is already stated. Adding another LUI at the end gives the impression of: I like him - and no one else. It's aggressive.

question: What are some common verbs that are always followed by DE? Why is it helpful to memorize these?
answer: boire de + parler de (to speak about something) + avoir besoin de (to need something) + jouer de (to play an instrument) + se souvenir de (to remember) + partir de (to leave) + penser de (to have an opinion about); Knowing whether or not a verb requires the preposition DE determines which pronoun you can use to replace the object of the verb. Use Y to replace à + object. Use EN to replace de + object.; e.g. I speak at it. = J'en parle (PARLER + DE).

question: What is an adverbial pronoun?
answer: It is a pronoun that represents a place or a quantity or the object of a preposition.; 1) there: I go to the store. I go there. There references the store - which also happens to be the object of the preposition 'to' (à).; 2) them: Cars... I have some of them/those. 'Them/those' references the object of the preposition 'of' (de).; 3) those/that: I have none of this/that. 'This/that' references the object of the preposition 'of' (de).

question: When do you use the pronom Y?
answer: Rule of thumb: Y is a pronoun that replaces a place. It means 'there'. e.g. Je vais À Paris. becomes... J'Y vais. (I go there.).; The more correct rule: Y is an adverbial pronoun that replaces a noun that is the object of the preposition À. Y can replace any noun that is the object of preposition À EXCEPT an animate object (including people).; This means that you first need to understand whether a verb requires À (use Y) or DE (use EN).; NB: If the structure is À + NOUN and the noun is an animate object...then use a tonique pronoun instead of Y.; Pronunciation: Pronom Y is pronounced 'ee'. So J'y is pronounced 'gee'.

question: When do you use the pronom EN?
answer: Rule of thumb: EN is a pronoun that replaces something that has a count/quantity to it (either clearly or vaguely). e.g. Je parle DE mon ami. (I talk about my friend.) becomes... J'EN parle. (I talk about them.).; e.g. J'en voudrais. = I want one (of those).; EN replaces any of the following: (un + une + du + de la + des) + NOUN.; The more correct rule: EN is an adverbial pronoun that replaces a noun that is the object of the preposition DE.; This means that you first need to understand whether a verb requires À (use Y) or DE (use EN).; e.g. Il cherche DEs idées. (He looks for ideas.) becomes... Il EN cherche. (He looks for some.); NB: EN can replace a NOUN on its own or an entire phrase.

question: When is it difficult to determine when to use Y vs EN?
answer: For example when someone says: I'm thinking about X. And then the next sentence references X as a pronoun. Whether you use EN or Y to reference X depends on whether you say (in french) Je pense à X or Je pense de X. So you have to memorize whether to use verb + à X or verb + de X. Then this determines whether you use Y (replaces à X) or EN (replaces de X).

question: Where do you place pronom Y or pronom EN in a phrase?
answer: Pronom Y/EN are placed last after all over pronouns. This means that they are placed directly before the verb (before the auxiliary in passé composé).; NB: Only PAS (no pronouns) comes between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé.

question: I went to Beijing. + I went there.
answer: Je suis allé(e) à Pékin. + J'y suis allé(e).; 'there' is an adverbial pronoun refering to 'Beijing'. In this case we use the pronom Y (instead of EN) because the verb (ALLER) is always followed by À (instead of DE).; Another way to remember this is that we generally use pronom Y when referring to a location.

question: I come from Shanghai. + I come from there.
answer: Je viens de Shanghai. + J'EN viens.; Use pronom EN to replace Shanghai (instead of Y) because VENIR triggers DE (not À).

question: I think about my country. + I think about it.
answer: Je pense À mon pays. + J'Y pense.; Use pronom Y (instead of pronom EN) because the verb PENCER uses À (instead of de). Therefore the object of the preposition (my country) is replaced with Y.

question: I will think about it.
answer: J'y penserai.; PENSER in futur simple. Use Y because PENSER uses À (instead of DE).

question: I think about Simone. + I think about her.
answer: Je pense À Simone. + Je pense À ELLE.; Use pronom tonique (instead of Y) because the verb PENCER uses À and the object of the preposition is a person. Therefore use the pronom tonique (elle) to replace Simone.

question: I'm interested in politics. + I'm interested in it.
answer: Je m'intéresse À la politique. + Je m'Y intéresse.; Use pronom Y (instead of pronom EN) because the verb SE INTÉRESSER uses À (instead of de). Therefore the object of the preposition (politics) is replaced with Y.

question: I change the train. + I change it.
answer: Je change DE train. + J'EN change.; Use pronom EN (instead of pronom Y) because the verb CHANGER uses DE (instead of à). Therefore the object of the preposition (the train) is replaced with EN.

question: I need a television. + I need one.
answer: J'ai besoin D'une télé(vision). + J'EN ai besoin.; 'one' is an adverbial pronoun refering to 'a television'. In this case we use the pronom EN (instead of Y) because the verb (AVOIR besoin) is always followed by DE (instead of À).; Another way to remember this is that we use pronom EN when referring to a quantity of something (one television).

question: They want telephones. + They want some.
answer: Ils veulent des téléphones. + Ils EN veulent.; 'some' is an adverbial pronoun refering to 'telephones'. In this case we use the pronom EN (instead of Y) because we are referring to a quantity of something (some phones).

question: I have it. + I do not have it.
answer: J'EN ai. ('zshoh-nay') + Je n'EN ai pas. ('zshuh-noh-nay-pah'); These are very common french expressions. This is typically how you express these phrases in french.; Use pronom EN to refer to the thing that you have or do not have because it clearly or vaguely has a count/quantity.; If you are really referring to a very specific thing that was explicitly discussed before this phrase then you can use a regular pronoun (e.g. le) instead of pronom EN to refer to 'it': I have it. = Je l'ai. (le + ai = l'ai)

question: I like to go to the Mediterranean Sea. + I like to go there. + I like the climate there.
answer: J'aime aller à la mer Méditerranée. + J'aime Y aller. (Y is placed before the infinitive verb that it modifies.) + J'aime le climat là-bas.; In the last case it doesn't make sense to use Y to replace 'there'. The verb AIMER must be connected to the object (le climat). What we really mean is that we like the climate 'over there'.

question: I am looking forward to the concert. + I am looking forward to being there.
answer: J'ai hâte ('hat') DE le concert. + J'ai hâte d'Y être.; Use pronom Y to replace an event (the concert) even though the pronom DE is in play.; If the thing you are looking forward to is a verb then use DE + INFINITIVE.

question: I am really looking forward to being on vacation.
answer: J'ai vraiment hâte D'être en vacances.

question: I have not gone to the Netherlands.
answer: Je ne suis pas allé(e) aux Pays-Bas.; Use ALLER instead of ÊTRE.; NE always comes directly after the subject (before any pronouns). PAS goes between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé.

question: I have not gone there.
answer: Je n'Y suis pas allé(e).; Use pronom Y to replace À + location.; Use ALLER instead of ÊTRE.; NE always comes directly after the subject (before any pronouns). PAS goes between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé.

question: I have never been/gone there.
answer: Je n'Y suis jamais allé(e).; Use pronom Y to replace À + location.; NE always comes directly after the subject (before any pronouns). JAMAIS replaces PAS (between the auxiliary and past participle in passé composé).

question: I have never been/gone to Japan or Vietnam.
answer: Je ne suis jamais allé(e) au Japon et au Vietnam.; You can use ET (and) or OU (or) here - they are both correct.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.

question: I had never been to the Netherlands. (...before some other event)
answer: Je n'étais jamais allé(e) aux Pays-Bas.; JAMAIS replaces PAS.; Use plus que parfait tense (past perfect; 'had done something') because the action was completed before some other action. Plus que parfait: être/avoir conjugated in imparfait + past participle.

question: I had never been there. (...before some other event)
answer: Je n'Y étais jamais allé(e).; Use pronom Y to reference À + location. NE always comes directly after the subject (before any pronouns). JAMAIS replaces PAS.; Use plus que parfait tense (past perfect; 'had done something'). Plus que parfait: être/avoir conjugated in imparfait + past participle.

question: It was good to be there at that time.
answer: C'etait bien d'Y être à moment lá.

question: I prefer to go there on foot.
answer: Je préfère Y aller à pieds.; The pronom Y is placed in between the verbs because it is more closely related to ALLER than to PRÉFÉRER.

question: I would install it. + I would like to install it.
answer: J'Y installerais. + J'aimerais Y installer.; INSTALLER uses À so 'it' is replaced by pronom Y.; Both sentences use the conditionnel.; The second phrase is a slight exception because pronom Y comes after one of the verbs (instead of before the verb which is generally the rule).

question: How do you know which preposition to use in front of an infinitive verb?
answer: 1) Always use 'pour' if you could replace the phrase with 'in order to do x'. You are providing a reason/explanation for doing something.; 2) In the remainder of cases use with À or DE and the rules are not fixed or straightforward.

question: How do you know whether to use À vs DE in front of an infinitive verb?
answer: 1) In many cases the preceding word (verb or adjective) determines whether to use À or DE. (e.g. Tu es prêt À danser. + Tu es content(e) DE danser.); 2) AVOIR + NOUN + DE: This pattern always requires DE. (e.g. J'ai besoin DE qqch. J'ai envie DE qqch.); 3) In some cases the preceding verb can use both À or DE and it will change the meaning. (e.g. Je décide qqun À faire qqch. = I persuade someone to do something. OR Je décide DE faire qqch. = I decide to do something.); 4) In some cases use À if the infinitive verb is not followed by an object: Cette leçon est facile À comprendre. 5) In some cases use DE if the infinitive verb is followed by an object: C'est facile DE comprendre cette leçon.

question: What are expressions impersonnelles and which prepositions do they trigger?
answer: Impersonal expressions have the formula: generic subject + conjugated être + adjective + preposition + verb. (e.g. It's possible to do. It's easy to do. It's absurd to do.) In English these expressions always use the preposition TO + INFINITIVE. But in French sometimes À + INFINITIVE is correct and sometimes DE + INFINITIVE is correct. Whether you use À or DE depends on whether the generic subject refers to something real (use À) or whether it is truly a dummy subject (use DE).

question: What is the difference between these two expressions impersonnelles: C'est/Il est difficile de parler. C'est/Il est bon à savoir.
answer: C'est difficile de parler. = It's difficult to speak. This means 'speaking is difficult'. The subject (C'est/Il) in this case is a 'dummy' - it doesn't really exist. So we must use DE before the infinitive.; C'est bon à savoir. = It's good to know. The subject (C'est/Il) in this case refers to something real - a piece of information that was likely mentioned previously. So we must use À before the infinitive.

question: It's impossible to find. + It's important to study.
answer: C'est/Ils est impossible À trouver. (Use À + INFINITIVE because the generic subject refers to something real that was likely mentioned previously. You wouldn't rephrase as: Finding is impossible.) + C'est/Il est important d'étudier. (Use DE + INFINITIVE because the generic subject is truly a dummy. We could rephrase as: Studying is important.)

question: It's easy to cook. + It's dificult to cook.
answer: Il/C'est facile DE cuisiner. + Il/C'est dificile DE cuisiner.; It's easy/difficult to do something is almost always a completely generic impersonal expression. The subject 'it' is just a dummy subject. So facile/dificil almost always trigger DE before an infinitive.

question: It's easy to anticipate. + It's difficult to eat the entire meal.
answer: Il/C'est facile D'anticiper. + Il/C'est dificil DE manger tout le repas.; It's easy/difficult to do something is almost always a completely generic impersonal expression. The subject 'it' is just a dummy subject. So facile/dificil almost always trigger DE before an infinitive.

question: It's easy for us to leave earlier.
answer: Il/C'est facile pour nous DE partir plus tôt.; It's easy/difficult to do something is almost always a completely generic impersonal expression. The subject 'it' is just a dummy subject. So facile/dificil almost always trigger DE before an infinitive.

question: It's difficult to swim. + It's difficult to do.
answer: Il/C'est dificile DE nager. (Use DE because the subject is a dummy: Swimming is difficult.) + Il/C'est dificile À faire. (Use À because the subject refers to something real - to do something specific that was mentioned previously); This demonstrates that often an impersonal expression triggers DE when there is only an infinitive. If there is an infinitive plus object (e.g. faire qqch) then the expression triggers À because the generic subject is no longer a 'dummy'.

question: It's absurd to find. + It's absurd to find a route.
answer: Il/C'est absurde À trouver. + Il/C'est absurde DE trouver une route.; In the first phrase the subject is completely generic / dummy. So use À instead of DE. This is often the case when there is no object after the infinitive.; In the second phrase the subject is something more concrete. So use DE instead of À. This is often the case when there is an object after the infinitive.

question: the song to sing
answer: la chanson À chanter; In this case À is the correct preposition before the infinitive.

question: What is a demonstrative article/adjective?
answer: this/that e.g. this cat + that whale; Demonstrative articles precede a noun. They act like an adjective modifying the noun to show (in real life) exactly which one you are talking about.; Demonstrative articles do not stand on their own. If you need a word to mean 'that one' (where the noun is absent) then you are using a demonstrative pronoun (now a demonstrative article/adjective).

question: What are the demonstrative articles/adjectives (e.g. this X + that X) in french? How are they pronounced?
answer: There are three: Ce 'suh' (masculine singular) + Cette 'set' (feminine singular) + Ces 'sayz' (plural regardless of gender)

question: this bra
answer: ce soutein-gorge (masculine)

question: this baseball hat
answer: cette casquette (feminine)

question: these gloves
answer: ces gants (plural)

question: these pajamas
answer: ce pyjama (masculine); pyjama is singular in french but plural in english

question: this article (article is spelled the same in french but is masculine)
answer: cet article ('suh-tar-teecl') is masculine singular; Normally we use CE for masculine singular but here the noun starts with a vowel so we change CE to CET.; cette and cet are pronounced exactly the same because the T sound is required in cet to manage the following noun that starts with a vowel.

question: this apartment
answer: cet appartement (pronounce as a single word); appartement is masculine so normally we would use CE (instead of CETTE). But the noun starts with a vowel. So CE transforms to CET.

question: this summer
answer: cet été ('set-a-tay'); Êté (summer) is masculine so we would normally choose CE. But the noun starts with a vowel so we change CE to CET.; cette and cet are pronounced the same. The T sound is required in cet (even though an E does not follow the final T) in order to manage the following noun that starts with a vowel.

question: this island
answer: cette île ('se-teel'); Île (island) is feminine. Use CETTE regardless of whether or not the noun starts with a vowel.

question: What is a demostrative pronoun?
answer: A demonstrative pronoun stands alone in place of a noun. It shows which one you are talking about without mentioning the noun at all. e.g. THIS (one) bit me. THE ONE who bit me.; Pronouns in English that can be used as demonstrative pronouns are: this + that + these + those.; NB: In English we sometimes say 'this/that one' or 'these/those ones' instead of simply this/that/these/those. But French is more deterministic in terms of word choice.

question: What are the demonstrative pronouns (this/these) in French?
answer: Regular demonstrative pronouns must agree in gender and number with the noun that they represent: celui (masc sing) + celle (fem sing) + ceux (masc pl) + celles (fem pl). Additionally there are indefinite/neuter demonstrative pronouns that do not agree in gender/number: ça + ce + ceci + cela.; e.g. NB: In French demonstrative pronouns CANNOT be used to represent people - only things.; NB: CE can be either a demonstrative article/adjective or an indefinite/neuter demonstrative pronoun.

question: After talking about hats... How do you say?: the one that is on the chair
answer: celui qui est sur la chaise; CELUI is the masculine singular demonstrative pronoun (= this/that/the one).

question: After talking about dresses... How do you say?: the one that is on the bed
answer: celle qui est sur le lit; CELLE is the feminine singular demonstrative pronoun (= this/that/the one).

question: After talking about hats... How do you say?: the ones that on the couch
answer: ceux qui sont sur le canapé; CEUX is the masculine plural demonstrative pronoun (= these/those/the ones).

question: After talking about dresses... How do you say?: the ones that are on the table
answer: celles qui sont sur la table; CELLES is the feminine plural demonstrative pronoun (= these/those/the ones).

question: After talking about a person... How do you say?: the one over there
answer: cette personne là; We cannot use demonstrative pronouns (celui/celle/ceux/celles) to reference people - only things.

question: When you are physically pointing out something... This one (here). (m/f)
answer: The thing is singular: celui-ci (m) / celle-ci (f); We are just adding 'here' (ici) to the singular demonstrative pronouns (celui and celle) that mean this/that/the one.

question: When you are physically pointing out something... These ones (here). (m/f)
answer: The things are plural: ceux-ci (m) / celles-ci (f); We are just adding 'here' (ici) to the plural demonstrative pronouns (ceux and celles) that mean these/those/the ones.

question: When you are physically pointing out something... That one (there). (m/f)
answer: The thing is singular: celui-là (m) / celle-là (f); We are just adding 'there' (là) to the singular demonstrative pronouns (celui and celle) that mean this/that/the one.

question: When you are physically pointing out something... Those ones (there). (m/f)
answer: The things are plural: ceux-là (m) / celles-là (f); We are just adding 'there' (là) to the plural demonstrative pronouns (ceux and celles) that mean these/those/the ones.

question: When do you use voilà vs voici?
answer: The suffixes change the meaning. -là (there) vs -ici (here). Voilà is more general like a conclusion e.g. There it is. There you have it.; Voici is tangible like something you have in your hand that you are showing or giving e.g. Here he/she/it is. Here they are. Here you go.

question: What do you say when you come to a conclusion. e.g. There you have it.
answer: voilà; If you are instead displaying or giving over something tangible like change or a document then use voici instead of voilà.

question: What do you say when you hand over a document (le document)?
answer: LE voici or voici; Literally: Here he is.; Use voici (instead of voilà) because you are showing or handing over something tangible that is right there.

question: What do you say when you hand over a carte vitale (la carte vitale)?
answer: LA voici or voici; Literally: Here she is.; Use voici (instead of voilà) because you are showing or handing over something tangible that is right there.

question: What do you say when you hand over some objects (des objets)?
answer: LES voici or voici; Literally: Here they are.; Use voici (instead of voilà) because you are showing or handing over something tangible that is right there.

question: What is ça?
answer: Ça ('sah') is an indefinite/neuter demonstrative pronoun. It means 'this/that (one)'. It is a more familiar alternative to the other indefinite demonstrative pronouns: ce + ceci + cela.; It is also an alternative to demonstrative pronouns that must agree in gender/number with the noun they represent: celui + celle + ceux + celles.

question: What is ce?
answer: Ce is an indefinite/neuter demonstrative pronoun. It means 'this/that (one)'. CE can only be followed by a small selection of verbs: être + pouvoir + devoir. Furthermore if there is a double verb then the second verb must also be one of those three. For example you cannot say: Ce doit commencer. But you could say: Ce doit être.

question: This/That is... +  These/Those are...
answer: C'est ('say')...  + Ce sont ('suh-son')... ; CE is a generic indefinite/neuter demonstrative pronoun. CE is special because it is only used with the verbs être + pouvoir + devoir. If you use a different verb then you must use ÇA instead of CE.; NB: CE always contracts when followed by a word that starts with a vowel. ÇA contracts some of the time but not always.

question: This/That is not... + These/Those are not...
answer: Ce n'est pas... + Ce ne sont pas...; CE is a generic indefinite/neuter demonstrative pronoun. CE is special because it is only used with the verbs être + pouvoir + devoir. If you use a different verb then you must use ÇA instead of CE.; NB: CE always contracts when followed by a word that starts with a vowel. ÇA contracts some of the time but not always.

question: It's not complicated.
answer: If you choose an indefinite/neuter demonstrative pronoun (to represent it) then there are two options: 1) Ça n'est pas compliqué. 2) Ce n'est pas compliqué.; The meanings are the same.

question: It begins.
answer: Ça commence.; You cannot say: Ce commence. because CE can only be used with the verbs être + pouvoir + devoir.

question: What do ceci and cela mean?
answer: Both are indefinite/neuter demonstrative pronouns (like ça and ce).; CECI = this here. It is a contraction of CE (indefinite/neuter demonstrative pronoun meaning this/that one) and ICI (here).; CELA = that there. It is a contraction of CE and LÀ (there).; ÇA can be used as an alternative to all of these and it is the best choice for most scenarios. Use ceci and cela in very formal communication.

question: What are les relatifs (relative pronouns)?
answer: A pronoun that shows a relationship between a noun and a clause. Relative pronouns introduce a relative clause (a phrase that gives more information about the subject). Relative pronouns can be used to connect phrases that have the same subject to avoid repitition.; Example: A hat is on the table. This hat is blue. ...becomes... The hat THAT is on the table is blue. THAT is the relative pronoun. 'that is on the table' is the relative clause.

question: What are the les relatifs (list the actual pronouns) in English and French?
answer: Examples of relative pronouns in English: that + which + who + + whom + whose + where + when. Examples of relative pronouns in French: qui + que + lequel + auquel + duquel + dont + où.; NB: The choice of word is more flexible in English than it is in French. In French the preposition in play often dictates which relative pronoun to use.; NB: Many of these pronouns can also be used as demonstrative pronouns/articles (used to show exactly which one) or interrogative pronouns (used to ask a question). But in those cases the words are serving a slightly different purpose.

question: What is the difference between a restrictive and a descriptive clause?
answer: Restrictive Clause: A relative clause that (working from the noun) hones in on a subgroup or a single item that you are talking about. It is necessary to the meaning of the sentence (therefore not separated from the sentence by pair of commas). It should use 'that' (instead of 'which'). e.g. I like roller coasters THAT have lots of loops.; Descriptive Clause: A relative clause that adds contextual information about the noun. It not is necessary to the meaning of the sentence (therefore it is separated from the sentence by pair of commas). It should use 'which' (instead of 'that'). e.g. The students complained about the book` WHICH was hard to follow.; We need to know the difference between a restrictive clause and a descriptive clause in order to know whether to use 'that' or 'which' at.

question: the woman who is walking by
answer: La femme QUI passe.; Use relative pronoun QUI because 'who' in this case represents the subject (the person/thing doing the action). Hint: Use QUI when the relative pronoun is followed directly by a verb (or COI/COD pronouns + verb)

question: the hat that I am wearing
answer: Le chapeau QUE je porte.; Use relative pronoun QUE because 'that' in this case represents a direct object (the person/thing receiving the action). Hint: Use QUE when the relative pronoun is followed directly by the subject (not a verb).

question: the woman who arrives
answer: La femme QUI arrive.; QUI does not contract when followed by a vowel (unlike que)!; Use relative pronoun QUI because 'who' in this case represents the subject doing the action. Hint: Use QUI when the relative pronoun is followed directly by a verb (or COI/COD pronouns + verb).

question: the man that she likes
answer: Le homme QU'ELLE aime.; QUE contracts when followed by a vowel (unlike qui)!; Use relative pronoun QUE because 'that' in this case represents the object receiving the action. Hint: Use QUE when the relative pronoun is followed directly by a noun - the subject of the phrase.

question: the dress that is interesting + the dress that he loves
answer: La robe QUI est intéressant. La robe QU'IL aime.; QUI never contracts but QUE contracts when followed by a vowel.

question: you (formal) who look at yourself in the mirror
answer: Vous QUI vous regardez dans le miroir.; Use QUI (instead of QUE) because it represents the subject and is followed by the verb.; This is a case where a conjugated verb does not follow QUI directly. That is because the verb (SE REGARDER) is reflexive. So 'vous' in this case is just another pronoun. It is not the subject of the phrase.

question: the person who you (formal) are watching
answer: La personne QUE vous regardez.; The relative pronoun 'who' represents the object of the verb so use QUE instead of QUI.; In this case the verb (REGARDER) is not reflexive because one thing is watching another thing. So the 'vous' that follows the pronoun is the subject pronoun - the person/thing that is doing the action in the phrase.

question: When do you use Qu'est-ce que...? vs Qu'est-ce qui...?
answer: The relative pronouns QUE and QUI work the same in questions as they do in statements. So Qu'est-ce QUE... is followed by a subject + verb. Qu'est ce QUI is followed by a verb (or COI/COD pronouns + verb). Generally you use the latter (QUI) when the subject has been dropped from the question. The subject could be dropped out of necessity for meaning or it may be dropped when someone is talking in a very casual and familiar way.
